l.explanation: length
The 12th letter of the modern English alphabet.
Any of the speech sounds represented by the letter l.
The 12th in a series.
Something shaped like the letter L.
A part of a house or other structure projecting at a right angle from the main body, so as to form with it the figure of the letter L: as, the building has an L of 20 feet.
A rectangularly bent pipe-connection. Also ell in both senses.
An abbreviation of the Latin (New Latin) Baccalaureus Litterarum , Bachelor of Letters.
In musical notation , an abbreviation for left hand.
locus sigilli , ‘place of the seal’: usually inserted within brackets in copies of documents to indicate the position of the seal in the originals.
Used colloquially for el. , an abbreviation of elevated , shortened from elevated railway .
An abbreviation of Literate in Arts .
Legum Baccalaureus , Bachelor of Laws.
chem. , for lithium: also Li ;

Laiin ;
left ;

lowercase ] in references, of line: as, Milton, Lycidas, l. 72;
lowercase ] of logarithm ;

electricity , the symbol for inductance (which see).

la.explanation: The sixth tone of the diatonic scale in solfeggio.
Used to express emphasis or indicate surprise.
In solmization , the syllable used for the sixth tone of the scale—that is, the submediant.
The feminine form of the definite article in French, occurring in some names and phrases used in English.
In chem. , the symbol for lanthanum.
A syllable applied to the sixth tone of the scale in music in solmization.
The tone A; -- so called among the French and Italians.
Look; see; behold; -- sometimes followed by you .
An exclamation of surprise; -- commonly followed by me
Prefixed to the name of a woman , with ironic effect (as though an opera prima donna ).
A syllable used in solfège to represent the sixth note of a major scale .
Used to introduce a statement with emphatic or intensive effect.
a state in southern United States on the Gulf of Mexico; one of the Confederate states during the American Civil War
a white soft metallic element that tarnishes readily; occurs in rare earth minerals and is usually classified as a rare earth
the syllable naming the sixth (submediant) note of a major or minor scale in solmization

laager.explanation: A defensive encampment encircled by armored vehicles or wagons.
To camp in a defensive encirclement.
In South Africa, an encampment; an inclosure for temporary defense formed of the wagons of a traveling party.
A camp, especially one surrounded by a circular formation of travelers' wagons for temporary defense.
To form into, or camp in, a laager, or protected camp.
A defensive encampment encircled by wagons , especially by South African Boers .
A temporary formation of armoured vehicles for resupply.
a camp defended by a circular formation of wagons

lab.explanation: A blabber; a tattler; a telltale.
To prate; to gossip; to babble; to blab.
Of or pertaining to a laboratory.
A telltale; a prater; a blabber.
a workplace for the conduct of scientific research

labadist.explanation: A follower of Jean de Labadie (1610–74), a Jesuit, afterward a mystic Protestant preacher in France and Holland.

A follower of Jean de Labadie, a religious teacher of the 17th century, who left the Roman Catholic Church and taught a kind of mysticism, and the obligation of community of property among Christians.

labarum.explanation: An ecclesiastical banner, especially one carried in processions.
The banner adopted by Constantine I after his conversion to Christianity.
A Roman military standard adopted by the later emperors as the imperial standard.
A standard or banner of similar form, borne in ecclesiastical processions of the Roman Catholic Church.
Figuratively, a moral standard, guide, or device.

The standard adopted by the Emperor Constantine after his conversion to Christianity. It is described as a pike bearing a silk banner hanging from a crosspiece, and surmounted by a golden crown. It bore a monogram of the first two letters (ΧΡ) (which appear like the English letters X and P), of the name of Christ in its Greek form. Later, the name was given to various modifications of this standard.
The Roman military standard adopted by Constantine I. The banner was known for its Christian chi-rho sign - ☧ .

labba.explanation: In British Guiana, a name applied to the paca, Cælogenys paca. It seems formerly to have been also used for the agouti, as the name occurs in books of West Indian travel, and the paca was never a resident of the West Indies.

labdanum.explanation: A resin of certain Mediterranean rockroses of the genus Cistus, yielding a fragrant essential oil used in flavorings and perfumes.
A sticky brown resin obtained from species of rockrose , used mainly in perfume .
a soft blackish-brown resinous exudate from various rockroses used in perfumes especially as a fixative
a dark brown to greenish oleoresin that has a fragrant odor and is used as a fixative in perfumes; obtained as a juice from certain rockroses

labefactation.explanation: A weakening or loosening; a failing; decay; downfall; ruin.

labefaction.explanation: The act of labefying or making weak; the state of being weakened; decay; ruin.
The act of shaking or weakening or the resulting state ; overthrow , ruination .

labefied.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of labefy .

label.explanation: An item used to identify something or someone, as a small piece of paper or cloth attached to an article to designate its origin, owner, contents, use, or destination.
A descriptive term; an epithet.
A distinctive name or trademark identifying a product or manufacturer, especially a recording company.
A molding over a door or window; a dripstone.
A figure in a field consisting of a narrow horizontal bar with several pendants.
To attach a label to.
To identify or designate with a descriptive term; describe or classify.
To add a tracer to (a compound).
In botany , same as labellum , 1.
label a package to be despatched by express.
labeled poison.
architecture , to furnish with labels or hood-moldings. See label , n. , 7.
A small loosely hanging flap; specifically, a pendant like a broad ribbon hanging from a head-dress; a lappet.
In heraldry :
One of the ribbons that hang down from a miter or the electoral crown. See infula , 3 .
A fillet resembling a barrulet with three or more pendent drops or points, which were originally straight with parallel sides, but are now usually shaped like a dovetail.
A slip of paper or any other material, bearing a name, title, address, or the like, affixed to something to indicate its nature, contents, ownership, destination, or other particulars.
A narrow slip of parchment or paper, or a ribbon of silk, affixed to a diploma, deed, or other formal writing, to hold the appended seal.
In law , a paper annexed to a will by way of addition, as a codicil.
A small reserved space in a work of art, or the like, forming a panel or cartouche, used for containing a name, monogram, or other mark for identification.
In medieval architecture , a projecting tablet or molding over a door or window. See dripstone , Also called label-molding .
A long, thin brass rule, with a small sight at one end and a centerhole at the other, commonly used with a tangent line on the edge of a circumferentor, to take altitudes, etc.
Border; verge; marge.
To affix a label to; to mark with a name, etc..
To affix in or on a label.
A tassel.
A slip of silk, paper, parchment, etc., affixed to anything, and indicating, usually by an inscription, the contents, ownership, destination, etc..
A slip of ribbon, parchment, etc., attached to a document to hold the appended seal; also, the seal.
A writing annexed by way of addition, as a codicil added to a will.
A barrulet, or, rarely, a bendlet, with pendants, or points, usually three, especially used as a mark of cadency to distinguish an eldest or only son while his father is still living.
A brass rule with sights, formerly used, in connection with a circumferentor, to take altitudes.
The name now generally given to the projecting molding by the sides, and over the tops, of openings in mediæval architecture. It always has a square form, as in the illustration.
In mediæval art, the representation of a band or scroll containing an inscription.
A small ticket or sign giving information about something to which it is attached or intended to be attached.
A name given to something or someone to categorise them as part of a particular social group.
A company that sells records .
A user-defined alias for a numerical designation, the reverse of an enumeration .
A named place in source code that can be jumped to using a GOTO or equivalent construct.
To put a label (a ticket or sign) on (something).
To give a label to (someone or something) in order to categorise that person or thing.
assign a label to; designate with a label
pronounce judgment on
an identifying or descriptive marker that is attached to an object
trade name of a company that produces musical recordings
distinguish (as a compound or molecule) by introducing a labeled atom
attach a tag or label to
a radioactive isotope that is used in a compound in order to trace the mechanism of a chemical reaction
distinguish (an element or atom) by using a radioactive isotope or an isotope of unusual mass for tracing through chemical reactions

labeled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of label .
bearing or marked with a label or tag

labeler.explanation: One who affixes labels to anything.
A person or device that produces or affixes labels.

labeling.explanation: A set of labels applied to the various objects in a system.

The introduction of a traceable chemical group (e.g., containing an isotope or a fluorescent dye ) into a protein or other biomolecule of interest so it can be tracked or quantified during experimental analysis .

labelled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of label .
bearing or marked with a label or tag

labelloid.explanation: Of or pertaining to the labellum , the lower central petal of the orchid .

labellum.explanation: The median petal of an orchid flower, usually different in shape, size, or color from the two lateral petals; lip.
A liplike part, such as the tip of the labium of certain flies, used for lapping up liquids.
In botany , one of the three divisions of an orchidaceous corolla, differing from the others in shape or direction, and not seldom spurred; the lip.
In entomology , a part of the mouth of an insect, by some considered to be the epipharynx. In Diptera the labellum is one of a pair of tumid lobes terminating the theca of the proboscis.
The lower or apparently anterior petal of an orchidaceous flower, often of a very curious shape.
A small appendage beneath the upper lip or labrum of certain insects.
The lower central petal of orchid flowers , usually developed to be showy and attract pollinators .

labels.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of label .

labia.explanation: A genus of earwigs of the family Forficulidæ , having the body short and the antennæ with fewer than twelve joints. L. minor is the little earwig, a European species found in manure-heaps and hotbeds.
The folds of tissue at the opening of the vulva .

labial.explanation: Of or relating to the lips or labia.
Articulated mainly by closing or partly closing the lips, as the sounds (b), (m), or (w).
A labial consonant.

anatomy and zoology , pertaining to the lips or to a lip-like part; situated on or by a lip; having a lip-like character, as in shape, position, or office: as, a labial vessel or nerve; a labial fold or process.
entomology , pertaining to the labium, or lower lip of an insect.
A letter or character representing an articulate sound which in speaking is accompanied by a proximate or complete closure of the lips.

In herpetology , one of a series of plates or scales which lie along the edge of the lips, especially in Ophidia , those of the upper lip being the superior labials , those of the lower lip the inferior labials.
In entomology , one of the labial palpi.
A letter or character representing an articulation or sound formed or uttered chiefly with the lips, as b , p , w .
An organ pipe that is furnished with lips; a flue pipe.
One of the scales which border the mouth of a fish or reptile.
Of or pertaining to the lips or labia.
Furnished with lips.
Articulated, as a consonant, mainly by the lips, as b, p, m, w.
Modified, as a vowel, by contraction of the lip opening, as � (f�d), ō (ōld), etc., and as eu and u in French, and ö, ü in German. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 11, 178.
Of or pertaining to the labium. See Labium .
Of or pertaining to the lips or labia
articulated by the lips, as the consonants b , m and w
Of an incisor or canine , on the side facing the lips. See mesial .
a labial consonant
an organ pipe having a lip that influences its sound
of or relating to the lips of the mouth
relating to or near the female labium
a consonant whose articulation involves movement of the lips

labialism.explanation: A tendency to labial pronunciation—that is, to change articulate sounds to labials or to labiodentals; labialization.
The quality of being labial; ; conversion into a labial, as of a sound which is different in another language.
A form of stammering characterized by confusion in the use of the labial consonants .

labiality.explanation: The character of being labial, especially in phonetics and music.
The quality of being labial , that is, lip - or labia -like.

labialize.explanation: To pronounce (a speech sound) with the lips touching , nearly touching, or pursed.
To modify by contraction of the lip opening.
To round , make (a sound, notably a consonant ) labial .

labialized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of labialize .

labially.explanation: In a labial manner; with, or by means of, the lips.
In a labial manner; by means of the lips .

labiatae.explanation: a large family of aromatic herbs and shrubs having flowers resembling the lips of a mouth and four-lobed ovaries yielding four one-seeded nutlets and including mint; thyme; sage; rosemary

labiate.explanation: Having or characterizing flowers with the corolla divided into liplike parts.
Of or belonging to the mint family.
A plant belonging to the mint family.
A plant of the natural order Labiatæ.
Having the limb of a tubular corolla or calyx divided into two unequal parts, one projecting over the other like the lips of a mouth, as in the snapdragon, sage, and catnip.
Belonging to a natural order of plants (Labiatæ), of which the mint, sage, and catnip are examples. They are mostly aromatic herbs.
A plant of the order Labiatæ.

labiate.category: botany, of flowers such as the snapdragon
labiate.explanation: having the corolla divided into two liplike parts
of, or belonging to the mint family (Labiatae).
a plant of the mint family (Labiatae)
having lips or parts that resemble lips

labidometer.explanation: In obstetrics , a scale adapted to the handles of the forceps, which indicates the distance of the blades from each other when applied to the head of the child.
A forceps with a measuring attachment for ascertaining the size of the fetal head.
A specialized forceps or attachment to a regular forceps for measuring the size and curvature of the head of a fetus in the pelvis .

labidura.explanation: Orthoptera , distinguishing the Forficulidæ alone from other orthopterous insects: a synonym of Euplexoptera and of Dermaptera in a limited sense.

labiella.explanation: In Myriapoda , a median single or multiple piece of the deutomala, situated between the malulellæ.

labile.explanation: Open to change; readily changeable or unstable.
medicine , noting a mode of application of electricity in which the active electrode is passed back and forth over the nerve or muscle to be acted upon: opposed in this sense to slabile .
Liable to slip, err, fall, or apostatize.
Easily decomposed or inactivated when subjected to heat, radiation, or mildly acidic or alkaline conditions; -- of chemical compounds.
Liable to slip , err , fall , or apostatize .

labile.category: chemistry, of a compound or bond
labile.explanation: Kinetically unstable ; rapidly cleaved (and possibly reformed).
(chemistry, physics, biology) readily undergoing change or breakdown

lability.explanation: The quality of being labile; liability to lapse or err. Coleridge. See quotation under labile.
Instability, as, in chem. , the quality of being easily broken down to form simpler chemical compounds or even elements.
Liability to lapse, err, or apostatize.
The property of being labile{3}; -- of chemical compounds.

labilize.explanation: chem. , to make labile or more readily susceptible of change; make unstable.

labiodental.explanation: Articulated with the lower lip and upper teeth, as the sounds (f) and (v).
An articulate sound produced by the coöperation of the lips and the teeth, or the letter or character representing such sound. The labiodentals are f and verb
Formed or pronounced by the cooperation of the lips and teeth, as f and v .
articulated with the lower lip and upper teeth
a consonant whose articulation involves the lips and teeth

labiograph.explanation: In physiology and psychophysics , an instrument for recording the voluntary (in speaking) or involuntary movements of the lips.

labioguttural.explanation: phonetics , sounded in the throat and shaped by the lips.

labiomancy.explanation: Divination or interpretation by means of the motions of the lips; specifically, lip-reading.

labionasal.explanation: An articulate sound produced by the cooperation of the lips and the nose, or the letter or character representing such sound, namely, masculine In pronouncing m , the lips are closed and nasal passages are open.
Formed by the lips and the nose.
Labial and nasal ; pertaining to both the upper lip and the nose , or to both lips and the nose.

labioplasty.explanation: A plastic operation to replace the whole or a part of a lip which has been lost.
A plastic operation for making a new lip, or for replacing a lost tissue of a lip.

labiose.explanation: botany , having the (distinct) petals so arranged as to imitate a labiate corolla.
Having the appearance of being labiate; -- said of certain polypetalous corollas.
Having the appearance of being labiate ; said of certain polypetalous corollas .

labiovelar.explanation: Simultaneously labial and velar, as (kw) in quick.
a velar sound articulated with lip-rounding, i.e. labialization

labis.explanation: In the Greek and other Oriental churches, a small spoon, usually of silver, and with a cruciform handle, used to administer the eucharistic elements (the species of bread dipped in that of wine: see intinction ) to the laity.

labium.explanation: Any of four folds of tissue of the female external genitals.
A liplike structure, such as that forming the floor of the mouth of certain invertebrates, especially insects.
The inner margin of the opening of a gastropod shell.
One of the liplike divisions of a bilabiate corolla.
In anatomy and zoology , a lip or lip-like part. Specifically.
The lower or anterior lip of a bilabiate corolla
In Isoëtes , a lip-like structure formed by the lower margin of the foveola.
[capitalized] A genus of ichneumon-flies, with one small New Guinean species
The lip of an organ pipe.
The folds of integument at the opening of the vulva.

The organ of insects which covers the mouth beneath, and serves as an under lip. It consists of the second pair of maxillæ, usually closely united in the middle line, but bearing a pair of palpi in most insects. It often consists of a thin anterior part (ligula or palpiger) and a firmer posterior plate (mentum).
Inner margin of the aperture of a shell.
A liplike structure; especially one of the two pairs of folds of skin either side of the vulva .
The lip of a labiate corolla .
The lip against which pressured air is driven in a flue pipe in an organ .
a liplike structure that bounds a bodily orifice (especially any of the four labiate folds of a woman's vulva)

lablab.explanation: The Egyptian or black bean, Dolichos Lablab , a native of India, widely cultivated, and naturalized in most warm countries.
an East Indian name for several twining leguminous plants related to the bean, but commonly applied to the hyacinth bean ( Dolichos Lablab ).
Any of several twining leguminous plants related to the bean , especially the hyacinth bean.

labor.explanation: Physical or mental exertion, especially when difficult or exhausting; work. synonym : work .
A specific task or effort, especially a painful or arduous one.
A particular form of work or method of working.
Work for wages.
Workers considered as a group.
The trade union movement, especially its officials.
A political party representing workers' interests, especially in Great Britain.
The process by which childbirth occurs, beginning with contractions of the uterus and ending with the expulsion of the fetus or infant and the placenta.
To work; toil.
To strive painstakingly.
To proceed with great effort; plod.
To pitch and roll.
To suffer from distress or a disadvantage.
To undergo the labor of childbirth.
To deal with in exhaustive or excessive detail; belabor.
To distress; burden.
Of or relating to labor.
Of or relating to a Labor Party.
A Mexican land-measure, equal to 177 acres.

Work done by a human being or an animal; exertion of body or mind, or both, for the accomplishment of an end; effort made to attain useful results, in distinction from exercise for the sake of recreation or amusement.

Specifically, bodily toil; physical exertion for the sake of gain or reward; the use of muscular strength for the satisfaction of wants, in distinction from purely mental exertion and from the productive use of capital.
Work done or to be done; that which requires exertion or effort; a work; a performance; an achievement: as, the twelve labors of Hercules.
The laboring class; productive work as represented by those devoted to it: as, the claims or rights of labor ; the labor -market.
The pangs and efforts of childbirth; parturition; travail.

(Sp. pron. lä-bōr′ ). In the quicksilver-mines of California, any place where work has been or is going on; especially, in the plural, those parts of the mine from which ore is being extracted in some quantity; workings.
Synonyms Toil, Drudgery , etc. (see work ); effort, pains.
under or (formerly) of.
To struggle, plod, drudge, slave, suffer.
To work at; to work; to till; to cultivate by toil.
To form or fabricate with toil, exertion, or care.
To prosecute, or perfect, with effort; to urge strenuously.
To belabor; to beat.

Physical toil or bodily exertion, especially when fatiguing, irksome, or unavoidable, in distinction from sportive exercise; hard, muscular effort directed to some useful end, as agriculture, manufactures, and like; servile toil; exertion; work.
Intellectual exertion; mental effort.
That which requires hard work for its accomplishment; that which demands effort.
Travail; the pangs and efforts of childbirth.
Any pang or distress.
The pitching or tossing of a vessel which results in the straining of timbers and rigging.
A measure of land in Mexico and Texas, equivalent to an area of 1771/7 acres.

laborant.explanation: One who labors; a workman; specifically, a working chemist.

laboratorian.explanation: One who conducts scientific investigations in a laboratory.

laboratory.explanation: A room or building equipped for scientific experimentation or research.
An academic period devoted to work or study in such a place.
A place where drugs and chemicals are manufactured.
A place for practice, observation, or testing.
The space between the fire and the flue-bridges of a reverberatory furnace in which the work is performed.

A room, building, or workshop especially fitted with suitable apparatus for conducting investigations in any department of science or art, or for elaborating or manufacturing chemical, medicinal, or any similar products: as, a chemical or pharmaceutical laboratory ; hence, also, figuratively, any place where or in which similar processes are carried on by natural forces.
Milit. , an establishment for the manufacture of rockets, port-fires, fuses, percussion-caps, quick-and slow-matches, friction-primers, electric primers, etc., designed for military operations.
The workroom of a chemist; also, a place devoted to experiments in any branch of natural science. Hence, by extension, a place where something is prepared, or some operation is performed.
Any place, activity or situation suggestive of a scientific laboratory{1}, especially in being conducive to learning new facts by experimentation or by systematic observation.
a room , building or institution equipped for scientific research , experimentation or analysis
a place where chemicals , drugs or microbes are prepared or manufactured
a region resembling a laboratory inasmuch as it offers opportunities for observation and practice and experimentation
a workplace for the conduct of scientific research

labored.explanation: labored style of composition; a labored painting.
Bearing marks of labor and effort; elaborately wrought; not easy or natural
Simple past tense and past participle of labor .
Of an action that is difficult to perform .

laboredly.explanation: In a labored manner; with labor.

laborer.explanation: One who labors or works with body or mind, or both; specifically, one who is engaged in some toilsome physical occupation; in a more restricted sense, one who performs work which requires little skill or special training, as distinguished from a skilled workman; in the narrowest sense, such an unskilled workman engaged in labor other than that of a domestic servant, particularly in husbandry.
One who labors in a toilsome occupation; a person who does work that requires strength rather than skill, as distinguished from that of an artisan .
One who uses body strength instead of intellectual power to earn a wage , usually hourly .
someone who works with their hands; someone engaged in manual labor

laboring.explanation: That labors; performing labor; esp., performing coarse, heavy work, not requiring skill also, set apart for labor.
the oar which requires most strength and exertion; often used figuratively.

laborious.explanation: Marked by or requiring long, hard work.
laborious husbandman or mechanic; a laborious minister or pastor.
Requiring labor, perseverance, or sacrifices; toilsome; tiresome.
characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion; especially physical effort

laboriously.explanation: With great expenditure of effort, in a manner requiring much labor .

laboriousness.explanation: The quality of being laborious or attended with toil; toilsomeness; difficulty.
the quality of requiring extended effort

laborist.explanation: A member of a labor party or one who is an advocate of the interests of labor.
A physician who aids labor and delivery but does not provide prenatal care.

laborite.explanation: A member or supporter of a labor movement or union.
A member of a political party representing labor.
A supporter of a labor movement.
A member of a political party supporting labor .

laborless.explanation: Not involving labor; not laborious; easy.

labors.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of labor .

laborsaving.explanation: Designed to conserve human energy in performing work or to decrease the amount of human labor needed.
Describing something that makes work easier or faster.

laborsome.explanation: Made with, or requiring, great labor, pains, or diligence.
Likely or inclined to roll or pitch, as a ship in a heavy sea; having a tendency to labor.

laboulbenia.explanation: A genus of minute ascomycetous fungi containing numerous species parasitic upon insects, especially beetles.

labour.explanation: Effort expended on a particular task ; toil , work .
Workers in general; the working class, the workforce; sometimes specifically the labour movement, organised labour.
A political party or force aiming or claiming to represent the interests of labour.
The act of a mother giving birth .
The time period during which a mother gives birth.
To belabour , to emphasise or expand upon (a point in a debate, etc).
productive work (especially physical work done for wages)
concluding state of pregnancy; from the onset of contractions to the birth of a child
a political party formed in Great Britain in 1900; characterized by the promotion of labor's interests and formerly the socialization of key industries
strive and make an effort to reach a goal
a social class comprising those who do manual labor or work for wages

laboured.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of labour .
Of an action that is difficult to perform .
Of writing or speech or similar, stilted or not natural due to too much effort being used in the production.

labourer.explanation: a laborer; someone who works with their hands.
someone who works with their hands; someone engaged in manual labor

labours.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of labour .

laboursaving.explanation: designed to replace or conserve human and especially manual labor

laboursome.explanation: Requiring labour, laborious ; difficult , elaborate , involved .

labradorite.explanation: A usually brilliant blue or green variety of plagioclase feldspar that contains approximately equal proportions of sodium and calcium and occurs in silica-poor igneous rocks.
A lime-soda feldspar (see feldspar ), one of the species intermediate between the lime feldspar, anorthite, and the soda feldspar, albite, but more closely allied to the former.
A kind of feldspar commonly showing a beautiful play of colors, and hence much used for ornamental purposes. The finest specimens come from Labrador. See feldspar .
A plagioclase feldspar mineral , calcium sodium aluminum silicate, often very coarsely crystalline , used as a decorative stone for carvings and building façades.

labral.explanation: entomology , of or pertaining to the labrum.
Of or pertaining to a labrum (lip-like projection).

labret.explanation: An ornament inserted into a perforation in the lip.
A piece of stone, bone, shell, or other material, inserted into the lip or into the cheek near the mouth, which is pierced for the purpose.
a form of body piercing in which an object is attached to the lip

labrid.explanation: A fish of the family Labridæ. Also labridan .
Any of the family Labridae of marine fishes.

labroid.explanation: Labridæ or Labroidea , or having their characters.
A fish of the family Labridæ or of the superfamily Labroidæ.

Like the genus Labrus; belonging to the family Labridæ , an extensive family of marine fishes, often brilliantly colored, which are very abundant in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. The tautog and cunner are American examples.
Like or belonging to the genus Labrus or family Labridae of marine fishes , often brilliantly coloured, and very abundant in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

labroidea.explanation: Labroides of Cuvier and Labridæ of Günther, comprising the families Labridæ , Siphonognathidæ and Searidæ.

labrum.explanation: A lip or liplike structure, such as the one forming the roof of the mouth in insects.
The outer margin of the opening of a gastropod shell.
In Rom. archæol. , a bath-tub, especially one of those of hard, fine material more or loss richly sculptured, rather common in the museums of Italy. Also called lavabrum .
In zoöl, alip or lip-like part. Specifically
A lip or edge, as of a basin.
An organ in insects and crustaceans covering the upper part of the mouth, and serving as an upper lip. See Illust. of Hymenoptera .
The external margin of the aperture of a shell. See Univalve .
A large basin of warm water, with an overhanging lip , in a Roman bath .
The uppermost of the mouthparts ( trophi ) of a typical insect, such as a cockroach . Typically resembles an upper lip and forms part of the roof of the mouth in such insects .

labrus.explanation: The typical genus of Labridæ: so called from the thick fleshy lips.
A genus of marine fishes, including the wrasses of Europe. See wrasse .

labrys.explanation: a double-headed ax in Minoan mythology

laburnum.explanation: Any of several poisonous trees or shrubs of the genus Laburnum of the pea family, especially L. anagyroides, which is cultivated for its drooping clusters of yellow flowers.
A small leguminous tree, Cytisus Laburnum , a native of the Alps and neighboring mountains, much cultivated for the beauty of its pendulous racemes of yellow peashaped flowers.
One of numerous other species of the same genus, or of some similar plants of other genera.
A small leguminous tree ( Cytisus Laburnum ), native of the Alps. The plant is reputed to be poisonous, esp. the bark and seeds. It has handsome racemes of yellow blossoms.
Any tree of genus Laburnum , which have bright yellow flowers and are poisonous.
flowering shrubs or trees having bright yellow flowers; all parts of the plant are poisonous

labyrinth.explanation: An intricate structure of interconnecting passages through which it is difficult to find one's way; a maze.
The maze in which the Minotaur was confined.
Something highly intricate or convoluted in character, composition, or construction.
A group of complex interconnecting anatomical cavities.

An intricate combination of passages running into one another from different directions, in which it is difficult or impossible to find the way from point to point, or to reach the place of exit from the interior, without a clue or guide; a maze.
Any confused complication of objects, lines, ideas, etc.; any thing or subject characterized by intricate turnings or windings; a perplexity.
The internal ear; the essential organ of hearing.
In ornithology , same as tympanum , 2
.—5. In mining , an apparatus used in concentrating or dressing slimes.
A long chamber filled with deflectors or diaphragms placed alternately, used to cool and condense the fumes of mercury, other vapors, or smoke.
An edifice or place full of intricate passageways which render it difficult to find the way from the interior to the entrance.
Any intricate or involved inclosure; especially, an ornamental maze or inclosure in a park or garden, having high hedges separating confusingly convoluted passages.
Any object or arrangement of an intricate or involved form, or having a very complicated nature.
An inextricable or bewildering difficulty.
The internal ear. See Note under Ear .
A series of canals through which a stream of water is directed for suspending, carrying off, and depositing at different distances, the ground ore of a metal.
A pattern or design representing a maze, -- often inlaid in the tiled floor of a church, etc.
A maze , especially underground or covered .
Part of the inner ear .
Anything complicated and confusing , like a maze.
To enclose in a labyrinth, or as though in a labyrinth.
To arrange in the form of a labyrinth.
a complex system of interconnecting cavities; concerned with hearing and equilibrium
complex system of paths or tunnels in which it is easy to get lost

labyrinthal.explanation: Pertaining to, or resembling, a labyrinth; intricate; labyrinthian.
Like a maze or labyrinth , intricate or convoluted . labyrinthine .

labyrinthian.explanation: Intricately winding; like a labyrinth; perplexed; labyrinthal.
mazelike , having long corridors and passageways that seemingly have no exit.
resembling a labyrinth in form or complexity

labyrinthibranch.explanation: One of the Labyrinthibranchii. Sir John Richardson.
Of or pertaining to the Labyrinthici.

labyrinthibranchii.explanation: Acanthopterygii: fishes having the body compressed, oblong or elevated, scales of moderate size, and a superbranchial organ in a cavity accessory to the gillcavity for the purpose of retaining water. It includes the Labyrinthici or Anabantidæ and the Luciocephalidæ.

labyrinthic.explanation: Like or pertaining to a labyrinth.

labyrinthical.explanation: labyrinthine ; like or relating to a labyrinth

labyrinthically.explanation: In a labyrinthic or mazy fashion; with twistings or confusion.

labyrinthici.explanation: Acanthopterygii labyrinthibranchii , having dorsal or anal spines present, sometimes in great numbers. It is equivalent to the family Anabantudæ.
An order of teleostean fishes, including the Anabas, or climbing perch, and other allied fishes.

labyrinthiform.explanation: botany , characterized by intricate and sinuous lines, as in Dædalia .
Having the form of a labyrinth; intricate.
Having the form of a labyrinth ; intricate .

labyrinthine.explanation: Relating to, resembling, or constituting a labyrinth.
Pertaining to, or like, a labyrinth; labyrinthal; labyrinthian.
Physically resembling a labyrinth ; with the qualities of a maze .
relating to or affecting or originating in the inner ear
resembling a labyrinth in form or complexity

labyrinthitis.explanation: Inflammation of the labyrinth of the internal ear.
inflammation of the labyrinth of the inner ear
inflammation of the inner ear; can cause vertigo and vomiting

labyrinthodon.explanation: The typical genus of Labyrintho - dontidæ , containing certain fossil amphibians whose teeth have the enamel folded and sunk inward and are labyrinthine in structure, whence the name.
A member of the genus Labyrinthodon or order Labyrin-thodontia ; any labyrinthodont.
A genus of very large fossil amphibians, of the Triassic period, having bony plates on the under side of the body. It is the type of the order Labyrinthodonta. Called also Mastodonsaurus.

labyrinthodont.explanation: Having teeth with a labyrinthine internal structure.
Of or relating to an extinct group of amphibians having a labyrinthine tooth structure, often classified in the subclass (or superorder) Labyrinthodontia.
A labyrinthodont animal; a member of the order Labyrinthodontia.
Of or pertaining to the Labyrinthodonta.
Having teeth with a labyrinthine (maze-like) internal structure
Any extinct amphibian of the subclass Labyrinthodontia
an amphibian of the superorder Labyrinthodontia

labyrinthodontoid.explanation: A stegocephalous amphibian related to the genus Labyrinthodon.

labyrinthula.explanation: The typical genus of Labyrinthulidæ , containing such species as L. vitellina , a marine form found on algæ, growing in patches visible to the naked eye.

lac.explanation: A resinous secretion of lac insects, used in making shellac.
A Middle English form of lack .
The sum of 100,000, usually of rupees.
A resinous incrustation deposited on the twigs of various trees in India and southern Asia by the lac-insect, Carteria lacca.

A resinous substance produced mainly on the banyan tree, but to some extent on other trees, by the Laccifer lacca (formerly Coccus lacca ), a scale-shaped insect, the female of which fixes herself on the bark, and exudes from the margin of her body this resinous substance.
a resinous exudation of the tree Croton lacciferum , resembling lac.
a scarlet dye obtained from stick-lac.
the coloring matter of lac dye when precipitated from its solutions by alum.
an exudation of the tree Croton Draco .
One hundred thousand; also, a vaguely great number.
One hundred thousand (commonly used in Pakistan and India).
A resinous substance produced mainly on the banyan tree by the female of Coccus lacca, a scale-shaped insect.
resinlike substance secreted by certain lac insects; used in e.g. varnishes and sealing wax

laccase.explanation: An oxidizing ferment which is concerned in the production of the black Japanese lacquer. It is obtained from the Japanese lac-tree, Rhus vernicifera , and from various fungi.
Any of several copper - containing oxidase enzymes found in plants and microorganisms .

laccic.explanation: 16 H 12 O 8 (?) obtained from lac-dye by the action of dilute hydrochloric acid. It crystallizes in minute plates, decomposes without melting at about 180° C, and resembles carminic acid.
Pertaining to lac, or produced from it.
Characteristic of lac , such as in laccic acid

laccin.explanation: A yellow amorphous substance obtained from lac.
A yellow amorphous substance obtained from lac .

laccol.explanation: A compound contained in the juice of the lac-tree, Rhus vernicifera.

laccolite.explanation: A mass of igneous rock intruded between sedimentary beds and resulting in a mammiform bulging of the overlying strata.

laccolith.explanation: A mass of igneous rock intruded between layers of sedimentary rock, resulting in uplift.

A name given by G. K. Gilbert to masses of lava which, when rising from below, have not found their way to the surface, but have spread out laterally, and formed a lenticular aggregation, thereby lifting the rocks above into dome-shaped forms.
a mass of igneous or volcanic rock found within strata which forces the overlaying strata upwards and forms domes .
mass similar to lopolith but concave up.

lace.explanation: A cord or ribbon used to draw and tie together two opposite edges, as of a shoe.
A delicate fabric made of yarn or thread in an open weblike pattern.
Gold or silver braid ornamenting an officer's uniform.
To thread a cord through the eyelets or around the hooks of.
To draw together and tie the laces of.
To restrain or constrict by tightening laces, especially of a corset.
To pull or pass through; intertwine.
To trim or decorate with or as if with lace.
To add a touch of flavor to.
To add a substance, especially an intoxicant or narcotic, to.
To add or intersperse with something in order to produce a certain effect.
To streak with color.
To give a beating to; thrash.
To be fastened or tied with laces or a lace.
A machine-made lace of coarse cotton thread.
A pillow-lace with geometric designs.
lace a shoe.
laced waistcoat.
laced with a drop of brandy.
lace in front.
A noose; snare; net.

A cord or string used in binding or fastening; specifically, a cord or string used for drawing together opposite edges, as of a corset, a bodice, a shoe, or the like, by being passed out and in through holes and fastened.

Hence, any ornamental cord or braid used as an edging or trimming, especially when made of gold or silver thread. See gold lace , below—4. A fabric of fine threads of linen, silk, or cotton, whether twisted or plaited together or worked like embroidery, or made by a combination of these processes, or (as at the present time) by machinery.
Spirits added to coffee or other beverage.
A stringer; beam.
A blaek-silk lace, in demand because made in unusually large pieces, as for shawls, fichus, etc.
Buckingham trolly (which see, under trolly ), and
a lace having a point ground, which is peculiar in having the pattern outlined with, thicker threads, these threads being weighted by bobbins larger and heavier than the rest.
At the presentday, the finest Brussels lace, where needle-point sprigs are applied to Brussels bubbin-ground. See application-lace , above.
A general name for Valenciennes made in Belgium.
Same as bobbin-lace .
A white pillow-lace, originally made at Grammont in Belgium.
A black-silk lace like blond-lace.
In the seventeenth century, a guipure, more delicate in texture and varied in design than other guipures.
At the present day, an application lace, made of sprigs of bobbin-lace sewed upon grounds often made elsewhere, especially of the Alençon réseau.
Lace which has been whitened. See powder , v. t.
Cut and drawn work made in convents in Spain, of patterns usually confined to simple sprigs and flowers
A modern black silk lace with large flower patterns, mostly of Flemish make
A modern needle-made fabric, the pattern usually in large squares.
To be fastened with a lace, or laces.

That which binds or holds, especially by being interwoven; a string, cord, or band, usually one passing through eyelet or other holes, and used in drawing and holding together parts of a garment, of a shoe, of a machine belt, etc.
A snare or gin, especially one made of interwoven cords; a net.

lacebark.explanation: A small tree of the West Indies, the Lagetta lintearia , natural order Thymelæaceæ , so called from the texture of its inner bark, which consists of numerous concentric layers of fibers interlacing in all directions. It is made into sleeves, collars, purses, etc.
In New South Wales, Sterculia acerifolia , the flame-tree.
In New Zealand, a malvaceous tree, Plagianthus betulinus.
A small tree or shrub ( Hoheria populnea ) of New Zealand having a profusion of axillary clusters of honey-scented paper-white flowers and whose bark is used for cordage.
Any of various New Zealand plants in the genus Hoheria.
small tree or shrub of New Zealand having a profusion of axillary clusters of honey-scented paper-white flowers and whose bark is used for cordage

laced.explanation: Fastened with a lace or laces; decorated with narrow strips or braid. See lace , v. t.
a strong stocking which can be tightly laced; -- used in cases of weak legs, varicose veins, etc.
Tainted with something, especially a drug.
Simple past tense and past participle of lace .
Especially of shoelaces, intertwined and neatly knotted.

laceman.explanation: A man who deals in lace.
A man who deals in lace.

lacepod.explanation: annual herb having pinnatifid basal leaves and slender racemes of small white flowers followed by one-seeded winged silicles

lacer.explanation: A person or thing who laces
a workman who laces shoes or footballs or books (during binding)

lacerable.explanation: That can be lacerated or torn.
Susceptible to laceration ; capable of being, or liable to be, torn.

lacerate.explanation: To cause deep emotional pain to; distress.
lacerate the flesh; a lacerated wound.
lacerated ) to a leaf having the edge variously cut into irregular segments, and in anatomy to three foramina at the base of the cranium. See below.
Jagged, or slashed irregularly, at the end, or along the edge.
To tear; to rend; to separate by tearing; to mangle.
Jagged , as if torn or lacerated .
having edges that are jagged from injury
irregularly slashed and jagged as if torn
deeply hurt the feelings of; distress

lacerated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lacerate .
having edges that are jagged from injury
irregularly slashed and jagged as if torn

lacerates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of lacerate .

laceration.explanation: In Actinozoa , the formation of a new polyp by the separation of a portion of the basal expansion by contraction of the body.
The act of lacerating or tearing or rending.
A rough or jagged breach made by rending.
A wounding or harrowing, as of the feelings or sensibility.
A breach or wound made by lacerating.
An irregular open wound caused by a blunt impact to soft tissue.

lacerative.explanation: Lacerating, or having the power to lacerate.
Lacerating, or having the power to lacerate .

lacert.explanation: A muscle of the human body.
A fleshy muscle of the human body .

lacertian.explanation: Lacertæ or Lacertilia ; saurian, in a narrow sense.
Like a lizard; of or pertaining to the Lacertilia.

lacertid.explanation: A lizard of the restricted family Lacertidæ.
Any lizard of the family Lacertidae, a family of Old World terrestrial lizard.
Any lizard of the family Lacertidae

lacertidae.explanation: A natural family of Old World lizards.

lacertilian.explanation: Any of various lizards and closely related reptiles.
Lacertilia , or having their characters; lacertiform; saurian.
One of the Lacertilia ; a saurian.
Relating to the reptilian suborder Lacertilia.

lacertiloid.explanation: Like or belonging to the Lacertilia.
Resembling or belonging to the Lacertilia.

laces.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of lace .

lacet.explanation: In needlework , a trimming made of a braid known as lacet braid fashioned into various designs with lace stitches.

lacewing.explanation: Any of various neuropteran insects of several families, especially Chrysopidae and Hemerobiidae, having predaceous larvae and, in the adult, two pairs of delicate, many-veined wings and long antennae.

Any one of several species of neuropterous insects of the genus Chrysopa and allied genera. They have delicate, lacelike wings and brilliant eyes. Their larvæ are useful in destroying aphids. Called also lace-winged fly , and goldeneyed fly .
Any of several gauzy - winged insects of the families Chrysopidae and Hemerobiidae.
any of two families of insects with gauzy wings (Chrysopidae and Hemerobiidae); larvae feed on insect pests such as aphids

lacewood.explanation: Any of several types of wood that has a coarse texture , but especially that from several varieties of sycamore
variably colored and sometimes variegated hard tough elastic wood of a sycamore tree

lacework.explanation: A piece or example of lace .
work consisting of (or resembling) lace fabric

lache.explanation: A Middle English form of latch .

lachenalia.explanation: A genus of bulbous plants of the family Liliaceæ.
Any of the genus Lachenalia of bulbs .

laches.explanation: A legal doctrine that bars a claimant from receiving relief where the claimant's delay in pursuing the claim has operated to the prejudice of the opposing party.
A genus of spiders: same as Lachesis , a name preoccupied in herpetology.
law , remissness in asserting or enforcing a right, or neglect prejudicing some right of the person chargeable with it.

Neglect; negligence; remissness; neglect to do a thing at the proper time; especially, a delay in asserting a claim, sufficient to cause a person to lose the right to adjuducation of the claim by a court.

Legal doctrine that a person who waits too long to bring a claim alleging a wrong shall not be permitted to seek an equitable remedy because the delay prejudiced the moving party. Sleeping on one's rights.

lachnosterna.explanation: A genus of scarabæoid beetles of the subfamily Melolonthinæ , characterized by the transverse, not prominent anterior coxæ, narrow side-pieces of the metasternum, and claws not serrate but with a single tooth.

lachrymal.explanation: Of or relating to tears, or the tear glands.
relating to or located near the organ that produces tears

lachrymary.explanation: Containing, or intended to contain, tears; lachrymal.
Containing or made to contain tears ; lachrymal .

lachrymation.explanation: The act of shedding tears; weeping.

lachrymator.explanation: A substance, such as tear gas, that causes tears to flow.
A chemical substance that causes tears to flow; same as lacrimator .
Any substance that causes tears ; especially tear gas
a gas that makes the eyes fill with tears but does not damage them; used in dispersing crowds

lachrymatory.explanation: Relating to or inducing tears; -- especially of chemical substances.

A “tear-bottle;” a narrow-necked vessel found in sepulchers of the ancient Romans; -- so called from a former notion that the tears of the deceased person's friends were collected in it. Called also lachrymal or lacrymal .
A vase intended to hold tears, formerly used by archaeologists to designate certain urns found in Roman burials.

lachrymiform.explanation: Having the form of a tear; tear-shaped.

lachrymose.explanation: Weeping or inclined to weep; tearful.
Causing or tending to cause tears.
Generating or shedding tears; given to shedding tears; suffused with tears; tearful.
tearful , sorrowful , sad, pertaining to tears , weeping , causing tears or crying

lacier.explanation: comparative form of lacy : more lacy

laciest.explanation: superlative form of lacy : most lacy .

lacing.explanation: Something that laces; a lace.
A touch of liquor added to a beverage or food.
A beating or thrashing.

In structural work, particularly bridge work, the system of slender, diagonal members which connect the two opposite parallel members or flanges of a structural iron or steel beam, column, or strut. In lacing the several members form a single, continuous zigzag line, but do not cross one another as in latticing.
The act of binding or fastening with a cord or thong passed backward and forward through holes or around buttons or hooks.
A method of fastening the adjoining ends of a belt by the use of a thong or lace.
In bookbinding , the fastening of the boards of a book to its back by cords which pass around the sewed threads of the signatures and through holes pierced in the boards.
A cord used in drawing tight or fastening; laces in general.
Nautical , the cord or rope used to lace a sail to a gaff, yard, or boom, or to fasten two parts of a sail or an awning together.
In ship-building , a piece of compass- or knee-timber fitted and bolted to the back of the figurehead and to its supporting piece, called the knee of the head. Also called lace-piece .
In mining , same as lagging , 3.
In the plumage of birds, especially in descriptions of standard or pure-bred poultry:
A border or edging of a different color from the center, completely surrounding the web of a feather
The coloration of plumage resulting from feathers marked as above, considered collectively.
In mathematics , a complex of three or more closed bands, so that no two are interlinked, yet so that they cannot be separated without breaking.
The act of securing, fastening, or tightening, with a lace or laces.
A lace
A rope or line passing through eyelet holes in the edge of a sail or an awning to attach it to a yard, gaff, etc.
A system of bracing bars, not crossing each other in the middle, connecting the channel bars of a compound strut.
A quantity of a substance, such as an alcoholic liquor, added to a food or a drink.
A beating, especially with a lash.
Present participle of lace .
That with which something is laced .
The tied laces that form a netlike pattern.
a cord that is drawn through eyelets or around hooks in order to draw together two edges (as of a shoe or garment)
the act of inflicting corporal punishment with repeated blows
a small amount of liquor added to a food or beverage

lacinia.explanation: A slash in or a slender lobe of a leaf or petal.
The apex of the insect maxilla.
In botany , a long slash or incision in a leaf, petal, or similar organ; also, one of the narrow lobes or segments resulting from such incisions.
In entomology , the apex of the maxilla, especially when it is slender and bladelike, as in many Coleoptera. See galea , 1 .
A genus of mollusks: same as Chama. Humphreys .
One of the narrow, jagged, irregular pieces or divisions which form a sort of fringe on the borders of the petals of some flowers.
A narrow, slender portion of the edge of a monophyllous calyx, or of any irregularly incised leaf.
The posterior, inner process of the stipes on the maxillæ of insects.
One of the narrow, jagged, irregular pieces or divisions which form a sort of fringe on the borders of the petals of some flowers .
A narrow, slender portion of the edge of a monophyllous calyx , or of any irregularly incised leaf.
The posterior inner process of the stipes on the maxillae of insects .

laciniate.explanation: Shaped or formed like a fringe, as a ligament.
botany , irregularly cut into narrow lobes; jagged: said of leaves, petals, bracts, etc.
zoology , lacerate; slashed or jagged at the end or along the edge; incised as if frayed out; fringe-like.
Cut into deep, narrow, irregular lobes; slashed.
Of, pertaining to, or having a fringe .
Cut into deep, narrow, irregular lobes ; slashed.
having edges irregularly and finely slashed

laciniform.explanation: zoology and botany , fringe like; laciniate in form: applied by Kirby to the tegulæ of insects when they are long, irregular, and like a fringe, on each side of the body, as in Lithosia .

laciniolate.explanation: botany , finely fringed; marked with minute laciniæ.
Consisting of, or abounding in, very minute laciniæ.
Consisting of, or abounding in, very minute laciniae .

lacinula.explanation: The abruptly inflexed acumen or point of each of the petals of an umbelliferous flower.

lack.explanation: Deficiency or absence.
A particular deficiency or absence.
To be without or in need of.
To be missing or deficient.
To be in need of something.
Want or deficiency of something requisite or desirable; defect; failure; need.
Want of presence; a state of being away; absence.
A want; defect; a blemish; especially, a moral defect; a fault in character.
A fault committed; an offense; a censurable act.
Blame; reproach; rebuke; censure.
lac .
lacky .

Lack, Need, Want. These words have come to overlap each other a good deal by figurative extension, and have considerable variety of peculiar idiomatic use. To lack is primarily and generally to be without, that which is lacked being generally some one thing, and a thing which is desirable, although generally not necessary or very important.
Good lack. See good .
Exclamation of regret or surprise.
To be wanting; often, impersonally, with of, meaning, to be less than, short, not quite, etc.
To be in want.
Blame; cause of blame; fault; crime; offense.
Deficiency; want; need; destitution; failure.
To blame; to find fault with.
To be without or destitute of; to want; to need.

To be without , to need, to require .
To be short (of or for something).
the state of needing something that is absent or unavailable
be without

in an idle and lackadaisical manner

lackadaisicalness.explanation: The state or quality of being lackadaisical .

lackaday.explanation: Used to express regret or disapproval.
Alack the day; alas; -- an expression of sorrow, regret, dissatisfaction, or surprise.
An expression of regret or grief .

lacked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lack .

lacker.explanation: One who lacks or is in want.

lackered.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lacker .

lackey.explanation: A liveried male servant; a footman.
To wait on as a footman; attend.
To act in a servile manner; fawn.
An attending servant; a runner; a footboy or footman; hence, any servile follower.
An attending male servant; a footman; a servile follower.

the caterpillar, or larva, of any bombycid moth of the genus Clisiocampa; -- so called from its party-colored markings. The common European species ( Clisiocampa neustria ) is striped with blue, yellow, and red, with a white line on the back. The American species ( Clisiocampa Americana and Clisiocampa sylvatica ) are commonly called tent caterpillars . See Tent caterpillar, under Tent .
the moth which produces the lackey caterpillar.

To act or serve as lackey; to pay servile attendance.
