a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage

lackland.explanation: One who lacks land or landed possessions; one who, like a younger son, inherits no territory: as, John Lackland , King of England.

lackluster.explanation: Lacking brightness, luster, or vitality; dull. synonym : dull .
A want of luster, or that which lacks brightness.
Lacking spirit, liveliness, or enthusiasm; dull.
Having no shine or lustre ; dull
Not exceptional ; not worthy of special merit , attention , or interest ; having no vitality

lacks.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of lack .

lacmoid.explanation: A coal-tar color used in dyeing: same as fluorescent resorcinal blue (which see, under blue ).

laconian.explanation: An inhabitant of Laconia, a division of the Peloponnesus in Greece, anciently constituting the country of the Spartans or Lacedæmonians, now a nomarchy of the kingdom of Greece; a Lacedæmonian or Spartan.
Of or pertaining to Laconia, a division of ancient Greece; Spartan.

laconic.explanation: Using or marked by the use of few words; terse or concise.
A concise, pithy expression; something expressed in a concise, pithy manner; a laconism: chiefly used in the plural: as, to talk in laconics.
In ancient prosody , an anapestic tetrameter catalectic with a spondee instead of the penultimate anapest . So called as a variety of the tetrameter used in the Laconian or Spartan embateria.
Expressing much in few words, after the manner of the Laconians or Spartans; brief and pithy; concise; brusque; epigrammatic. In this sense laconic is the usual form.
Laconian; characteristic of, or like, the Spartans; hence, stern or severe; cruel; unflinching.
Using as few words as possible; pithy and concise .
brief and to the point; effectively cut short

laconically.explanation: In a terse manner, given to using few words.

laconicism.explanation: A laconic mode or style of expression; laconism.
A laconic phrase or expression; a laconism.

laconicum.explanation: In Rom. archæol. , a vapor-bath; a chamber in a bathing-establishment warmed by means of air artificially heated: so called because the Laconians used such a dry or sudorific bath, avoiding the use of warm water as enervating.
A hot dry sweating room , next to the caldarium in a Roman baths

laconism.explanation: Terseness or succinctness of style or expression.
Pointed brevity of speech or expression; sententiousness; conciseness; pithiness.
A concise or pithy expression; an utterance conveying much meaning in few words.
A vigorous, brief manner of expression; laconic style.
An instance of laconic style or expression.
A very or notably brief expression.

laconize.explanation: To imitate the manner of the Laconians, especially in brief, pithy speech, or in frugality and austerity.
To imitate the manner of the Laconians , especially in brief , pithy speech , or in frugality and austerity .

laconized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of laconize .

lacquer.explanation: Any of various clear or colored synthetic coatings made by dissolving nitrocellulose or other cellulose derivatives together with plasticizers and pigments in a mixture of volatile solvents and used to impart a high gloss to surfaces.
A glossy, resinous material, such as the processed sap of the lacquer tree, used as a surface coating.
A finish that is baked onto the inside of food and beverage cans.
To coat with lacquer.
To give a sleek, glossy finish to.
Lac as used in dyeing.
An opaque varnish containing lac, properly so called.
Decorative work colored and then varnished so as to produce a hard, polished appearance like that of enamel.
A resinous varnish obtained from the Rhus vernicifera by making incisions in the bark.
Lacquer-ware; articles of wood which have been ornamented by coating with lacquer.
crude lacquer, the sap of the Rhus vernicifera of Japan.
lacquer colored with lampblack, used for drawing fine lines in the shading of feathers, hair, etc., on gold lacquer.
a variety of Japanese lacquer with small gold fiakes in irregular clusters. See nashiji lacquer .
a pure lacquer freed from water, exposed to the light, and stirred till it becomes black: used as a basis, or undercoating, on which the finishing lacquer is afterward placed.
a variety of Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold, in imitation of the skin of a pear. Also called a venturin lacquer .
a pure lacquer to which has been added water which had been used with a whetstone and contains fine particles of the stone in suspension: used on cheap ware.
a variety of Japanese lacquer of a pure black or greenish-black color.

a dark-green varnish made by adding to branchlacquer a small proportion of tooth-dye, which is prepared by boiling rice-vinegar in which iron filings have been placed, and by afterward exposing it to the rays of the sun for several days.

a variety of Japanese lacquer produced by mixing oil with the sap of the lacqner-tree ( Rhus vernicifera ). It is of a yellowish color and needs no polishing. When applied to furniture, being transparent, it shows the natural grain of the wood beneath.
a Japanese lacquer of a pure red color: same as coral or vermilion lacquer (which see, under coral ).
a red lacquer which requires no final polishing. See shunuri lacquer .
a red cinnabar lacquer with carved decoration, made in China.
a variety of Japanese lacquer with marbled or veined effects in various colors.
varnish obtained from the branches of the lacquer-tree; branch-lacquer. See seshime lacquer , under lacquer.

A varnish, consisting of a solution of shellac in alcohol, often colored with gamboge, saffron, or the like; -- used for varnishing metals, papier-maché, and wood. The name is also given to varnishes made of other ingredients, esp. the tough, solid varnish of the Japanese, with which ornamental objects are made.
To cover with lacquer.
A glossy , resinous material used as a surface coating ; either a natural exudation of certain trees, or a solution of nitrocellulose in alcohol , etc.
A similar finish , baked onto the inside of cans .
To apply a lacquer to something or to give something a smooth, glossy finish.
a hard glossy coating
coat with lacquer
a black resinous substance obtained from certain trees and used as a natural varnish

lacquered.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lacquer .

lacquerer.explanation: One who applies lacquer or produces lacquered ware.
One who lacquers, especially one who makes a business of lacquering.

lacquering.explanation: Finish or decoration in lacquer, especially Japanese lacquer.
The act or business of putting on lacquer; also, the coat of lacquer put on.

lacquey.explanation: alternative form of (to play the) lackey

lacrimal.explanation: Of, relating to, or constituting the glands that produce tears.
relating to or located near the organ that produces tears

lacrimation.explanation: Secretion of tears, especially in excess.

lacrimator.explanation: a chemical substance that causes tears to flow; same as lachrymator .
a gas that makes the eyes fill with tears but does not damage them; used in dispersing crowds

lacrimatory.explanation: relating to or inducing tears; -- especially of chemical substances; same as lachrymatory .

lacroixite.explanation: A monoclinic-prismatic mineral containing aluminum , fluorine , oxygen , phosphorus , and sodium .

lacrosse.explanation: A game played on a rectangular field by two teams of ten players each, in which participants use a long-handled stick that has a webbed pouch on one end to try to propel a ball into the opposing team's goal.
A game of ball played by two parties of players, twelve on each side, on a level plot of ground, at each end of which is a goal through which the players strive to hurl the ball.

A game of ball, originating among the North American Indians, now the popular field sport of Canada, and played also in England and the United States. Each player carries a long-handled racket, called a “ crosse ”. The ball is not handled but caught with the crosse and carried on it, or tossed from it, the object being to carry it or throw it through one of the goals placed at opposite ends of the field.
A sport played on a field between two opposing teams using sticks (crosses) and a ball, whereby one team defeats the other by achieving a higher score by scoring goals within the allotted time.
a game invented by American Indians; now played by two teams who use long-handled rackets to catch and carry and throw the ball toward the opponents' goal

lactagogue.explanation: A substance which induces lactation ; a galactagogue .

lactalbumin.explanation: The albumin contained in milk and obtained from whey.
An albuminous substance resembling serum, albumin which is found in milk.

lactam.explanation: A cyclic amide, or any compound containing it, formed by the intramolecular condensation of an amino carboxylic acid.

The name of a class of organic compounds containing the group or They are formed by the elimination of water from γ-or δ-amino acids respectively, the reaction being characteristic of these two classes of compounds. They are simple cyclicacid amides.
One of a series of anhydrides of an amido type, analogous to the lactones, as oxindol; a cyclic amide.
an antibiotic containing a beta-lactam, such as a penicillin , cephalosporin , or carbapenem ; also called a beta-lactam antibiotic .
Any of a class of cyclic amides , that are the nitrogen analogs of lactones , formed by heating amino acids ; the tautomeric enol forms are known as lactims .

lactamide.explanation: A colorless crystalline substance (C 3 H 7 NO 2 .) formed by the union of lactide and ammonia, whence the name.
An acid amide derived from lactic acid, and obtained as a white crystalline substance having a neutral reaction. It is metameric with alanine.
An acid amide derived from lactic acid , and obtained as a white crystalline substance having a neutral reaction. It is metameric with alanine .

lactarene.explanation: The commercial name for a preparation of the casein of milk, used by calico-printers like albumen.
A preparation of casein from milk, used in printing calico.
A preparation of casein from milk , used in printing calico .

lactarius.explanation: large genus of agarics that have white spore and contain a white or milky juice when cut or broken; includes both edible and poisonous species

lactary.explanation: A house used as a dairy.
Milky; full of white juice like milk.

lactase.explanation: An enzyme occurring in certain yeasts and in the intestinal juices of mammals and catalyzing the hydrolysis of lactose into glucose and galactose.
A ferment which inverts lactose to dextrose and galactose.
A β- galactosidase enzyme that is involved in the hydrolysis of the disaccharide lactose into constituent galactose and glucose monomers .
any of a group of enzymes (trade name Lactaid) that hydrolyze lactose to glucose and galactose

lactate.explanation: In chem. , a salt of lactic acid, or the acid of sour milk. The lactates are soluble in water, and many of them are uncrystallizable.
Any salt or ester of lactic acid
a salt or ester of lactic acid

lactated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lactate .

lactating.explanation: actively producing milk; -- of female mammals.

lactation.explanation: Secretion or formation of milk by the mammary glands.
The period during which the mammary glands secrete milk.
The formation or secretion of milk; the physiological function of secreting milk.
The act of giving suck, or the time of suckling.
The secretion and yielding of milk by the mammary gland; giving suck.
The secretion of milk from the mammary gland of a female mammal .
The process of providing the milk to the young; breastfeeding .
The period of time that a mother lactates to feed her young; lactation period.
the production and secretion of milk by the mammary glands
the period following birth during which milk is secreted
feeding an infant by giving suck at the breast

lacteal.explanation: Of, relating to, or resembling milk.
Of or relating to any of numerous minute intestinal lymph-carrying vessels that convey chyle from the intestine to lymphatic circulation and thereby to the thoracic duct.
In anatomy , one of numerous minute tubes which absorb or take up the chyle (a milk-like fluid) from the alimentary canal and convey it to the thoracic duct.
One of the lymphatic vessels which convey chyle from the small intestine through the mesenteric glands to the thoracic duct; a chyliferous vessel.
Pertaining to, or resembling, milk; milky.
Lactiferous ducts or other components of milk-producing organs.
any of the lymphatic vessels that convey chyle from the small intestine to the thoracic duct
relating to or consisting of or producing or resembling milk

lacteally.explanation: Milkily; in the manner of milk.
milkily ; in the manner of milk

lactean.explanation: Milky; consisting of, or resembling, milk.

lacteous.explanation: entomology , white with a very slight bluish-gray tinge, like the color of milk: applied generally to white surfaces which are somewhat translucent.

lactescence.explanation: The state of being lactescent; milkiness or milky coloration.
In botany , an abundant flow of juice or sap from a plant when wounded, commonly white, but sometimes yellow or red.
The state or quality of producing milk, or milklike juice; resemblance to milk; a milky color.
The latex of certain plants. See Latex .
The state or quality of producing milk , or milky sap .
Resemblance to milk; a milky colour.

lactescent.explanation: Secreting or yielding a milky sap.
botany , abounding in a thick milky juice, as the milkweed.
entomology , secreting a milky fluid, as the joints of certain Coleoptera.
Having a milky look; becoming milky.
Producing milk or a milklike juice or fluid, as the milkweed. See Latex .

lactic.explanation: Of, relating to, or derived from milk.
Of or pertaining to milk; procured from sour milk or whey

a sirupy, colorless fluid, soluble in water, with an intensely sour taste and strong acid reaction. There is one center of optical activity, and this results in the observation of three isomeric modifications all having the formula C3H6O3; one is dextrorotatory (L-lactic acid), the other levorotatory (D-lactic acid), and the third an optically inactive mixture of the first two (DL-lactic acid); chemically it is 2-hydroxypropanoic acid. Sarcolactic acid or paralactic acid occurs chiefly in dead muscle tissue, while ordinary lactic acid (DL-lactic acid) results from fermentation, such as the fermentation of milk by lactic acid bacteria. The two acids are alike in having the same constitution (expressed by the name ethylidene lactic acid ), but the latter is optically inactive, while sarcolactic acid rotates the plane of polarization to the right. The third acid, ethylene lactic acid , accompanies sarcolactic acid in the juice of flesh, and is optically inactive.

an organized ferment ( Bacterium lacticum or Bacterium lactis ), which produces lactic fermentation, decomposing the sugar of milk into carbonic and lactic acids, the latter, of which renders the milk sour, and precipitates the casein, thus giving rise to the so-called spontaneous coagulation of milk.
Of, relating to, or derived from milk
of or relating to or obtained from milk (especially sour milk or whey)

lactide.explanation: A volatile substance, C 6 H 8 O 4 , one of the anhydrids of lactic acid produced by the dry distillation of that acid. See lactone .
A white, crystalline substance, obtained from lactic acid by distillation, and regarded as an anhydride; also, by extension, any similar substance.
Any of a class of heterocyclic compounds , formally acid anhydrides , formed by heating α- lactones

lactiferous.explanation: Bearing or containing milk or a milky fluid.
Bearing or containing milk or a milky fluid.

lactification.explanation: The production of lactic acid in milk and other fluids by the lactic-acid bacteria.

lactifuge.explanation: A medicine which checks or diminishes the secretion of milk.
A medicine to check the secretion of milk, or to dispel a supposed accumulation of milk in any part of the body.
A medicine to check the secretion of milk , or to dispel a supposed accumulation of milk in any part of the body.
any agent that reduces milk secretion (as given to a woman who is not breast feeding)

lactim.explanation: The name of a class of organic compounds containing the group -C(OH):N-. It is a tautomeric and, occasionally, isomeric form of the lactam radical.
One of a series of anhydrides resembling the lactams, but of an imido type. Cf. lactam .
Any of a class of cyclic hydroxy - imides ( enols ) that are tautomeric with the lactams .

lactimide.explanation: A colorless neutral compound, , prepared by heating a -aminopropionic acid in a current of hydrochloric-acid gas. It crystallizes in needles or plates, melts at 275° C, and sublimes.
A white, crystalline substance obtained as an anhydride of alanine, and regarded as an imido derivative of lactic acid.
A white crystalline substance obtained as an anhydride of alanine , and regarded as an imido derivative of lactic acid .

lactobacillus.explanation: Any of various rod-shaped, oxygen-tolerant anaerobic bacteria of the genus Lactobacillus that ferment sugars to lactic acid and are used in the production of certain foods such as yogurt, sauerkraut, and pickles.
Any of many rod-shaped , nonmotile , aerobic bacteria , of the genus Lactobacillus , that ferment sugars to form lactic acid
a Gram-positive rod-shaped bacterium that produces lactic acid (especially in milk)

lactobutyrometer.explanation: A kind of lactometer for ascertaining the quantity of buttery matter any particular milk contains.
An instrument for determining the amount of butter fat contained in a given sample of milk.
An instrument for determining the amount of butterfat in milk .

lactocele.explanation: In pathology , a morbid collection of milk-like fluid. Also called galactocele .

lactochrome.explanation: In chem. , a name given by Blyth to a nitrogenous substance of an orange color, obtained in very small quantity from the whey of milk after casein and albumin had been removed, and believed by him to be the source of the yellow color of milk and of butter.

lactodensimeter.explanation: A kind of lactometer furnished with scales intended to show what proportion of the cream, if any, has been removed from a sample of milk by skimming.
A form of hydrometer, specially graduated, for finding the density of milk, and thus discovering whether it has been mixed with water or some of the cream has been removed.
A form of hydrometer for finding the density of milk , and thus discovering whether it has been mixed with water or had some of the cream removed.

lactoflavin.explanation: a B vitamin that prevents skin lesions and weight loss

lactogen.explanation: any agent that enhances milk production

lactol.explanation: A color, less, tasteless compound, the lactic-acid ester of β-naphthol: an intestinal antiseptic.
any cyclic hemiacetal formed by the intramolecular addition of a hydroxy group to a carbonyl group

lactometer.explanation: A device used to measure the specific gravity, and therefore the richness, of milk.
An instrument for gaging the purity or richness of samples of milk.
An instrument for estimating the purity or richness of milk, as a measuring glass, a specific gravity bulb, or other apparatus.
A device that estimates the cream content of milk by measuring its specific gravity

lactone.explanation: A cyclic ester, or a compound containing a cyclic ester, formed by the intramolecular condensation of a hydroxy carboxylic acid.
A colorless volatile liquid possessing an aromatic smell, produced, along with lactide, by the dry distillation of lactic acid.

One of a series of organic compounds, being cyclic esters which may be regarded as anhydrides of certain hydroxy acids. In general, they are colorless liquids, having a weak aromatic odor. They are so called because the typical lactone is derived from lactic acid.
A cyclic intramolecular ester derived from a hydroxy acid .

lactonic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by the oxidation of milk sugar ( lactose ).
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, a lactone.

lactonization.explanation: Reaction with, or conversion into a lactone

lactonized.category: organic chemistry, of a hydroxy carboxylic acid
lactonized.explanation: Converted into a lactone by internal condensation

lactophosphate.explanation: A phosphate combined with lactic acid.

lactoproteid.explanation: Any one of the albumins which occur in milk.

lactoprotein.explanation: A protein normally present in milk.
A peculiar albuminous body considered a normal constituent of milk.
Any protein (such as casein ) present in milk

lactoscope.explanation: An instrument for testing the quality and richness of samples of milk, by their comparative opacity, constructed and operated upon the principle that the richer the milk is in fatty and caseous substances the greater will be its resistance to the passage of light through a stratum of any given thickness.
An instrument for estimating the amount of cream contained in milk by ascertaining its relative opacity.
An instrument for estimating the amount of cream in milk , based on its relative opacity .

lactose.explanation: A white crystalline disaccharide, C 12 H 22 O 11 , found in milk, that may be hydrolyzed to yield glucose and galactose. Refined lactose obtained from whey is used in infant foods, bakery products, confections, and pharmaceuticals as a diluent and excipient.
Sugar of milk, C 12 H 22 O 11 , obtained by evaporating whey, filtering through animal charcoal, and crystallizing.

The main sugar present in milk, called also sugar of milk or milk sugar . When isolated pure it is obtained crystalline; it is separable from the whey by evaporation and crystallization. It is a disaccharide with the formula C12H22O11, being chemically 4-(β-D-galactosido)-D-glucose. It has a slightly sweet taste, is dextrorotary, and is much less soluble in water than either cane sugar or glucose. Formerly called lactin . When hydrolyzed it yields glucose and galactose. In cells it may be hydrolyzed by the enzyme β-galactosidase.
The disaccharide sugar of milk and dairy products, C12H22O11, (a product of glucose and galactose ) used as a food and in medicinal compounds.
a sugar comprising one glucose molecule linked to a galactose molecule; occurs only in milk

lactosuria.explanation: The presence of lactose in the urine.
presence of lactose in the urine; can occur during pregnancy or lactation

lactothermometer.explanation: A small thermometer inclosed in a glass tube and used in testing milk.

lactotoxin.explanation: A ptomaïne found in milk: supposedly the same as the tyrotoxicon of cheese.

lactovegetarian.explanation: Variant of vegetarian : a person whose diet excludes animal flesh and eggs , but includes dairy products.
Excluding animal flesh and eggs , but including dairy products.

lactucarium.explanation: A drug consisting of the concreted milky juice of several species of Lactuca.
The inspissated juice of the common lettuce, sometimes used as a substitute for opium.
The thickened juice of certain varieties of lettuce , used as a drug .

lactucerin.explanation: The dried milky juice of the European lettuce, Lactuca virosa. It consists of a mixture of α- and β-lactucerol acetates and has the formula C 20 H 32 O 2 .
A colorless dextrorotatory compound, C 28 H 44 O 2 (?), contained in the juice of the European lettuce. It crystallizes in microscopic needles and melts at 210° C. Also called lactucon .

lactucin.explanation: A colorless compound, C 40 H 48 O 13 or C 22 H 26 O 7 or C 22 H 28 O 8 , obtained from the dried juice of the common lettuce, Lactuca sativa and L. sagittata. It crystallizes in pearly scales.
A white, crystalline substance, having a bitter taste and a neutral reaction, and forming one of the essential ingredients of lactucarium.
One of the essential ingredients of lactucarium .

lactucol.explanation: A colorless dextrorotatory compound, C 13 H 20 O, prepared by fusing lactucerin with potassium hydroxid. It crystallizes in needles melting at 162° C.

lactyl.explanation: A lactic-acid radical: as, lactyl chlorid, CH 3 .CHCl.CO.Cl.
An organic residue or radical (CH3.CHOH.CO-) derived from lactic acid.
An organic residue or radical derived from lactic acid .

lacuna.explanation: An empty space or a missing part; a gap.
A cavity, space, or depression, especially in a bone, containing cartilage or bone cells.
A gap; a hiatus; especially, a vacancy caused by the omission, loss, or obliteration of something necessary to continuity or completeness.
In conchology , the typical genus of Lacunidæ.
A small opening; a small pit or depression; a small blank space; a gap or vacancy; a hiatus.

A small opening; a small depression or cavity; a space, as a vacant space between the cells of plants, or one of the spaces left among the tissues of the lower animals, which serve in place of vessels for the circulation of the body fluids, or the cavity or sac, usually of very small size, in a mucous membrane.
A small opening ; a small pit or depression ; a small blank space; a gap or vacancy ; a hiatus .
An absent part, especially in a book or other piece of writing, often referring to an ancient manuscript or similar.
A space visible between cells , allowing free passage of light .
A language gap , which occurs when there is no direct translation in the target language for a lexical term found in the source language
a blank gap or missing part
an ornamental sunken panel in a ceiling or dome

lacunal.explanation: of or pertaining to a lacuna , like a lacuna

lacunar.explanation: A ceiling constructed with recessed panels.
A recessed panel in such a ceiling.

One of the coffers or sunk compartments in ceilings or soffits formed of beams crossing one another, or resembling in structural form or for purposes of decoration such a construction of beams, as the stone ceilings of the Grecian Doric, those (generally formed of wood and plaster, and profusely decorated with gilding and ornament) common in Renaissance buildings, etc.
Hence A ceiling or soffit having lacunars.
The ceiling or under surface of any part, especially when it consists of compartments, sunk or hollowed without spaces or bands between the panels.
One of the sunken panels in such a ceiling.
Of or pertaining to a lacuna
A coffer ; a ceiling constructed of coffers

lacunary.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or having characteristics of a lacuna

lacune.explanation: A lacuna; a small empty space; a gap; a hiatus; a defect.

lacunose.explanation: botany and entomology , having scattered, irregular, broadish, but shallow excavations, as a surface.
Furrowed or pitted; having shallow cavities or lacunæ.

lacustral.explanation: Found in, or pertaining to, lakes or ponds, or growing in them.
the deposits which have been accumulated in fresh-water areas.

lacustrian.explanation: A lake-dweller; one whose habitation is built upon a lake.

lacustrine.explanation: Living or growing in or along the edges of lakes.
Relating to a system of inland deep-water and wetland habitats associated with lakes and reservoirs and characterized by the absence of trees, shrubs, or emergent vegetation.
botany , growing in lakes or ponds. Also lacustral and lacustrian.
of or relating to or living near lakes

lacy.explanation: Of, relating to, or resembling lace.
Made of lace or decorated with it.

lad.explanation: A man of any age; a fellow.
An obsolete preterit and past participle of lead .
A boy; a youth; a stripling: often used familiarly or affectionately in speaking of or to a man of any age.
A male sweetheart: correlative to lass.
A thong of leather; a shoe-latchet.
A boy; a youth; a stripling.
A companion; a comrade; a mate.
A jack the lad ; a boyo .
A familiar term of address for a young man .
A groom who works with horses (also called stable-lad).
a male child (a familiar term of address to a boy)

ladanum.explanation: A resinous juice that exudes from the Cistus ladaniferus , a shrub which grows in Spain and Portugal, and from C. Creticus and C. salvifolius , which grow in Crete, Syria, etc.
A gum resin gathered from certain Oriental species of Cistus. It has a pungent odor and is chiefly used in making plasters, and for fumigation.
a soft blackish-brown resinous exudate from various rockroses used in perfumes especially as a fixative

ladder.explanation: An often portable structure consisting of two long sides crossed by parallel rungs, used to climb up and down.
Something that resembles this device, especially a run in a stocking.
A means of moving higher or lower, as in a hierarchy.
A series of ranked stages or levels.
A fish ladder.
An athletic workout in which one does progressively longer intervals followed by progressively shorter intervals.
One of the intervals in such a workout.
To run, as a stocking does.
A series of buckets for dredging and filling which are carried up and down an incline; a bucket-conveyer.
In railroads , a track which connects by switches the ends of a series of parallel tracks and is used in sorting cars in a drill-yard. See drill-yard .

A frame of wood, metal, or rope, usually portable, and consisting essentially of two side-pieces connected at suitable distances by cross-pieces, generally in the form of rounds or rungs, forming steps by which, when the frame is properly set, a person may ascend a height.
Figuratively, any means of ascending; a means of rising to eminence.
In logic , a figure illustrating the theory of the old logic concerning the relations of genera, differences, and species
Nautical See Jacob's-ladder , 1.
A frame usually portable, of wood, metal, or rope, for ascent and descent, consisting of two side pieces to which are fastened cross strips or rounds forming steps.
That which resembles a ladder in form or use
See under Fish .
an American leaf beetle ( Chrysomela scalaris ). The elytra are silvery white, striped and spotted with green; the under wings are rose-colored. It feeds upon the linden tree.
an iron rail at the side of a vertical fixed ladder, to grasp with the hand in climbing.
a spiral marine shell of the genus Scalaria. See Scalaria .
A frame usually portable, of wood, metal, or rope, for ascent and descent, consisting of two side pieces to which are fastened cross strips or rounds forming steps.
That which resembles a ladder in form or use; hence, that by means of which one attains to eminence, e.g. the corporate ladder.
Length of unravelled fabric in a knitted garment, especially in nylon stockings .
In the game of go , a sequence of moves following a zigzag pattern and ultimately leading to the capture of the attacked stones .
To ascend a building or wall using a ladder.
To develop a ladder as a result of a broken thread.
come unraveled or undone as if by snagging
ascending stages by which somebody or something can progress
steps consisting of two parallel members connected by rungs; for climbing up or down
a row of unravelled stitches

laddered.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ladder .

laddering.explanation: A narrow insertion of lace or muslin used in dressmaking, consisting of alternate bars and open spaces, somewhat resembling a ladder. Ribbons may be run in and out through these for ornament. Also called beading .

ladderlike.explanation: Resembling a ladder (device used for climbing).

ladderman.explanation: In a fire-brigade, a member of a hook-and-ladder company.

ladderway.explanation: A space or opening for ascending and descending by a ladder; specifically, in mining , a shaft arranged with a system of ladders by winch the miners have access to the part of the mine in which their work is carried on.

laddie.explanation: A boy or young man; a lad.
a male child (a familiar term of address to a boy)

laddish.explanation: Like a stereotypical jack the lad : boorish , reckless , inclined to binge drinking , etc.

lade.explanation: To load with or as if with cargo.
To place (something) as a load for or as if for shipment.
To burden or oppress; weigh down.
To take up or remove (water) with a ladle or dipper.
To take on cargo.
To ladle a liquid.
A load; specifically, a bag of meal.
lade a ship with cotton; to lade a horse with corn.
lade water out of a tub or into a cistern.
A way; course. See lode .
A watercourse; a channel for water; a ditch or drain; in Scotland, specifically, a mill-race, especially a headrace.
The mouth of a river.
To draw water.
To admit water by leakage, as a ship, etc.
The mouth of a river.
A passage for water; a ditch or drain.
To load; to put a burden or freight on or in; -- generally followed by that which receives the load, as the direct object.
To throw in or out, with a ladle or dipper; to dip.
To transfer (the molten glass) from the pot to the forming table.
To fill or load (related to cargo or a shipment).
To weigh down , oppress , or burden .
To use a ladle or dipper to remove something (generally water).
The mouth of a river .
A passage for water ; a ditch or drain .
Water pumped into and out of mills, especially woolen mills.
remove with or as if with a ladle
fill or place a load on

laded.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lade .

lademan.explanation: A person who has charge of a pack-horse.
A servant employed by a miller to return to the owners their meal when ground.
One who leads a pack horse; a miller's servant.
One who leads a packhorse ; a miller 's servant .

laden.explanation: Weighed down with a load; heavy.
Weighed down with a load, burdened .
: In the form of an adsorbate or adduct .
fill or place a load on
remove with or as if with a ladle

lades.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of lade .

ladies.explanation: A toilet for women or girls .

ladified.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ladify .

ladify.explanation: To make a lady of; to make ladylike.
To make a lady of; to make ladylike .

lading.explanation: That which constitutes a load or cargo; freight; burden: as, the lading of a ship.
In glass-making , the transfer of the glass into the cuvettes.
That which lades or constitutes a load or cargo; freight; burden.
goods carried by a large vehicle

ladino.explanation: Trifolium repens, a larger variety of white clover .
A mixed-race descendant of whites and Native Americans ; a mestizo .

ladle.explanation: A long-handled spoon with a deep bowl for serving liquids.
To lift out or serve with a long-handled spoon.
A burghal duty charged on grain, meal, and flour brought to market for sale; the proceeds obtained from that duty: from the dish or vessel used to measure the grain or meal.
A long-handled dish-shaped utensil for dipping or conveying liquids.
A similarly shaped instrument for drawing a charge from a cannon.
The float-board of a mill-wheel; a ladle-board.
In glass manufacturing , same as cuvette , 2.
A cuplike spoon, often of large size, with a long handle, used in lading or dipping.
A vessel to carry liquid metal from the furnace to the mold.
The float of a mill wheel; -- called also ladle board .
An instrument for drawing the charge of a cannon.
A ring, with a handle or handles fitted to it, for carrying shot.
the wood of a South African tree ( Cassine Colpoon ), used for carving.
To take up and convey in a ladle; to dip with, or as with, a ladle
A deep-bowled spoon with a long, usually curved, handle .
A container used in a foundry to transport and pour out molten metal
to serve something with a ladle
put (a liquid) into a container by means of a ladle
remove with or as if with a ladle
a spoon-shaped vessel with a long handle; frequently used to transfer liquids from one container to another

ladled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ladle .

ladleful.explanation: A quantity sufficient to fill a ladle.
A sufficient quantity to fill a ladle

ladler.explanation: someone who transports molten metal in a ladle .

ladles.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of ladle .

ladlewood.explanation: The wood of the tree Hartogia Capensis.

ladrone.explanation: In the Philippine Islands, among American soldiers, a hostile Filipino soldier or ‘insurgent.’
A robber; a pirate; hence, loosely, a rogue or rascal.
A robber ; a pirate ; a rogue or rascal .

ladronism.explanation: The character or conduct of a ladrone or robber. See extract under ladrone , 2.

lads.explanation: A group of friends , regardless of gender. Often the lads.

lady.explanation: A woman of high social standing or refinement, especially when viewed as dignified or well-mannered.
A woman who is the head of a household.
A woman, especially when spoken of or to in a polite way.
Used as a form of address for a woman, often with sarcasm or irritation.
A woman who is the object of romantic or chivalrous love.
A wife or girlfriend.
A lady in waiting.
A general feminine title of nobility and other rank, specifically as the title for the wife or widow of a knight or baronet.
Used as a form of address for a woman of high rank, especially for a marchioness, countess, viscountess, baroness, or baronetess.
The Virgin Mary. Usually used with Our.
In astrology , a term designating the planet Venus when in the circumstances under which, if a masculine planet, she would be termed lord : as, lady of the ascendant.
A woman who has authority over a manor or family; the mistress of a household: the feminine correlative to lord.

Specifically, in Great Britain, the proper title of any woman whose husband is higher in rank than baronet or knight, or who is the daughter of a nobleman not lower than an earl, though the title is given by courtesy also to the wives of baronets and knights; also, the feminine title correlative originally to Lord , and now also to Sir.
In the days of chivalry, the woman chosen by a knight or squire as the object of his especial service, his feats of arms being done in her honor, and his success ascribed to her influence.
A woman of good family and of established social position, or one accepted as such: a restricted sense correlative to gentleman in like use.

A woman of good breeding, education, and refinement of mind and manner: a general sense correlative to gentleman in like use: in common speech used indiscriminately as a synonym for woman (a use generally vulgar, and to be avoided except in address). See gentleman , 4.
A wife; a man's spouse: used in this sense always with direct reference to the husband: as, John Smith and lady.
A sweetheart.
A slate measuring about 16 inches long by 10 broad.
The calcareous apparatus in the cardiac part of the stomach of the lobster, the function of which is the trituration of the food.
Belonging or becoming to a lady; ladylike.
A woman who looks after the domestic affairs of a family; a mistress; the female head of a household.
A woman having proprietary rights or authority; mistress; -- a feminine correlative of lord .
A woman to whom the particular homage of a knight was paid; a woman to whom one is devoted or bound; a sweetheart.

A woman of social distinction or position. In England, a title prefixed to the name of any woman whose husband is not of lower rank than a baron, or whose father was a nobleman not lower than an earl. The wife of a baronet or knight has the title of Lady by courtesy, but not by right.
A woman of refined or gentle manners; a well-bred woman; -- the feminine correlative of gentleman .
A wife; -- not now in approved usage.
Any woman; ; also used in combination.
The triturating apparatus in the stomach of a lobster; -- so called from a fancied resemblance to a seated female figure. It consists of calcareous plates.
a man who affects the society of ladies.
an altar in a lady chapel.
a chapel dedicated to the Virgin Mary.
the court of a lady of the manor.
a handsomely spotted swimming crab ( Platyonichus ocellatus ) very common on the sandy shores of the Atlantic coast of the United States.
See Female fern, under Female , and Illust. of Fern .
a lady of the queen's household, appointed to wait upon or attend the queen.
a Mass said in honor of the Virgin Mary.
a lady having jurisdiction of a manor; also, the wife of a manor lord.
a maidservant who dresses and waits upon a lady.
the Virgin Mary.
The mistress of a household .
A woman of breeding or higher class , a woman of authority .
The feminine of lord .
A title for someone married to a lord.
A title for somebody married to a gentleman .
A title that can be used instead of the formal terms of marchioness , countess , viscountess or baroness .

ladybird.explanation: A beetle of the family Coccinellidæ , order Coleoptera , so called from its graceful form and delicate coloration.
The pintail duck, Dafila acuta: so called from its graceful form.
A lady-love; a sweetheart: often used as a term of endearment.

Any one of numerous species of small beetles of the genus Coccinella and allied genera (family Coccinellidæ ); -- called also ladybug , ladyclock , lady cow , lady fly , ladybeetle , and lady beetle . Coccinella seplempunctata in one of the common European species. See coccinella .
Any of the Coccinellidae family of beetles , typically having a round shape and red or yellow spotted elytra .
small round bright-colored and spotted beetle that usually feeds on aphids and other insect pests

ladybug.explanation: Any of numerous small, rounded, usually colorful beetles of the family Coccinellidae, often reddish with black spots and feeding primarily on other insects, including pests such as scale insects and aphids.
A ladybird: the more common name in the United States and in some parts of England.
any beetle of the Coccinellidae family of beetles , typically having a round shape and a colorful shell.
small round bright-colored and spotted beetle that usually feeds on aphids and other insect pests

ladyfinger.explanation: A small sponge cake , shaped approximately like a finger.

ladyfish.explanation: Any of several marine game fishes of the family Elopidae, especially Elops saurus of warm coastal waters of the western Atlantic Ocean, having an elongated silvery body.
A fish, Albula vulpes , of the family Albulidæ , of a brilliant silvery color, abundant in tropical seas, and quite gamy, but of little value as food.

A labroid fish, Harpe rufa , with 12 dorsal spines, continuous lateral line, scaly cheeks and opercles, base of dorsal fin scaly, and posterior canines. It is a common West Indian fish, occurring also along the Florida coast, and of beautiful color. More fully called Spanish ladyfish ; also doncella .
The skipper or saury, Scomberesox saurus.
A trachinoid fish, Sillago domina , found in the Bay of Bengal and generally throughout the East Indian archipelago.
A large, handsome oceanic fish ( Albula vulpes ), found both in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans; -- called also bonefish , grubber , French mullet , and macabé .
A labroid fish ( Harpe rufa ) of Florida and the West Indies.
A coastal dwelling fish in the genus Elops, found throughout the tropical and sub-tropical regions.
game fish resembling the tarpon but smaller

ladyfy.explanation: To bestow the title of Lady on a woman

ladyhood.explanation: The condition, character, quality, rank, etc., of a lady.
The state or quality of being a lady; the personality of a lady.
the quality or state of being a lady or ladylike .

ladyism.explanation: The condition and manners of an affected “fine lady.”

ladykin.explanation: A little lady: applied by Elizabethan writers, in the abbreviated form Lakin , to the Virgin Mary.
A little lady; -- applied by the writers of Queen Elizabeth's time, in the abbreviated form Lakin , to the Virgin Mary.

ladykind.explanation: The women of a family or party. Compare womankind .

ladylike.explanation: Characteristic of a well-mannered woman or girl who adheres to traditional norms of propriety and femininity.
Appropriate to such a woman or girl, as in being restrained or delicate.
Like a lady in appearance or manners; well-bred.
Becoming or suitable to a lady.
Of or connected with the appearance or behaviour of a well-mannered woman .
befitting a woman of good breeding

ladylikeness.explanation: The quality or state of being ladylike.

ladyling.explanation: A young, petite , or unimportant lady .

ladylove.explanation: A woman or girl who is someone's sweetheart.
A female sweetheart; a woman who is loved.
Love for a lady; romantic love.
A woman who is loved by someone; an object of desire .
a woman who is a man's sweetheart

ladyship.explanation: Used with Your, Her, or Their as a title and form of address for a woman or women holding the rank of lady.
The condition or rank of a lady.
The rank or position of a lady; -- given as a title (preceded by her or your ).
Term of respect for a woman of the peerage without using her title.
Formal form of address for a lady judge (as opposed to the informal "judge")
a title used to address any peeress except a duchess

laelia.explanation: any of various spectacular plants of the genus Laelia having showy flowers in many colors

laemodipod.explanation: Læmodipoda , or having their characters. Also læmodipodous .
A member of the order Læmodipoda. Also læmodipodan .

laemodipoda.explanation: An order of edriophthalmous crustaceans, related to the amphipods, by some made a group of Amphipoda.
A division of amphipod Crustacea, in which the abdomen is small or rudimentary and the legs are often reduced to five pairs. The whale louse, or Cyamus, and Caprella are examples.

laemodipodous.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Læmodipoda.

laetrile.explanation: A substance derived from amygdalin, promoted by some individuals as an antineoplastic drug but found by researchers to have no proven benefit in animals or humans.
A drug , derived from the amygdalin of apricot kernels , once thought capable of destroying cancer cells by the release of cyanide but later banned in the United States by the FDA.

laevigate.explanation: Having a smooth surface, as if polished.

laevulose.explanation: a simple sugar found in honey and in many ripe fruits

lafayette.explanation: A market fish , the goody or spot (Liostomus xanthurus), of the southern coast of the United States .

laft.explanation: A Middle English preterit and past participle of leave .

lag.explanation: A barrel stave.
A strip, as of wood, that forms a part of the covering for a cylindrical object.
To furnish or cover with lags.
To fail to keep up a pace; straggle.
To proceed or develop with comparative slowness.
To weaken or slacken; flag.
To determine the order of play by hitting or shooting a ball toward a mark, as in marbles or billiards, with the player whose ball stops closest to the mark going first.
To fail to keep up with (another).
To proceed or develop at a slower pace than (another).
In golf, to hit (a putt) so that it stops a short way from the hole and can then be tapped in.
An interval between one event or phenomenon and another.
A condition of weakness or slackening.
To arrest.
To send to prison.
A convict.
An ex-convict.
One who or that which comes behind; the last comer; one who hangs back.
The lowest class; the rump; the fag-end.
In mech. , the amount of retardation of some movement: as, the lag of the valve of a steam-engine.
In machinery , one of the strips which form the periphery of a wooden drum, the casing of a carding-machine, or the lagging or covering of a steam-boiler or-cylinder.
An old convict.
A term of hard labor or transportation.
In electricity , the displacement of phase of an electric wave back, or behind (in time), to another electric wave: used mainly with regard to alternating-current circuits.
See lagging of the tides , under lagging.

The angle corresponding to the lag of the tides; the hour-angle between the lunar transit and the flood-tide; the shifting of the earth's magnetic system from a symmetrical distribution about the noon meridian into the observed eccentric position.
Coming tardily after or behind; slow; tardy.
Last; long-delayed; -- obsolete, except in the phrase lag end .
Last made; hence, made of refuse; inferior.
One transported for a crime.
To walk or more slowly; to stay or fall behind; to linger or loiter.
To cause to lag; to slacken.
To cover, as the cylinder of a steam engine, with lags. See Lag , n., 4.
One who lags; that which comes in last.
The fag-end; the rump; hence, the lowest class.
The amount of retardation of anything, as of a valve in a steam engine, in opening or closing.
A stave of a cask, drum, etc.
See Graylag .
The failing behind or retardation of one phenomenon with respect to another to which it is closely related.

the interval by which the time of high water falls behind the mean time, in the first and third quarters of the moon; -- opposed to priming of the tide, or the acceleration of the time of high water, in the second and fourth quarters; depending on the relative positions of the sun and moon.
an iron bolt with a square head, a sharp-edged thread, and a sharp point, adapted for screwing into wood; a screw for fastening lags.
To transport for crime.
late
A gap, a delay; an interval created by something not keeping up; a latency .

lagan.explanation: Cargo or equipment thrown into the sea but attached to a float or buoy so that it can be recovered.
Goods or materials found or left on the sea floor.
goods (or wreckage) on the sea bed that is attached to a buoy so that it can be recovered

lagarto.explanation: A common name of two different fishes belonging to the family Synodontidæ , both of the Atlantic.

lagena.explanation: In Roman antiquity , a wine-vase; an amphora.
A vase of bottle-shaped form, generally in unfamiliar wares, as Levantine, Persian, or the like.
The saccular extremity of the cochlea in some of the vertebrates below mammals, as a bird, where ramify the ultimate filaments of the auditory nerve.
In zoology : The typical genus of Lagenidæ. A genus or subgenus of mollusks of the family Fasciolariidæ.
The terminal part of the cochlea in birds and most reptiles; an appendage of the sacculus, corresponding to the cochlea, in fishes and amphibians.
The upper part of the cochlear duct .
A similar structure, shaped like a flask , that is a hearing organ in some vertebrates .

lagenaria.explanation: A genus of plants of the natural order Cucurbitaceæ.

lagend.explanation: goods (or wreckage) on the sea bed that is attached to a buoy so that it can be recovered

lagenian.explanation: Like, or pertaining to, Lagena, a genus of Foraminifera having a straight, chambered shell.

lageniform.explanation: botany and zoology , shaped like a Florence flask; much dilated or subglobose at base, but ending in a slender cylinder or neck.
Shaped like a bottle or flask; flag-shaped.

lager.explanation: A type of beer of German origin that contains a relatively small amount of hops and is aged from six weeks to six months to allow sedimentation.
Same as lager-beer (which see, under beer ).
A type of beer , brewed using a bottom-fermenting yeast .
a camp defended by a circular formation of wagons
a general term for beer made with bottom fermenting yeast (usually by decoction mashing); originally it was brewed in March or April and matured until September

lagering.explanation: The stage in the manufacture of a lager beer when it is stored at a low temperature for maturing and clarification

lagerstroemia.explanation: shrubs or small trees of tropical Asia and Africa usually with showy white, pink, or purplish flowers

lagetta.explanation: A genus of dicotyledonous apetalous trees of the West Indies, belonging to the natural order Thymelæaceæ and tribe Euthymelæeæ.

laggard.explanation: Slow or delayed in action. synonym : slow .
One who lags; a loiterer; a lazy, slack fellow.
One who lags behind and takes more time than is necessary .
someone who takes more time than necessary; someone who lags behind

laggardism.explanation: Sluggishness; the characteristic of hanging back; lagging.

laggardly.explanation: Resembling a laggard ; slow; taking more time than is necessary; lagging behind
In the manner of a laggard .

laggardness.explanation: The quality or state of being a laggard .

lagged.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lag .

laggen.explanation: The angle between the side and the bottom of a wooden dish.

lagger.explanation: A player who lags (has a poor or slow network connection).
A member of support staff responsible for contacting lawyers to check how a case is progressing .
someone who takes more time than necessary; someone who lags behind

lagging.explanation: Insulation used to prevent heat diffusion, as from a steam pipe.
A wooden frame built especially to support the sides of an arch until the keystone is positioned.
The act of walking or moving slowly, or of falling behind.

In architecture , the planking, consisting of narrow strips, extending from one rib of the centering of an arch, vault, or tunnel to another, and affording direct support to the voussoirs until the arch or vault is closed in.
In mining , strips of wood or light timbers laid across the stulls in the drifts to prevent fragments of rock from falling through.
A covering for the face of a pulley, designed to increase its effective diameter or to augment the adhesion of the belt.
Nautical , the part of a barrel-stave beyond the head. Also spelled laggin .
The clothing (esp., an outer, wooden covering), as of a steam cylinder, applied to prevent the radiation of heat; a covering of lags; -- called also deading and cleading .
Lags, collectively; narrow planks extending from one rib to another in the centering of arches.
falling behind, not keeping up the pace
Occurring after; indicating the later phase of
The covering of something with strips of felt , wood etc, either as insulation or for protection
used to wrap around pipes or boilers or laid in attics to prevent loss of heat

laggingly.explanation: So as to lag or fall behind.

lagna.explanation: The point on the ecliptic which is rising at any given moment.

lagnappe.explanation: A trifling article added gratis to a purchase in shops or markets to encourage custom; any complimentary present from a dealer to a customer: as, a turkey sent at Christmas for lagnappe.

lagniappe.explanation: A small gift presented by a storeowner to a customer with the customer's purchase.
An extra or unexpected gift or benefit.
In Louisiana, a trifling present given to customers by tradesmen; a gratuity.
An extra or unexpected gift or benefit , such as that given to a customer when they purchase something else.
a small gift (especially one given by a merchant to a customer who makes a purchase)

lagomorph.explanation: Any of various plant-eating mammals of the order Lagomorpha, having fully furred feet and two pairs of upper incisors and including the rabbits, hares, and pikas.
ny member of the Lagomorpha , a superfamily of rodents containing the hares and pikas.
A member of the mammalian taxonomic order , Lagomorpha , which includes hares , rabbits , and pikas .
relative large gnawing animals; distinguished from rodents by having two pairs of upper incisors specialized for gnawing

lagomorphic.explanation: Lagomorpha , as a hare or pika.
Characteristic of the taxonomic order Lagomorpha

lagonite.explanation: A hydrous ferric borate occurring as an earthy incrustation, of a yellow color, in the Tuscan lagoons.

lagoon.explanation: A shallow body of water, especially one separated from a sea by sandbars or coral reefs.
A shallow artificial pond used for treating or storing liquid waste material or for collecting flood waters.

An area of shallow water, or even of marshy land, bordering on the sea, and usually separated from the region of deeper water outside by a belt of sand or of sand-dunes, more or less changeable in position.
With reference to Tuscany and some other parts of Italy, the basin of a hot spring, especially one from which borax is obtained: from the Italian use of lagone in this sense.
In occasional use, the area of still water inclosed within an atoll, which is often called a lagoon island. See atoll .
A shallow sound, channel, pond, or lake, especially one into which the sea flows.
A lake in a coral island, often occupying a large portion of its area, and usually communicating with the sea. See Atoll .
a coral island consisting of a narrow reef encircling a lagoon.
A shallow body of water separated from deeper sea by a bar .
a body of water cut off from a larger body by a reef of sand or coral

lagoonal.explanation: Of or pertaining to a lagoon , especially one behind a coral reef

lagophthalmos.explanation: abnormal condition in which an eye cannot close completely

lagopodous.explanation: zoology , hare-footed; having the feet densely furry or feathery, as a lemming or a ptarmigan. See first cut under grouse .

lagopous.explanation: botany , soft and hairy like a hare's foot.
Having a dense covering of long hair, like the foot of a hare.

lagopus.explanation: A genus of grouse, of the family Tetraonidæ , having the feet and nasal fossæ densely feathered; the ptarmigans.
A former generic name of the plant hare's-foot, Ochroma Lagopus.
The ptarmigan (which bird was so called because its feet resemble those of a hare).

lagthing.explanation: The upper house of the Norwegian Storthing or parliament, consisting of one fourth of the members of the latter elected by the whole body. See Storthing .

laguna.explanation: a body of water cut off from a larger body by a reef of sand or coral

laguncularia.explanation: A genus of dicotyledonous polypetalous plants of the natural order Combretaceæ and suborder Combreteæ , having the calyx-tube turbinate and not produced beyond the ovary, 10 included stamens, opposite leaves, and spiked flowers.

lagune.explanation: a body of water cut off from a larger body by a reef of sand or coral

lah.explanation: , Placed at the end of a sentence either for emphasis or reassurance.
the syllable naming the sixth (submediant) note of a major or minor scale in solmization

lahar.explanation: A mass of volcanic fragments, often mixed with water, moving rapidly down the side of a volcano.
The deposit produced by a lahar.
an avalanche of volcanic water and mud down the slopes of a volcano

lai.explanation: A mostly North European form of medieval song, with stanzas that do not repeat.

laic.explanation: Of or relating to the laity; secular.
A layman, in distinction from a clergyman.
Of or pertaining to a layman or the laity.
A layperson , as opposed to a member of the clergy .
Lay , relating to laypersons , as opposed to clerical .
characteristic of those who are not members of the clergy

laical.explanation: Of or pertaining to a layman or laity .

laicality.explanation: The condition or quality of being laic; the state of a layman.
The state or quality of being laic; the state or condition of a layman.
The quality of being laic ; the condition of a layman .

laically.explanation: As a layman; after the manner of a layman.

laicised.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of laicise .

laicises.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of laicise .

laicization.explanation: The act of rendering lay, or of depriving of a clerical character; removal from clerical rank, influence, or control.

laicize.explanation: To free from ecclesiastical control; give over to laypeople.
To change to lay status; secularize.
To convert from church controlled to independent of the church; to secularize .
To reduce from clergy to layman .

laicized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of laicize .

laicizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of laicize .

laid.explanation: embroidery , stitched upon a ground. Gold and silver thread, and silk cords, are frequently treated in this way.
paper marked with parallel lines or water marks, as if ribbed, from parallel wires in the mold. It is called blue laid , cream laid , etc., according to its color.
Simple past tense and past participle of lay .
Marked with parallel lines , as if ribbed , from wires in the mould.
set down according to a plan:

laik.explanation: To play (in the sense opposed to work).

lain.explanation: A layer. Harrison , Descrip. of England, p. 187.
Plow-land lying at the foot of the downs.
Past participle of lie (oriented in a horizontal position, situated).

laine.explanation: an area of arable land at the foot of a hill

lair.explanation: The den or dwelling of a wild animal.
A place in which to lie or rest; a bed; a couch: now used only of, or with figurative reference to, the den or resting-place of a wild beast.
A litter, as of rabbits; a stock.
Aportion of a burying-ground affording space sufficient for one or more graves; a burial-plot.
Soil; land; ground: in this sense probably confused with lair , 3.
A place in which to lie or rest; especially, the bed or couch of a wild beast.
A place inhabited by a wild animal , often a cave or a hole in the ground.
A place inhabited by a criminal or criminals, a superhero or a supervillain .

lairage.explanation: Space where cattle may lie down and rest.
A place where sheep or cattle may be rested during transit to a market or abattoir

laird.explanation: The owner of a landed estate.
In Scotland, a landed proprietor; especially, the owner of a hereditary estate; also, rarely, a house-owner; a landlord.
A lord; a landholder, esp. one who holds land directly of the crown.
The owner of a Scottish estate ; a landlord

lairdship.explanation: The condition or quality of a laird.
The state of being a laird; an estate; landed property.
the state or condition of being a laird

laired.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lair .; mired.

lairy.explanation: Touchy , aggressive or confrontational , usually while drunk .

laisse.explanation: A section of verse concerning a single theme ; tirade .

lait.explanation: Lightning ; flash of lightning; a flash.

laitance.explanation: The milky washings from the surface of concrete which has recently been laid under water.

A weak layer of cement and aggregate fines on a concrete surface that is usually caused by an overwet mixture , overworking the mixture, improper or excessive finishing or combination thereof. Also, could be caused when a slurry mix is used on a deep foundation, where the slurry mix is not completeley removed before placing concrete on top.

laity.explanation: All those persons who are not members of a given profession or other specialized field.
The state of being a layman, or of not being in orders.
The people, as distinguished from the clergy; the body of the people not in orders; laymen collectively.

The people outside of a particular profession, as distinguished from those belonging to it; persons unskilled in a particular art or science, as distinguished from those who are professionally conversant with it.
The people, as distinguished from the clergy; the body of the people not in orders.
Those who are not of a certain profession, as law or medicine, in distinction from those belonging to it.
people of a church who are not ordained clergy or clerics .
the unlearned, untrained or ignorant as in “The Layman’s Guide to Basket Weaving”
in Christianity, members of a religious community that do not have the priestly responsibilities of ordained clergy

lake.explanation: A pigment consisting of organic coloring matter with an inorganic, usually metallic base or carrier, used in dyes, inks, and paints.
A deep red.
A large inland body of fresh water or salt water.
A scenic pond, as in a park.
A large pool of liquid.
Play; sport; game.
A contest; a fight.
A kind of fine white linen.
leak .
A pigment formed by absorbing animal, vegetable, or coal-tar coloring matter from an aqueous solution by means of metallic bases.
An obsolete or dialectal form of lack .
A body of water surrounded by land, or not forming part of the ocean and occupying a depression below the ordinary drainage-level of the region.
A relatively small pond partly or wholly artificial, as an ornament of a park or of public or private grounds.
A stream; rivulet.
A pit; den.
laky .
A pigment formed by combining some coloring matter, usually by precipitation, with a metallic oxide or earth, esp. with aluminium hydrate
A kind of fine white linen, formerly in use.
To play; to sport.
A large body of water contained in a depression of the earth's surface, and supplied from the drainage of a more or less extended area.

people of a prehistoric race, or races, which inhabited different parts of Europe. Their dwellings were built on piles in lakes, a short distance from the shore. Their relics are common in the lakes of Switzerland.

dwellings built over a lake, sometimes on piles, and sometimes on rude foundations kept in place by piles; specifically, such dwellings of prehistoric times. Lake dwellings are still used by many savage tribes. Called also lacustrine dwellings . See Crannog .
any one of numerous species of dipterous flies of the genus Chironomus. In form they resemble mosquitoes, but they do not bite. The larvæ live in lakes.
the cisco ( Coregonus Artedii ).

a collective name originally applied in contempt, but now in honor, to Southey, Coleridge, and Wordsworth, who lived in the lake country of Cumberland, England, Lamb and a few others were classed with these by hostile critics. Called also lakers and lakists .
a sturgeon ( Acipenser rubicundus ), of moderate size, found in the Great Lakes and the Mississippi River. It is used as food.

Synonyms Lamina, lamella. In zoölogy and anatomy these words are usually absolutely synonymous, used interchangeably and without distinction. If there be a possible distinction, it is that lamella may oftener apply to something smaller or thinner than a lamina : for instance, the cover of a book is a lamina , containing leaves or lamellæ. Haeckel draws and maintains this distinction in embryology.
