lava.explanation: Molten rock that reaches the earth's surface through a volcano or fissure.
The rock formed by the cooling and solidifying of molten rock.
Molten rock which issues from a volcano during an eruption; the same when cooled and hardened.

The melted rock ejected by a volcano from its top or fissured sides. It flows out in streams sometimes miles in length. It also issues from fissures in the earth's surface, and forms beds covering many square miles, as in the Northwestern United States.
a hard and coarse basaltic millstone from the neighborhood of the Rhine.

A washbowl that is attached to a wall and filled from a water tank fastened above.
The psalm in the mass service which the priest recites at the washing of his hands.

Eccles. , in the Roman Catholic Church, and in many Anglican churches, the ritual act of washing the celebrant's hands after the offertory and before entering upon the more solemn part of the eucharistic service: so called from the priest's reciting at the time the last part of the 26th psalm, beginning with the sixth verse, “ I will wash my hands in innocency,” in Latin, “ Lavabo manus meas in innocentia.” In the Greek Church this takes place in the prothesis, before vesting.

In many monasteries of the middle ages, a large stone basin from which the water issued by a number of small orifices around the edge, for the convenient performance of ablutions before religious exercises or meals.

a pale purple colour , like that of the lavender flower.

and Lawful, Legal, Legitimate, Licit , legalized, authorized, constitutional, just. Between lawful and legal there is really the same difference in breadth that there is between law and legislation or statute. (See law .) Legal is exact, meaning conformed to the law of the land, and having little figurative use: as, legal interest; a legal act. Lawful means not opposed to law, primarily to the law of the land, but with a good deal of freedom in figurative extension: it is unlike law , however, in always seeming figurative when carried beyond its primary meaning. Legitimate has as one of its primary meanings the idea of being born under law: as, a legitimate child; its other meanings are kindred. A legitimate inference is one that is drawn in conformity witll the laws of truth or thought. That which is legitimate is generally something made or done in conformity to law, principle, justice, fairness, or propriety. Licit is rarely used except in the phrase licit or illicit ; these words apply to that which is lawful or unlawful, or perhaps only legal or illegal, in trade, relations, or especially intercourse, illicit expressing much more opprobrium than unlawful or illegal. See criminal .
Conformable to law; allowed by law; legitimate; competent.

and Learned, Scholarly , erudite, deep read. These words agree in representing the possession of a knowledge obtained by careful and protracted study, especially in books. They differ in that learned expresses depth and fullness in the knowledge, while scholarly expresses accuracy: as, a learned and scholarly treatise upon the use of the dative case. leave , permit, allow, is generally confused with leave , permit to remain, quit, etc., from which, however, it differs in construction. Leave is now generally followed by an indirect object of the person, and an infinitive with to: as, I leave you to decide. Liberty granted to do something, or for some specific action or course of conduct; permission; allowance; license.
Specifically Liberty to depart; permission to be absent: as, to take leave. See below.
Originally, to receive formal permission, as from a superior, to depart; now, to part with some expression of farewell; bid farewell or adieu.

Synonyms Leave, Liberty, License. These words imply that the permission granted may be used or not. Leave is the lightest, is generally personal, and is used on familiar occasions. Liberty is more often connected with more important matters; it indicates full freedom, and perhaps that obstacles are completely cleared from the path. License , primarily the state of being permitted by law, may retain this meaning (as, license to sell iutoxicating drinks), or it may go so far as to mean that unlawful or undue advantage is taken of legal permission or social for bearance: as, liberty easily degenerates into license.

legger.explanation: A man employed by the owners of a canal to push boats through narrow canal tunnels. The legger would lie on his back on a piece of wood on the boat with his feet reaching to the tunnel wall, and walk it along. This could be done by the boat's crew, but the canals employed men specifically for the task because they could do it faster and prevent a tunnel becoming a bottleneck for traffic.

leniency.explanation: The condition or quality of being lenient. synonym : mercy .
The quality of being lenient; mildness; gentleness; lenity.

Synonyms Leniency, Lenity, Clemency, Mercy ; humanity, tenderness, forbearance. Clemency is exercised only toward offenders, being especially the attribute of those in exalted places having power to remit or lighten penalty. Leniency , as a word, is much more common and expressive than lenity; leniency or lenity may be practised by any one having authority to lighten or remit penalty or to excuse from tasks: as, the leniency of a judge, a parent, or a teacher. Mercy has a twofold use, expressing clemency toward offenders or great kindness toward the distressed; in either sense it is a strong word.

A light open cotton fabric used for window curtains.
A type of weave used to make light, open cotton fabric used for window curtains.

lens.explanation: A ground or molded piece of glass, plastic, or other transparent material with opposite surfaces either or both of which are curved, by means of which light rays are refracted so that they converge or diverge to form an image.
A combination of two or more such pieces, sometimes with other optical devices such as prisms, used to form an image for viewing or photographing.
A thin piece of glass or plastic, as on a pair of sunglasses, that transmits light without refraction.
A device or phenomenon (such as a gravitational field) that causes light or other radiation to converge or diverge by an action analogous to that of a lens.

A transparent, biconvex structure in the eye of a vertebrate or cephalopod that is located between the iris and the vitreous humor and focuses light rays entering through the pupil to form an image on the retina.
A similar structure in many invertebrates.
To make a photograph or movie of.
To bend or distort (light, for example) by means of a lens, especially a gravitational field.

A genus of dicotyledonous plants of the family Mimosaceæ. There are about 14 species, of which the best-known is L. phaseoloides , the match-box bean or simitar-pod. See Entada , gogo, sea-bean , 1, and simitar-pod.
In entomology : The crystalline lens or cone.
One of the facets of the compound eye.
In geology , a body of ore having a lenticular shape.
A surface-condenser made of two round, dished plates bolted together, resembling in form a double-convex lens.
A piece of transparent substance bounded by two curved surfaces (usually spherical), or by a curved surface and a plane.

In anatomy , in the eye, a double-convex body placed in the axis of vision behind the iris between the aqueous humor and the vitreous humor, serving to focus rays of light upon the retina; the crystalline lens. See first cut under eye .
Figuratively, photography, from the use of lenses in that art.
A genus of leguminous plants of the tribe Vicieæ.

A piece of glass, or other transparent substance, ground with two opposite regular surfaces, either both curved, or one curved and the other plane, and commonly used, either singly or combined, in optical instruments, for changing the direction of rays of light, and thus magnifying objects, or otherwise modifying vision. In practice, the curved surfaces are usually spherical, though rarely cylindrical, or of some other figure.
a double-convex lens with one radius equal to six times the other.
See Eye .

a compound lens formed by placing around a central convex lens rings of glass so curved as to have the same focus; used, especially in lighthouses, for concentrating light in a particular direction; -- so called from the inventor.

a lens one side of which is plane and the other convex, but made up of a number of plane faces inclined to one another, each of which presents a separate image of the object viewed through it, so that the object is, as it were, multiplied.
See Polyzonal .
An object, usually made of glass, that focuses or defocuses the light that passes through it.
A device which focuses or defocuses electron beams.
A convex shape bounded by two circular arcs, joined at their endpoints, the corresponding concave shape being a lune .
A genus of the legume family; its bean .
The transparent crystalline structure in the eye .
A way of looking, literally or figuratively, at something.
To film , shoot.
To become thinner towards the edges.
biconvex transparent body situated behind the iris in the eye; its role (along with the cornea) is to focuses light on the retina
(metaphor) a channel through which something can be seen or understood
a transparent optical device used to converge or diverge transmitted light and to form images
genus of small erect or climbing herbs with pinnate leaves and small inconspicuous white flowers and small flattened pods: lentils
electronic equipment that uses a magnetic or electric field in order to focus a beam of electrons

lense.explanation: Common misspelling of lens . (presumably a back-formation from the plural lenses )
a transparent optical device used to converge or diverge transmitted light and to form images

lenslike.explanation: Resembling or characteristic of a lens .

lent.explanation: Preterit and past participle of lend .
A suffix in some adjectives of Latin origin, as flatulent , pestilent , pulverulent , turbulent , vinolent , violent , virulent , etc. It is not used in new English formations.

An annual fast of forty days, beginning with Ash Wednesday and continuing till Easter, observed from very early times in the Christian church, in commemoration of Christ's forty days' fast (Mat. iv. 2), and as a season of special penitence and preparation for the Easter feast.
A fast of forty days, beginning with Ash Wednesday and continuing till Easter, observed by some Christian churches as commemorative of the fast of our Savior.
the daffodil; -- so named from its blossoming in spring.
Simple past tense and past participle of lend .
a period of 40 weekdays from Ash Wednesday to Holy Saturday

lentamente.explanation: In a very slow tempo. Used chiefly as a direction.

lentando.explanation: Slowing gradually. Used chiefly as a direction.
music , slackening; retarding: a direction to sing or play with increasing slowness the notes over which it is written.

lententide.explanation: The season of Lenten or Lent.
a period of 40 weekdays from Ash Wednesday to Holy Saturday

lentibulariaceae.explanation: carnivorous aquatic or bog plants: genera Utricularia, Pinguicula, and Genlisea

lentic.explanation: Of or pertaining to, or living in still waters. (as lakes, ponds, or wetlands)
of or relating to or living in still waters (as lakes or ponds)

lenticel.explanation: One of the small, corky, oval or elongated areas on the surface of a plant stem, trunk, or fruit that allow the interchange of gases between the interior tissue and the surrounding air.
In botany , a lens-shaped body of cells formed in the periderm or corky layer of bark, which by its enlargement soon ruptures the epidermis, or the older corky layers where such are present.
In anatomy , one of the small mucous crypts or follicles of the base of the tongue having the shape of a lentil; a lenticular gland.

One of the small, oval, rounded spots upon the stem or branch of a plant, from which the underlying tissues may protrude or roots may issue, either in the air, or more commonly when the stem or branch is covered with water or earth.
A small, lens-shaped gland on the under side of some leaves.

One of the small, oval, rounded spots upon the stem or branch of a plant, from which the underlying tissues may protrude or roots may issue, either in the air, or more commonly when the stem or branch is covered with water or earth.
A small, lens-shaped gland on the under side of some leaves.
one of many raised pores on the stems of woody plants that allow the interchange of gas between the atmosphere and the interior tissue

lenticle.explanation: In geology : A stratum of sedimentary rock. which from its central point of maximum thickness tapers to a thin edge in every direction; a common form of limestone in shales.
A mass of eruptive rock squeezed and sheared into a shape like the typical sedimentary lenticle.

lenticula.explanation: The lenticular nucleus in the brain.
A freckle; an ephelis. Also lenticule .
A kind of eruption upon the skin; lentigo; freckle.
A kind of eruption upon the skin ; lentigo ; freckle .

lenticular.explanation: Of or relating to a lens.
Resembling a lentil in size or form; having the form of a double-convex lens.
Of or pertaining to a lens .
convex on both sides; shaped like a lentil

lenticulare.explanation: A bone of the carpus of some reptiles, as crocodiles.

lenticularis.explanation: meteorology , a term adopted by the International Conference at Innsbruck, September, 1905, for clouds having an ovoid form with sharp edges: as, cumulus lenticularis , cumulo-stratus lenticularis. Such clouds occur especially in connection with sirocco, mistral and foehn winds, and frequently show rainbow colors.
a cloud species which consists of rounded lens shaped of cloud, often forming near mountains. Associated with cirrocumulus , and altocumulus , and sometimes stratocumulus genera.

lenticularly.explanation: In the manner of a lens; with a curve.

lentiform.explanation: Shaped like a lentil or a lens.
lentiform nucleus of the striate body of the brain.
convex on both sides; shaped like a lentil

lentiginose.explanation: botany and zoology , covered with minute dots as if dusted or freckled; speckled.
relating to or covered with or resembling freckles

lentiginous.explanation: Of or pertaining to lentigo; freckly; scurfy; furfuraceous.
Of, pertaining to, resembling or having lentigines
relating to or covered with or resembling freckles

lentigo.explanation: A small, flat, pigmented spot on the skin.
Pl. lentigines (len-tij′ i-nēz). In medicine , a freckle; abstractly, a freckly condition; the presence of freckles.
In zoology , a genus of mollusks.
A freckly eruption on the skin; freckles.
A brown pigmented spot on the skin .
a small brownish spot (of the pigment melanin) on the skin

lentil.explanation: A leguminous plant (Lens culinaris) native to southwest Asia, having flat pods containing lens-shaped, edible seeds.
The round, flattened seed of this plant.
A body or mass having the general form of a double-convex lens; a lenticular body or mass; a lenticle.
The annual leguminous plant Lens esculenta , or its seeds.

In apparatus for rectifying alcohol, one of the lentil-shaped bulbs (of which there are generally two, but may be more) placed in the condenser between the coil and the pipe leading from the column of the still. See still and rectification.
A leguminous plant of the genus Ervum ( Ervum Lens ), of small size, common in the fields in Europe. Also, its seed, which is used for food on the continent.
a small bivalve shell of the genus Ervillia, family Tellinidæ .
Any of several plants of the genus Lens , especially Lens culinaris, from southwest Asia , that have edible, lens-shaped seeds within flattened pods .
The seed of these plants, used as food.
widely cultivated Eurasian annual herb grown for its edible flattened seeds that are cooked like peas and also ground into meal and for its leafy stalks that are used as fodder
the fruit or seed of a lentil plant
round flat seed of the lentil plant used for food

lentilla.explanation: A genus of leguminous plants. It contains about 6 species, one of which is the lentil. See lens , 4, and lentil , 1.

lentisco.explanation: An extract of the leaves of the mastic-tree, Pistacia Lentiscus : said to be used as a substitute or adulterant for sumac.

lentiscus.explanation: A tree; the mastic. See mastic .

lentisk.explanation: The mastic-tree, Pistacia Lentiscus. See mastic-tree and Pistacia.
an evergreen shrub of the Mediterranean region that is cultivated for its resin

lentissimo.explanation: Very slowly. Used chiefly as a direction.

lento.explanation: In a slow tempo. Used chiefly as a direction.
music , at a slow tempo. Also lent .

lentoid.explanation: Having the form of a lens; lens-shaped.
Having the form of a lens ; lens-shaped.

lentor.explanation: Tenacity; viscousness; viscidity, as of fluids.
"...she walked through dilating space with the lentor of one walking under water..." — Nabokov's Lolita, 1955

lenvoy.explanation: A sort of postscript appended to a literary composition. See envoy .
A conclusion; a result. See envoy .

lenzites.explanation: A genus of fungi of the order Agaricini.

leon.explanation: A Middle English form of lion .
a historical area and former kingdom in northwestern Spain
a city in northwestern Spain at the foot of the Cantabrian Mountains

leonardesque.explanation: art , in the manner of Leonardo or Lionardo da Vinci, an illustrious Florentine artist, engineer, and man of letters (1452–1519).
A disciple or an imitator of Leonardo da Vinci; sometimes, a picture of the school of Leonardo. Also Lionardesque .
in the manner of Leonardo da Vinci

leoncito.explanation: The lion-monkey of Humboldt, a kind of tamarin or marmoset, Midas leoninus.

leone.explanation: A unit of currency of Sierra Leone , divided into 100 cents .

leonese.explanation: Of or pertaining to Leon, in Spain.

leonhardite.explanation: A mineral closely related to laumontite, and probably a variety of it, differing only in having lost part of its water.
a saline evaporite , consisting of a calcium aluminosilicate

leonine.explanation: Of, relating to, or characteristic of a lion.
Resembling or suggestive of a lion, as in being powerful or dignified.

prosody , consisting of metrical Latin hexameters or elegiacs (alternate hexameters and pentameters), in which the final word rimes with the word immediately preceding the cesural pause or the middle of the line.
A coin illegally imported into England by foreign merchants in the reign of Edward I.
Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the lion

a kind of verse, in which the end of the line rhymes with the middle; -- so named from Leo, or Leoninus, a Benedictine and canon of Paris in the twelfth century, who wrote largely in this measure, though he was not the inventor. The following line is an example
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of the lion .
of or characteristic of or resembling a lion

leonist.explanation: A name sometimes used for a member of the religious body known as the Waldenses.

leonotis.explanation: A small genus of tropical herbs and subshrubs of S Africa.
small genus of tropical herbs and subshrubs of South Africa

leontiasis.explanation: The bloating or enlargement of the head, especially of the face, due to tubercular leprosy: from the fancied leonine aspect produced by it.

leontopodium.explanation: A small genus of composite plants of the tribe Inuloideæ and subtribe Gnaphalieæ.
A genus of plants including the edelweiss ( Leontopodium alpinum ).

leonurus.explanation: A genus of labiate plants of the tribe Stachydeæ.
A genus of stout Old World herbs having cut-lobed leaves and flowers in whorls.
genus of stout Old World herbs having flowers in whorls

leopard.explanation: A large wild cat (Panthera pardus) of Africa and southern Asia, having either tawny fur with dark rosettelike markings or black fur.
Any of several similar felines, such as the cheetah or the snow leopard.
A lion in side view, having one forepaw raised and the head facing the observer.
The pard or panther, Felis pardus , the largest spotted cat of the Old World.
In heraldry , originally, a lion passant gardant.

A gold coin, weighing from about 53 to 69 grains, struck by Edward III. and Edward the Black Prince of England, for circulation in France, and having on the obverse a lion passant gardant. In French heraldry this representation is described as a lion léopardé, whence the name of the coin.

A large, savage, carnivorous mammal ( Felis leopardus ). It is of a yellow or fawn color, with rings or roselike clusters of black spots along the back and sides. It is found in Southern Asia and Africa. By some the panther ( Felis pardus ) is regarded as a variety of leopard.
any one of several species or varieties of small, spotted cats found in Africa, Southern Asia, and the East Indies; esp., Felis Bengalensis .
A large wild cat with a spotted coat, Panthera pardus, indigenous to Africa and Asia.
large feline of African and Asian forests usually having a tawny coat with black spots

leopardite.explanation: In petrog. , a fine-grained feldspathic quartzite, or quartz-porphyry, spotted with oxid of manganese, occurring in North Carolina.

leopardskin.explanation: Made of the hide of a leopard or of a fabric having a pattern similar to the markings of a leopard's coat.

leopardwood.explanation: The wood of Brosimum Aubletii. It is mottled with dark blotches, giving a fancied resemblance to the skin of a leopard. See snake-wood .
Flindersia maculosa, a tree in the citrus family.

leopoldinia.explanation: A genus of Brazilian palms of the tribe Areceæ and subtribe Caryotideæ.

leotard.explanation: A snugly fitting, stretchable one-piece garment with or without sleeves that covers the torso, worn especially by dancers, gymnasts, acrobats, and those engaging in exercise workouts.
A skin-tight one-piece garment with long sleeves and no legs , often worn by dancers , acrobats etc.

a tight-fitting garment of stretchy material that covers the body from the shoulders to the thighs (and may have long sleeves or legs reaching down to the ankles); worn by ballet dancers and acrobats for practice or performance

leotards.explanation: skintight knit hose covering the body from the waist to the feet worn by acrobats and dancers and as stockings by women and girls

lepadoid.explanation: A stalked barnacle of the genus Lepas, or family Lepadidæ ; a goose barnacle. Also used adjectively.
A stalked barnacle of the genus Lepas or family Lepadidae; a goose barnacle.

lepal.explanation: In botany , a barren transformed stamen.

lepas.explanation: The typical genus of Lepadidæ ; goose-mussels proper.
Any one of various species of Lepas, a genus of pedunculated barnacles found attached to floating timber, bottoms of ships, Gulf weed, etc.; -- called also goose barnacle . See barnacle .
Any of the genus Lepas of pedunculated barnacles found attached to floating timber, bottoms of ships, etc.; a goose barnacle.
type genus of the family Lepadidae

leper.explanation: A person who is avoided by others; a pariah.
A person who is shunned; a pariah .
a pariah who is avoided by others

lepidine.explanation: A colorless compound, obtained by the distillation of cinchonine with potassium hydroxid; py-4-methylquinoline. It has an odor of quinoline, melts below 0° C., and boils at 261–263° C. Also called quinolepidine .
An organic base, C9H6.N.CH3, metameric with quinaldine, and obtained by the distillation of cinchonine.
4-methylquinoline, a heterocyclic aromatic organic compound used in the preparation of certain dyes .

lepidium.explanation: A large genus of cruciferous plants, chiefly herbs, of the tribe Lepidineæ , distinguished by the dehiscent pod, which is almost always two-seeded, and by the white flowers.
In zoology , a genus of thysanurous insects. Also written Lepidion .
cosmopolitan genus of annual and biennial and perennial herbs: cress

lepidodendraceae.explanation: fossil plants characterized by conspicuous spirally arranged leaf scars on the trunk

lepidodendrid.explanation: One of an extinct family of trees allied to the modern club mosses, and including Lepidodendron and its allies.
Any of an extinct family of trees allied to the modern club mosses .

lepidodendron.explanation: A common fossil plant of the Carboniferous coal-measures, supposed, in some cases at least, to have furnished an important constituent of the coal itself.
A genus of fossil trees of the Devonian and Carboniferous ages, having the exterior marked with scars, mostly in quincunx order, produced by the separation of the leafstalks.

lepidoid.explanation: Lepidoidei: as, a lepidoid fish; a lepidoid scale.

lepidolite.explanation: A lilac or pink to gray mineral of the mica group, K(Li,Al) 3 (Si,Al) 4 O 10 (F,OH) 2 , used as lithium ore and in ceramic production.
A species of mica, of a lilac or rose-violet color, containing lithia. It usually occurs in masses consisting of small scales. See mica .
A pale lilac mica mineral that is a mixed basic fluoride and aluminosilicate of potassium , lithium and aluminium
a mineral of the mica group; an important source of lithium

lepidomelane.explanation: A species of the mica group (see mica ), of a deep-black color, usually occurring in small, rather inelastic scales. It contains a large amount of iron.
An iron-potash mica, of a raven-black color, usually found in granitic rocks in small six-sided tables, or as an aggregation of minute opaque scales. See mica .
A black iron - potash mica , usually found in granitic rocks in small six-sided tables, or as an aggregation of minute opaque scales .
a mica that is a biotite containing iron

lepidophloios.explanation: A genus of fossil plants of the coal-measures, closely related to Lepidodendron , with prominent (often very prominent) transverse rhombic leaf-cushions, at the lower end of each of which is a leafscar of the same shape, together with three smaller punctate vascular scars, the central one being the largest and triangular in form. This genus is found in various parts of Europe, in the United States, and in Canada.

lepidophyllum.explanation: A supposed genus of fossil plants, to which have been referred leaves, blades, or bracts forming a part of the organs of fructification of Lepidodendron and Lepidophloios.

lepidophyte.explanation: Any fossil plant of the great group supposed to represent the ancestors of the modern order Lycopodiales , including the families Lepidodendraceæ, Sigillariaceæ, Both-rodendraceæ , etc., or Paleozoic scale-trees.

lepidoporphyrin.explanation: A purple product which results from the yellow pigment in the wings and excrement of butterflies (lepidotic acid) on warming with dilute sulphuric acid.

lepidopteral.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Lepidoptera.

lepidopteran.explanation: Any of numerous insects of the order Lepidoptera, which includes the butterflies and moths, characterized by four membranous wings covered with small scales and having larvae that are called caterpillars.
An insect that in the adult state has four wings more or less covered with tiny scales; a lepidopterous insect.
Any insect of the order Lepidoptera ; the butterflies and moths
insect that in the adult state has four wings more or less covered with tiny scales

lepidopterist.explanation: One who is versed or engaged in the scientific study of Lepidoptera.
Someone who studies lepidoptery ; someone who studies butterflies and moths .
an entomologist who specializes in the collection and study of butterflies and moths

lepidopterologist.explanation: an entomologist who specializes in the collection and study of butterflies and moths

lepidopterology.explanation: That branch of entomology which treats of the Lepidoptera , or butterflies and moths.
The scientific study of butterflies and moths (the Lepidoptera ).
the branch of entomology dealing with Lepidoptera

lepidopteron.explanation: An insect that in the adult state has four wings more or less covered with tiny scales.
insect that in the adult state has four wings more or less covered with tiny scales

lepidopterous.explanation: entomology , having scaly wings; specifically, pertaining to the Lepidoptera , or having their characters. Also lepidopteral, lepidopteran.

lepidosauria.explanation: Reptilia , including reptiles with scales and plates, with limbs or without, and with the anal cleft transverse and the penis double.
A division of reptiles, including the serpents and lizards; the Plagiotremata.

lepidosiren.explanation: A genus of dipnoan fishes, typical of the family Lepidosirenidæ and subfamily Lepidosireninæ , of an elongate form, as in the amphibian genus Siren , but with a scaly body.

An eel-shaped ganoid fish of the order Dipnoi, having both gills and lungs. It inhabits the rivers of South America. The name is also applied to a related African species ( Protopterus annectens ). The lepidosirens grow to a length of from four to six feet. Called also doko .
An eel -shaped ganoid fish of the order Dipnoi , having both gills and lungs .

lepidosirenoid.explanation: A fish of the family Lepidosirenidæ.

lepidosis.explanation: In medicine , scaly disease: applied to ichthyosis, psoriasis, and pityriasis.
A scaly outgrowth; specifically, the ‘horn’ on the nose of the sand-viper, Vipera ammodytes.

lepidosperma.explanation: A genus of sedges of the tribe Rhynchosporeæ , distinguished by having subdistichous glumes and hard eroded seeds.

lepidosteus.explanation: A genus of fishes with rhomboid scales as hard as bone, whence the name.

lepidostrobus.explanation: The fruit-cone of plants of the genus Lepidodendron.

lepidote.explanation: botany , covered with scurfy scales of scaly spots; leprous.
Having a coat of scurfy scales, as the leaves of the oleaster.
Having a coat of scurfy scales .
rough to the touch; covered with scales or scurf

lepidotus.explanation: A genus of fossil ganoid fishes of the family Somionotidæ , characterized by thick, deeply imbricating scales with more or less produced overlapping edges, and numerous hemispherical successional teeth which make a revolution of 180° in passing from the incipi-ent to the mature condition. The genus ranges from the Keuper to the Lower Cretaceous, and is widespread in Europe, India, Siberia, and Brazil.

lepidurus.explanation: A genus of phyllopods of the family Apodidæ (or Apusidæ ), related to Apus , but having a spatulate telson; the spoontails. L. couesi is a species abounding in pools in Montana, Utah, and elsewhere.

lepiota.explanation: A large genus of agaricaceous fungi having a fleshy pileus, white spores, and an annulate stipe.
any fungus of the genus Lepiota.
any fungus of the genus Lepiota

lepisma.explanation: The typical genus of Lepismatidæ , having three long and four short caudal filaments, very long antennæ, and the body flat and scaly.

A genus of wingless thysanurous insects having an elongated flattened body, covered with shining scales and terminated by seven unequal bristles. A common species ( Lepisma saccharina ) is found in houses, and often injures books and furniture; it feeds on starch and eats sized paper and starched clothes. Called also shiner , silverfish , silver witch , silver moth , and furniture bug .
type genus of the Lepismatidae: silverfish

lepismoid.explanation: Like or pertaining to the Lepisma.
Like or pertaining to the Lepisma, a genus of insects .

lepisosteus.explanation: A genus of ganoid fishes which inhabit fresh waters of North America and China, and are commonly known as garpikes.
type genus of the Lepisosteidae: freshwater gars

lepocyta.explanation: An infusorian with a cell-membrane: distinguished from gymnocyta .

lepocyte.explanation: A nucleated cell with a cell-wall: distinguished from gymnocyte .

lepomis.explanation: A genus of sunfishes of American fresh waters, having The operculum ending behind in a convex black flap, sometimes highly developed.
A genus of freshwater sunfishes, inclding some of the breams.

leporid.explanation: A mammal of the family Leporidae , including the rabbits and hares.
Any mammal of the family Leporidae ; the rabbits and hares

leporidae.explanation: A natural family of mammals comprising the hares and rabbits.

leporide.explanation: A variety of the domesticated rabbit, supposed to be a hybrid between the rabbit ( Lepus cuniculus ) and the hare ( L. timidus ), and also known as the Belgian, hare.
red breed of domestic rabbits, also called Belgian hare .
red breed of domestic rabbits; hybrid between Old World rabbit and hare

leporine.explanation: Of or characteristic of rabbits or hares.
Of or pertaining to a hare; like or characteristic of, a hare.
of, relating to, or resembling a hare or rabbit .

lepothrix.explanation: The condition of a hair in which the scales of the cuticle are loosened and partially detached. Such hairs are found in the axilla.

leppy.explanation: A motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
(US) A young animal, particularly a cow or bull , a lamb , or a colt , which has been abandoned or orphaned .
motherless calf in a range herd of cattle

lepra.explanation: In pathology , a chronic and almost uniformly incurable disease, caused by a well-determined bacillus, Bacillus lepræ.
One of a class of scaly skin-affections, mostly psoriasis; lepra Græcorum.
In botany , a scurfy or mealy matter on the surface of some plants.

lepralia.explanation: A notable genus or chilostomatous polyzoans, of the family Escharidæ or Membraniporidæ , of irregularly branched form with broad flattened divisions. L. pertusa is an Adriatic species.

leprechaun.explanation: In Irish folklore, a mischievous elflike creature or fairy who grants wishes or reveals the location of hidden treasure when captured.

A small mischievous elf or spirit in Irish folklore; it is often depicted in literature as a dwarfish bearded old man; -- legend tells that if a leprechaun is captured, he will reveal the location of his hidden pot of gold.
One of a race of elves who can reveal hidden treasure to those who catch it
a mischievous elf in Irish folklore

leprologist.explanation: One who devotes special attention to the study of the nature and origin of leprosy and to its treatment.

leproma.explanation: One of the tubercles which occur in leprosy.

leprosarium.explanation: A hospital for the treatment of leprosy.
A hospital for the treatment of leprosy.
A place or institution (such as a colony, house or hospital used) for the treatment of leprosy .

leprose.explanation: botany , scale-like or scurf-like: said of some crustaceous lichens whose thallus adheres to trees or stones like a scurf; lepidote.
rough to the touch; covered with scales or scurf

leprosery.explanation: A hospital or home for lepers.

leprosity.explanation: The state of being leprous; leprousness.
The state or quality of being leprous or scaly; also, a scale.
The state or quality of being leprous or scaly .

leprosy.explanation: A chronic, mildly contagious disease of tropical and subtropical regions, caused by the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae, marked by lesions of the skin and mucous membranes and damage to peripheral nerves and other organs that, if untreated, can progress to disfigurement, lack of sensation, and blindness.

A name given to several different diseases. Regarding the leprosy of the Jews nothing certain is known. The term was probably applied to various cutaneous diseases, especially those of a chronic or contagious character. The term is now commonly restricted to lepra cutanea, or elephantiasis Græcorum. See lepra .

A cutaneous disease which first appears as blebs or as reddish, shining, slightly prominent spots, with spreading edges. These are often followed by an eruption of dark or yellowish prominent nodules, frequently producing great deformity. In one variety of the disease, anæsthesia of the skin is a prominent symptom. In addition there may be wasting of the muscles, falling out of the hair and nails, and distortion of the hands and feet with destruction of the bones and joints. It is incurable, and is probably contagious.
An infectious disease caused by infection by Mycobacterium leprae.
In the Bible , a disease of the skin not conclusively identified, which can also affect clothes and houses .

chronic granulomatous communicable disease occurring in tropical and subtropical regions; characterized by inflamed nodules beneath the skin and wasting of body parts; caused by the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae

leprous.explanation: Of, relating to, or resembling leprosy.
Having or consisting of loose, scurfy scales.

Leptons participate in weak interactions, but not strong interactions, and have masses generally less than those of mesons and baryons.
The smallest coin of modern Greece, equal to a centime. One hundred lepta make a drachma.

an elementary particle that participates in weak interactions but does not participate in the strong interaction; it has a baryon number of 0. Some known leptons are the electron , the negative muon , the tau-minus particle , and the neutrinos associated with each of these particles.
A small, bronze Judean coin from the 1st century BC. The lowest value coin ever in circulation. Considered by some to be the widow's mite .

Smaller, Less, Fewer. Smaller is rather more exact than less , but is used freely of persons and of things both concrete and abstract: as, a smaller man, soul, size. Less is not used of persons: as, less trouble, happiness, size, degree; less of an evil. With reference to size and number, the proper words are smaller and fewer. “This apple is less than that,” “There were less people there than I expected,” are inelegant and erroneous, although similar expressions are often used both in speech and in writing. While the latter, however, is in excusable, the former may be used sparingly without offense in certain collocations, especially in poetry. The allusion to the mustard-seed in Mark iv. 31 appears to be the only example in the Bible of the use of less in the sense of ‘smaller in size.’ In Shakspere's plays the word occurs more than two hundred times, and in Milton's poems more than a hundred; in the former it is used only four or five times and in the latter three times in the sense of ‘smaller in size,’ and never in that of ‘fewer.’

zoology and botany , marked as if with letters; having spots which look like letters, or make the surface seem to be written over: as, the lettered tortoise ( Emys scripta ); the lettered chinamark ( Diasemia literalis , small brown British moth).
Of or pertaining to learning or literature; learned.
Literate (able to read writing in letters).
Educated, especially having a degree (entitled to put an abbreviation such as BS, MA, PhD, MD after a signature).
highly educated; having extensive information or understanding

letterer.explanation: One who letters; one who marks or cuts the letters of an inscription, a title, or the like: as, a book- letterer.
One who makes, inscribes, or engraves, alphabetical letters.
A person who is professionally employed to add writing to something (as a sign, shop window, etc.)
A particular profession in the production of comics , an artist specializing in neatly writing written material such as dialogue.
A device for printing letters of text.

letterform.explanation: The development or design of the shape of an alphabet letter.
The shape of an individual letter
The design and development of such shapes

letterhead.explanation: The heading at the top of a sheet of letter paper, usually consisting of a name and an address.
Stationery imprinted with such a heading.
Paper which has the name of the person or company it is from printed on the top (possibly including address or other information). Used for formal correspondence .
a sheet of stationery with name and address of the organization printed at the top

lettering.explanation: The act, process, or art of forming letters.
Letters inscribed, as on a sign.
Specifically, in bookbinding , the act or process of affixing the alphabetical letters to the notched front margin of an indexed book; also, the addition of the name of the book on its back.
The act of stamping or marking with letters.
The letters impressed or marked upon anything; any inscription, as on a signboard, coin, or tombstone.
The act or business of making, or marking with, letters, as by cutting or painting.
letters inscribed (especially words engraved or carved) on something

letterleaf.explanation: An orchid of the genus Grammatophyllum : so named from its figured leaves. Also called letter-plant .

letterless.explanation: Without the presence or use of alphabetical letters .

letterman.explanation: A high school or college student who has earned a letter in a particular activity, especially a varsity sport.
A college student who has attained a specified level of participation in a sporting or other activity, and is awarded a cloth “ letter ” to be affixed to an item of clothing.

letterpress.explanation: The process of printing from a raised inked surface.
The text, as of a book, distinct from illustrations or other ornamentation.
A press for copying letters by transfer; a copying-press.
Letters or words impressed on paper or other material from printing-types; printed text: so called when subordinate to or in contrast with illustrations.
Print; letters and words impressed on paper or other material by types; -- often used of the reading matter in distinction from the illustrations.
The printing process in which ink is applied to the top surface of a raised image area, which is then pressed against paper to transfer the image.
: printing directly from type , in distinction from printing from plates .
a machine used for such printing .
printing from a plate with raised characters

letters.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of letter .

letterwood.explanation: The heart-wood of the South American tree Brosimum Aubletii.

The beautiful and highly elastic wood of a tree of the genus Brosimum ( Brosimum Aubletii ), found in Guiana; -- so called from black spots in it which bear some resemblance to hieroglyphics; also called snakewood , and leopardwood . It is much used for bows and for walking sticks.
The wood of the tree Brosimum aubletii, marked with black spots resembling hieroglyphics .

lettic.explanation: Lettic language; the Samoghitians are a Lettic people. Lettic race is a general term for the Letts, Lithuanians, and Borussians or Old Prussians.
Of or pertaining to the Letts; Lettish.
Of or pertaining to a branch of the Slavic family, subdivided into Lettish, Lithuanian, and Old Prussian.

lettice.explanation: A kind of fur, white or very light-colored, in use as late as the middle of the sixteenth century.

lettiga.explanation: A kind of sedan-chair, for two persons, who sit facing each other: carried on long poles by two mules.

letting.explanation: The award of a public contract
property that is leased or rented out or let

lettsomite.explanation: A basic sulphate of copper, of a bright-blue color: same as cyanotrichite .

lettuce.explanation: Any of various plants of the genus Lactuca of the composite family, especially L. sativa, cultivated for its edible leaves.
The leaves of L. sativa, used especially in salads.
A garden-herb, Lactuca sativa , a hardy annual, extensively cultivated for use as a salad.
Any plant of the genus Lactuca; also, a plant having some resemblance to Lactuca.
In America, Lactuca Canadensis. Also called trumpetweed and trumpet-milkweed.
Sometimes the same as blue lettuce .

A composite plant of the genus Lactuca ( Lactuca sativa ), the leaves of which are used as salad. Plants of this genus yield a milky juice, from which lactucarium is obtained. The commonest wild lettuce of the United States is Lactuca Canadensis .
United States currency; dollar bills; greenbacks.
certain papery green seaweeds of the genus Ulva.
An edible plant , Lactuca sativa and its close relatives, having a head of green and/or purple leaves .
The leaves of the lettuce plant, eaten as a vegetable ; as a dish often mixed with other ingredients, dressing etc.
: Folding money, also called cabbage , due to the green color of both US currency and the vegetables.
leaves of any of various plants of Lactuca sativa
any of various plants of the genus Lactuca

letup.explanation: A reduction in pace, force, or intensity; a slowdown.
A pause or period of slackening.

leu.explanation: A modern silver coin of Rumania, the unit of the monetary system, equivalent to the French franc, or about 19 United States cents.
The unit of currency of Romania , equal to one hundred bani .
The unit of currency of Moldova , equal to one hundred bani.
the basic unit of money in Moldova
the basic unit of money in Romania

leucadendron.explanation: A genus of plants of the order Proteaceæ and tribe Proteeæ , distinguished by having the regular diœcious flowers in heads in both sexes.
A genus of evergreen shrubs from the Cape of Good Hope, having handsome foliage. Leucadendron argenteum is the silverboom of the colonists.
Any of the genus Leucadendron of evergreen shrubs .
large genus of evergreen trees and shrubs having silvery white leaves and solitary terminal flowers with conspicuous silvery bracts

leucaemia.explanation: malignant neoplasm of blood-forming tissues; characterized by abnormal proliferation of leukocytes; one of the four major types of cancer

leucaena.explanation: small genus of tropical evergreen trees or shrubs having pods like those of the acacia

leucaniline.explanation: A white crystalline substance (C 20 H 21 N 3 ) forming colorless salts, prepared by treating fuchsine salts with zinc-dust and hydrochloric acid. It yields rosaniline by oxidation.
A colorless, crystalline, organic base, obtained from rosaniline by reduction, and also from other sources. It forms colorless salts.
A colourless crystalline organic base , obtained from rosaniline by reduction , and also from other sources.

leucaugite.explanation: An aluminous variety of pyroxene, allied to augite, but containing very little iron, and hence of a white or grayish color.

leucaurin.explanation: A colorless compound, , prepared by the reduction of aurin by means of zinc dust and sodium hydroxid. It crystallizes in prisms and is readily reconverted into aurin. Also called triphenylolmethane .

leucemia.explanation: A disease characterized by a large excess of the white corpuscles of the blood, with hypertrophy of the spleen or the lymphatic glands, or changes in the bone-marrow. It is usually fatal. Also called leucocythemia .

leuchtenbergite.explanation: A kind of chlorite of a white or greenish-white color, occurring in hexagonal plates or crystals.

leucic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from leucin, and called also oxycaproic acid .

leucin.explanation: A white pulverulent substance, amido-caproic acid (C 6 H 11 O 2 NH 2 ), obtained by treating muscular fiber with sulphuric acid, and afterward with alcohol.

leucine.explanation: An essential amino acid, C 6 H 13 NO 2 , obtained by the hydrolysis of protein by pancreatic enzymes during digestion and necessary for optimal growth in children and for the maintenance of nitrogen balance in adults.

a naturally occurring alpha-amino acid ((CH3)2CH.CH2.CH(NH2)-COOH), one of the building units of almost all proteins of living organisms, both animal and vegetable. It is one of the essential amino acids (not synthesized by the human body, a required component for proper nutrition), and is hydrophobic in character when bound in proteins. In isolated form it is a white, crystalline, zwitterionic substance formed, e. g. by the decomposition of proteins by pancreatic digestion, by the action of boiling dilute mineral acid, or by putrefaction. Chemically it is to be considered as amido-caproic acid. It occurs as two optical isomers, the L- and D-forms. The L-form, L-leucine, is the natural form, present in most proteins.
An essential amino acid , C6H13NO2, isomeric with isoleucine , found in most animal proteins ; it is essential for growth in children .
a white crystalline amino acid occurring in proteins that is essential for nutrition; obtained by the hydrolysis of most dietary proteins

leucism.explanation: A partial loss of pigmentation in a human or other animal, resulting in white, pale, or patchy coloration of the skin, hair, fur, or feathers but not the eyes.
In zoology , whiteness resulting from lack or loss of coloring; albinism, partial or complete: a technical term, correlated with melanism and erythrism. See albinism .
An animal condition characterized by reduced pigmentation .

leucite.explanation: A white or gray mineral of potassium aluminum silicate, KAlSi 2 O 6 .
A mineral originally found in the recent volcanic rocks of southern Italy, especially at Vesuvius, disseminated through the lavas in crystals, usually trapezohedrons, or in irregular masses.
A small yellowish body found in the cotyledons of a germinating plant that has not been exposed to sunlight.

A mineral having a glassy fracture, occurring in translucent trapezohedral crystals. It is a silicate of alumina and potash KAlSi2O6. It is found in the volcanic rocks of Italy, especially at Vesuvius.

A mineral of silica -poor igneous , plutonic and volcanic rocks . Chemically, leucite is a potassium feldspar with insufficient silica to satisfy the chemical bonds. Because of the unfilled bonds, leucite weathers rapidly and can only be seen as inclusions in freshly broken rock.

leucitite.explanation: The name given by Rosenbusch to varieties of leucite rock containing no olivin.

leucitoid.explanation: In crystallography , a tetragonal trisoctahedron, or trapezohedron: so called as being a common form of the mineral leucite.
The trapezohedron or tetragonal trisoctahedron; -- so called as being the form of the mineral leucite.
The trapezohedron or tetragonal trisoctahedron , the form of the mineral leucite .

leucitophyre.explanation: A crystalline-granular rock, differing from ordinary basalt chiefly in the presence of considerable leucite.

leuckartia.explanation: The typical genus of the family

leucoblast.explanation: A germinal leucocyte, or the germ of a leucocyte.

leucochalcite.explanation: A basic copper arseniate which occurs in white silky acicular crystals.

leucocholy.explanation: “White bile”: a nonce-word, opposed to melancholy , “black bile.”

leucochroic.explanation: anthropology , having a light-colored skin: contrasted with mesochroic and æthochroic (‘black-colored’).

leucocidin.explanation: A bacterial cytotoxin which causes the destruction of leucocytes.
Any staphylococcal or streptococcal exotoxin that causes leucocyte killing or lysis .

leucocratic.explanation: petrography , a term proposed by Brögger (1896) to designate igneous rocks characterized by a preponderance of light-colored minerals, or rather of minerals that are normally light-colored (chiefly feldspar and feldspathic minerals, and quartz), as contrasted with those ( melanocratic ) in which there is a preponderance of dark-colored minerals.

leucocyte.explanation: A white or colorless corpuscle of the blood or lymph.
A colorless corpuscle, as one of the white blood corpuscles, or those found in lymph, marrow of bone, connective tissue, etc.
blood cells that engulf and digest bacteria and fungi; an important part of the body's defense system

leucocythaemia.explanation: A disease in which the white corpuscles of the blood are largely increased in number, and there is enlargement of the spleen, or the lymphatic glands; leuchæmia.

leucocythemia.explanation: A disease in which there is a vastly increased number of white blood cells in the blood.

leucocytogenesis.explanation: The production of leucocytes, or white blood-corpuscles.

leucocytolysis.explanation: The destruction of leucocytes by specific leueocytotoxins.

leucocytopenic.explanation: pathology , of or relating to a decreased number of leucocytes, or colorless blood-corpuscles.

leucocytosis.explanation: The presence of an excessive number of white corpuscles in the blood, especially when merely the result of temporary causes and not produced by grave disease.
The number, actual or relative, of white corpuscles in a given specimen of blood, an excess being designated hyperleucocytosis , and a number below the normal hypoleueocytosis or leucopenia.
A raised white blood cell count, above the normal range.
an abnormal increase in the number of white blood cells in the blood as a result of infection (as in leukemia)

leucoderma.explanation: A loss of skin pigmentation , often in patches

leucoline.explanation: A nitrogenous organic base from coal tar, and identical with quinoline. Cf. quinoline .
A nitrogenous organic base from coal tar , identical with quinoline .

leucoma.explanation: In pathology , a white opacity of the cornea of the eye, the result of inflammation. Also called albugo .
A white opacity in the cornea of the eye; -- called also albugo .
An opaque area or scar on the cornea of an eye .
eye disease consisting of an opaque white spot on the cornea

leucomaine.explanation: A nitrogenous organic base or alkaloid produced in living animal tissues as a result of their activity: distinguished from a ptomaine , which is an alkaloid produced in the putrefactive decay of a dead tissue.
An animal base or alkaloid, appearing in the tissue during life; hence, a vital alkaloid, as distinguished from a ptomaine or cadaveric poison.
An animal base or alkaloid , appearing in the tissue during life ; hence, a vital alkaloid, as distinguished from a ptomaine or cadaveric poison .

leucon.explanation: The typical genus of the family Leuconidæ.
Any sponge belonging to the group Leuconaria.
A complex sponge structure in which chambers lined with choanocytes are connected by a network of canals

leucones.explanation: Calcispongiæ , characterized first by great thickening of the ectodermal syncytium, so that the inhalent pores, such as exist in Ascones , lengthen into canals which may variously branch and anastomose, and secondly by final restriction to these canals of the endodermal cells, which at first form a continuous layer.

leuconoid.explanation: leuconoid type of canal system in sponges. Contrasted with syconoid .

leucopenia.explanation: A diminution in the number of white corpuscles in the blood. Also called hypoleucocytosis .
an abnormal lowering of the white blood cell count

leucophane.explanation: An imperfectly crystallized mineral, of a pale greenish or wine-yellow color. It is a fluosilicate of beryllium, calcium, and sodium, and is found in Norway. Also called leucophanite .
A mineral of a greenish yellow color; it is a silicate of glucina, lime, and soda with fluorine. Called also leucophanite .

leucophanite.explanation: A sorosilicate mineral that occurs in pegmatites and alkali igneous complexes as yellow, greenish or white triclinic crystals .

leucophlegmacy.explanation: In pathology , an inferred tendency to a dropsical state, as indicated by paleness, flabbiness, or redundancy of serum in the blood.
A dropsical habit of body, or the commencement of anasarca; paleness, with viscid juices and cold sweats.
A dropsical habit of body, or the commencement of anasarca ; paleness with oily sweating .

leucophoenicite.explanation: A monoclinic-prismatic mineral containing hydrogen , manganese , oxygen , and silicon .

leucophore.explanation: Any chromatophore that shows white in reflected light

leucophyre.explanation: In petrography , a name given by Gümbel (1874) to certain light-colored altered diabases, with saussuritized feldspars, pale-green augite, and much chlorite.

leucoplast.explanation: One of certain very minute whitish or colorless granules occurring in the protoplasm of plants and supposed to be the nuclei around which starch granules will form.
An organelle found in certain plant cells , a non- pigmented category of plastid with various biosynthetic functions.

leucoplastid.explanation: A kind of unpigmented plastid involved in a wide range of essential biosynthetic functions.

leucopyrite.explanation: A mineral (Fe 3 As 4 ) of a color between white and steel-gray and of a metallic luster, consisting chiefly of arsenic and iron. It is related to loellingite (FeAs 2 ) and arsenopyrite (FeAsS or FeAs 2 .FeS 2 ).
A mineral of a color between white and steel-gray, with a metallic luster, and consisting chiefly of arsenic and iron.

leucorrhoea.explanation: In pathology , a mucous or mucopurulent discharge of a white color from the vagina; fluor albus; the whites. Also called blennelytria and colporrhea.
A discharge of a white, yellowish, or greenish, viscid mucus, resulting from inflammation or irritation of the membrane lining the genital organs of the female; the whites.
discharge of white mucous material from the vagina; often an indication of infection

leucoryx.explanation: The specific name of the saber-horned antelope, Oryx leucoryx , adopted as a common name.
A large antelope of North Africa ( Oryx leucoryx ), allied to the gemsbok.

leucosis.explanation: The formation or progress of leucoma.

leucosolenia.explanation: The typical genus of the family Leucosoleniidæ.

leucosphenite.explanation: A titanosilicate of barium and sodium, which occurs in wedge-shaped monoclinic crystals, white to grayish blue in color, with vitreous to pearly luster: obtained from southern Greenland.
A monoclinic-prismatic mineral containing barium , boron , oxygen , silicon , sodium , and titanium .

leucosphere.explanation: A name coined by Lockyer for the inner portion of the sun′ s corona: so called because of its whiteness, in contrast with the scarlet chromosphere.

leucosticte.explanation: A notable genus of fringilline birds, having an oblique ridge on the under mandible, and the plumage more or less rosy or silvery-gray.

leucothoe.explanation: Any of the genus Leucothoe of flowering plants .
any plant of the genus Leucothoe; grown for their beautiful white flowers; glossy foliage contains a poisonous substance similar to that found in genus Kalmia

leucotome.explanation: an instrument used to perform a leucotomy

leucotomy.explanation: surgical interruption of nerve tracts to and from the frontal lobe of the brain; often results in marked cognitive and personality changes

leucous.explanation: White; -- applied to albinos, from the whiteness of their skin and hair.

leucoxene.explanation: An opaque white substance often observed in thin sections of rocks, derived from the alteration of titanic iron. It is, sometimes at least, identical with titanite in composition.
A nearly opaque white mineral, in part identical with titanite, observed in some igneous rocks as the result of the alteration of titanic iron.
A mineral , mostly composed of rutile , occurring in igneous rocks, often by alteration of ilmenite or other titanium minerals

leucyl.explanation: The univalent radical derived from leucine .

leud.explanation: a vassal or tenant in the early Middle Ages

leukaemia.explanation: malignant neoplasm of blood-forming tissues; characterized by abnormal proliferation of leukocytes; one of the four major types of cancer

leukaemic.explanation: Characteristic of, or associated with leukaemia

leukemia.explanation: Any of various acute or chronic neoplastic diseases of the bone marrow in which unrestrained proliferation of white blood cells occurs, usually accompanied by anemia, impaired blood clotting, and enlargement of the lymph nodes, liver, and spleen.
A type of malignancy affecting the blood cells or blood-forming tissues.
Any specific form or type of cancer of the blood-forming tissues
malignant neoplasm of blood-forming tissues; characterized by abnormal proliferation of leukocytes; one of the four major types of cancer

leukocidin.explanation: A type of cytotoxin created by some types of bacteria .

leukocyte.explanation: blood cells that engulf and digest bacteria and fungi; an important part of the body's defense system

leukocytosis.explanation: An abnormally large increase in the number of white blood cells in the blood, often occurring during an acute infection or inflammation.
an abnormal increase in the number of white blood cells in the blood as a result of infection (as in leukemia)

leukoderma.explanation: a congenital skin condition characterized by spots or bands of unpigmented skin

leukodystrophy.explanation: Any of a group of disorders characterized by progressive degeneration of the white matter of the brain , caused by imperfect growth or development of the myelin sheath that acts as an insulator around nerve fibres .

leukoma.explanation: eye disease consisting of an opaque white spot on the cornea

leukopenia.explanation: An abnormally low number of leukocytes in the circulating blood.
an abnormally low count of leukocytes , or white blood cells , in the blood
an abnormal lowering of the white blood cell count

leukopoiesis.explanation: The formation or production of white blood cells.

leukorrhea.explanation: A thick, whitish discharge from the vagina or cervical canal.
discharge of white mucous material from the vagina; often an indication of infection

leukosis.explanation: An abnormally large number of leukocytes , or the tissue that produces them

leukotomy.explanation: surgical interruption of nerve tracts to and from the frontal lobe of the brain; often results in marked cognitive and personality changes

lev.explanation: The currency of Bulgaria , divided into 100 stotinki
the basic unit of money in Bulgaria

leva.explanation: A current silver coin of Bulgaria, of the value of 20 cents. One hundred stotinki equal one leva.

levana.explanation: A goddess who protected newborn infants.

levancy.explanation: The actor state of risingup. See levant and couchant , under couchant.

levant.explanation: To leave hurriedly or in secret to avoid unpaid debts.
A bet made by one who expects to evade paying if he loses.

[ capitalized ] The region east of Italy lying on and near the Mediterranean, sometimes reckoned as extending east to the Euphrates and as taking in the Nile valley, thus including Greece and Egypt; more specifically, the coast-region and islands of Asia Minor and Syria: a name originally given by the Italians.
An easterly wind blowing up the Mediterranean; a levanter.
Same as levant morocco .
levant me , a mild imprecation much like blow me!
Minsheu , 1617;

capitalized ] In geology , appellative of the fourth of Professor H. Rogers's fifteen divisions of the Paleozoic strata in the Appalachian chain, the names of which suggest metaphorically the different natural periods of the day.
Same as lavant .
In leather manufacturing , artificial blood used instead of real blood for obtaining a perfect black.
Rising or having risen from rest; -- said of cattle. See Couchant and levant, under couchant .
The countries washed by the eastern part of the Mediterranean and its contiguous waters.
A levanter (the wind so called).
Eastern.
To run away from one's debts; to decamp.
Disappearing or absconding after losing a bet.
To abscond or run away, especially to avoid paying money or debts.
Rising , of an animal.
run off without paying a debt
a heavy morocco often used in bookbinding
the former name for the geographical area of the eastern Mediterranean that is now occupied by Lebanon, Syria, and Israel

levanted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of levant .

levanter.explanation: A strong easterly wind of the Mediterranean area.
A native or inhabitant of the Levant.
An easterly wind blowing up the Mediterranean from the direction of the Levant.
One who levants; one who runs away disgracefully.
Specifically One who bets at a horse-race, and runs away without paying the wager lost.
A strong easterly wind peculiar to the Mediterranean.
An Easterly wind that blows from the Mediterranean, through the straits of Gibraltar to the Atlantic.
an easterly wind in the western Mediterranean area

levants.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of levant .

levation.explanation: The act of raising; elevation; especially, the elevation of the Host.
The act of raising; elevation; upward motion, as that produced by the action of a levator muscle.
The act of raising ; elevation or upward motion , such as that produced by the action of a levator muscle .

levator.explanation: A muscle that raises a bodily part.
A surgical instrument for lifting the depressed fragments of a fractured skull.
In anatomy , that which raises or elevates, as various muscles of the human body: opposed to depressor.
A surgical instrument used to raise a depressed part of the skull.
A muscle that serves to raise some part, as the lip or the eyelid.
A surgical instrument used to raise a depressed part of the skull.
a muscle that serves to lift some body part (as the eyelid or lip)

leve.explanation: An obsolete variant of leave , leave , leeve, live , and lief.
To grant; -- used esp. in exclamations or prayers followed by a dependent clause.

levee.explanation: An embankment on the margin of a river, to confine it within its natural channel: as, the levees of the Mississippi.
Hence A landing-place for vessels; a quay, pier, or landing-stage.
levee a river.
In irrigation , one of the small continuous ridges of earth surrounding the fields, or compartments, of land that is to be irrigated.
The act or time of rising.
A morning reception held by a prince or great personage; a morning assembly.
A general or miscellaneous assemblage of guests, without reference to the time of day; a reception: as, the president's levee.
To keep within a channel by means of levees.
The act of rising.

A morning assembly or reception of visitors, -- in distinction from a soirée , or evening assembly; a matinée ; hence, also, any general or somewhat miscellaneous gathering of guests, whether in the daytime or evening.
To attend the levee or levees of.
An embankment to prevent inundation; ; sometimes, the steep bank of a river.
The act of rising ; getting up, especially in the morning after rest.
A reception of visitors held after getting up.
A formal reception , especially one given by royalty or other leaders.
An embankment to prevent inundation ; as, the levees along the Mississippi.
The steep bank of a river , or border of an irrigated field .
A pier or other landing place on a river.
To keep within a channel by means of levees.
a pier that provides a landing place on a river
an embankment that is built in order to prevent a river from overflowing
a formal reception of visitors or guests (as at a royal court)

level.explanation: Relative position or rank on a scale.
A relative degree, as of achievement, intensity, or concentration.
A natural or proper position, place, or stage.
Position along a vertical axis; height or depth.
A horizontal line or plane at right angles to the plumb.
The position or height of such a line or plane.
A flat, horizontal surface.
A land area of uniform elevation.

An instrument for ascertaining whether a surface is horizontal, vertical, or at a 45° angle, consisting essentially of an encased, liquid-filled tube containing an air bubble that moves to a center window when the instrument is set on an even plane.
Such a device combined with a telescope and used in surveying.
A computation of the difference in elevation between two points by using such a device.
Having a flat, smooth surface.
Being on a horizontal plane.
Being at the same height or position as another; even.
Being at the same degree of rank, standing, or advantage as another; equal.
Being or relating to a specified rank or standing. Often used in combination.
Exhibiting no abrupt variations; steady.
Rational and balanced; sensible.
Filled evenly to the top.
To make horizontal, flat, or even.
To place on the same rank; equalize.
To tear down (a building, for example); raze.
To knock down, as with a blow; lay low.
To aim along a horizontal plane.
To direct emphatically or forcefully toward someone: synonym : aim .
To measure the different elevations of (a tract of land) with a level.
To bring persons or things to an equal level; equalize.
To aim a weapon horizontally.
To be frank and open.
Along a flat or even line or plane.
( (one's) level best ) The best one can do in an earnest attempt.
( on the level ) Without deception; honest.
The correction for level of an astronomical instrument; the deviation of its axis from exact horizontality.

In landscape-gardening , one of the horizontal surfaces in which an irregular piece of land may be arranged. By the use of different levels the designer may place various features of his design above or below the eye.
levy .
level a billiard-table.
level a road or walk.
level ranks of society.
level observations to the capacity of children.

leveled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of level .

leveler.explanation: One who advocates the abolition of social inequities.

A member of an English radical political movement arising in the Parliamentarian forces of the 1640s and advocating universal male suffrage, equality before the law, parliamentary democracy, and religious tolerance.
One of a secret society of rebels in Ireland in the latter half of the eighteenth century: named from their principles and the leveling of park palings and walls, practised by them.
In currying , a composition used to eradicate the grease before leather is dyed.
In golf , a hole of such length that no player can reach the green in one stroke and any player can reach it in two strokes.
A person who uses an engineer's level; a member of an engineering or surveying party.
One who levels or makes even; one who or that which brings or reduces to a level, or destroys by leveling: as, time is the great leveler.
One who desires or strives to bring men to a common level; one who would level social distinctions, or who disregards differences of rank or status.
[ capitalized ] One of a party which arose in the army of the Long Parliament about 1647.
A screw or other device fitted to the leg of a billiard-table or to any piece of apparatus for adjusting the table or apparatus to a true level.
One who, or that which, levels.
One who would remove social inequalities or distinctions; a socialist.
comparative form of level : more level
A person or thing that levels .
A person holding a political opinion in favor of eliminating disparities between the haves and the have nots .
a radical who advocates the abolition of social distinctions

levelheaded.explanation: exercising or showing good judgment or common sense; sensible.

levelheadedness.explanation: The property of being levelheaded , stable, not overly swayed by passion .

leveling.explanation: The act or process of reducing an uneven surface to a level or plane.

Carelessness of temper or conduct; want of seriousness; disposition to trifle; inconstancy; volatility: as, the levity of youth.

Synonyms . Levity, Volatility, Flightiness, Frivolity, Lightness. All these words are founded upon the idea of the lack of physical and, by figure, of mental and moral substance or weight, with a resulting ease in flying away from what is wise. The first three refer especially to outward conduct. Levity is a want of seriousness, temporary or habitual, a disposition to trifle with important interests. Volatility is that moral defect by which one cannot dwell long upon any one object of thought, or turns quickly from one source of pleasure to another: the word does not convey much opprobrium; in the young some degree of volatility is expected. Flightiness borders upon the loss of sanity in caprice or excitement of fancy; it is volatility in an extreme degree. Frivolity is a matter of nature, an inability to care about any but the most petty and trifling things. Lightness is not so strong as frivolity , but covers nearly the same ground; it emphasizes inconstancy.
The quality of weighing less than something else of equal bulk; relative lightness, especially as shown by rising through, or floating upon, a contiguous substance; buoyancy; -- opposed to gravity .

libration.explanation: A very slow oscillation, real or apparent, of a satellite as viewed from the larger celestial body around which it revolves.
The act of librating or balancing, or the state of being balanced; a state of equipoise; balance.
In astronomy , a real or apparent libratory or oscillating motion, like that of a balance before coming to rest.
libration in latitude , in consequenoe of her axis being inclined to the plane of her orbit, so that sometimes one of her poles and sometimes the other declines, as it were, or dips toward the earth

diurnal libration , which is simply a consequence of the lunar parallax. In the last case, an observer at the surface of the earth perceives points near the upper edge of the moon's disk, at the time of her rising, which disappear as her elevation is increased; while new ones on the opposite or lower edge, that were before invisible, come into view as she descends toward the horizon. If the observer were placed at the earth's center he would perceive no diurnal libration.
The act or state of librating.
A real or apparent libratory motion, like that of a balance before coming to rest.

any one of those small periodical changes in the position of the moon's surface relatively to the earth, in consequence of which narrow portions at opposite limbs become visible or invisible alternately. It receives different names according to the manner in which it takes place; as: (a) Libration in longitude , that which, depending on the place of the moon in its elliptic orbit, causes small portions near the eastern and western borders alternately to appear and disappear each month. ( b ) Libration in latitude , that which depends on the varying position of the moon's axis in respect to the spectator, causing the alternate appearance and disappearance of either pole. ( c ) Diurnal or parallactic libration , that which brings into view on the upper limb, at rising and setting, some parts not in the average visible hemisphere.

The apparent wobble or variation in the visible side of the Moon that permanently faces the Earth , allowing observers on Earth to see, over a period of time, slightly more than half of the lunar surface .
A similar rotational or orbital characteristic of some other celestial body.
(astronomy) a real or apparent slow oscillation of a moon or satellite

librational.explanation: astronomy , pertaining to the librations of the moon or of the planets Mercury and Venus.

libratory.explanation: Balancing; moving like a balance, as it tends to an equipoise or level.

license.explanation: Official or legal permission to engage in a regulated activity: synonym : permission .
A document, card, plate, or tag that is issued as proof of official or legal permission.
A contract allowing someone to use a proprietary product or service.
Freedom of action or permission to act.

To give or yield permission to or for.
To grant a license to or for; authorize. synonym : authorize .
license a man to keep an inn; to license a physician or a lawyer. Also licence .
licensed buffoon.

Authority or liberty to do or forbear some act; the admission of an individual, by proper authority, to the right of doing particular acts, practising a certain profession, or conducting a certain trade; a grant of authorization; a permit.

Specifically— In the law of real property , authority to do an act or series of acts upon the land of the person granting the license, without, however, conferring on the licensee any estate in the land: as, a license to enter and shore up an adjoining building, or to take sand, or bore for oil: distinguished from easement .
In patent and copyright law , permission to use the invention patented, or publish the work copyrighted, without a grant of any proprietary rights therein.

In the law of municipal corporations and police power , permission from government to pursue a vocation or carry on acts which are prohibited to those not taking a license, the object being, by the prohibition and the conditions imposed on the permission, to regulate the extent or manner of doing what is licensed.

In international law , a safe-conduct granted by a belligerent state to its own subjects, to those of its enemy, or to neutrals, to carry on a trade which is interdicted by the laws of war, and operating as a dispensation from the penalties of those laws, with respect to the state granting it.

Eccles. , an authority to preach, but not to administer the sacraments, nor to represent the church as a clergyman in its ecclesiastical assemblies, which powers are conferred by ordination. The license is granted, frequently for a limited period only, by an ecclesiastical body, after examination of the candidate as to his fitness. The person licensed is termed a licentiate. In the Anglican Church, a deacon must procure a license from a bishop to enable him to preach, that power not being inherent in his office. A license from the bishop is also necessary to permit a man not in orders to act as lay reader.
A document or certificate conferring such authority or permission.

Unrestrained freedom of thought and action, especially the abuse of such freedom; excess of liberty; undue freedom; freedom misused in contempt of law and decorum; rejection of legal and moral control; libertinism.

An intentional departure from a rule or standard in art or literature; exceptional liberty taken for the sake of a particular purpose or effect: as, poetical or musical license ; to use license in painting or sculpture.
Synonyms Liberty , etc. (see leave , n. ); laxity.

Authority or liberty given to do or forbear any act; especially, a formal permission from the proper authorities to perform certain acts or to carry on a certain business, which without such permission would be illegal; a grant of permission.
The document granting such permission.
Excess of liberty; freedom abused, or used in contempt of law or decorum; disregard of law or propriety.
That deviation from strict fact, form, or rule, in which an artist or writer indulges, assuming that it will be permitted for the sake of the advantage or effect gained
To permit or authorize by license; to give license to.
A legal document giving official permission to do something; a permit .
The legal terms under which a person is allowed to use a product, especially software .
Freedom to deviate deliberately from normally applicable rules or practices (especially in behavior or speech ).
Excessive freedom; lack of due restraint .
An academic degree , the holder of which is called a licentiate , ranking slightly below doctorate , awarded by certain European and Latin-American universities.
The act of giving a formal (usually written) authorization .

Specifically— A friar licensed by the Pope to hear confession, grant absolution, and inflict penance in any place independently of the local clergy.
