lichen.explanation: A composite organism made up of a fungus, usually an ascomycete, that grows symbiotically with an alga or a cyanobacterium and characteristically forms a crustlike or branching growth on rocks or tree trunks.
Any of various skin diseases characterized by patchy eruptions of small, firm papules.

In botany , a plant or vegetable growth of the group Lichenes , ordinarily recognizable by its dry aspect and gray, brown, greenish, or blackish color, and its appearance in crusts, scaly patches, or bush-like forms on trees, rails, rocks, etc.

In pathology , an eruption of papules, of a red or pale color, which do not reach a vesicular or pustular stage. They may be in clusters or scattered, or disseminated over the surface of the skin; and may be attended with itching, as in lichen ruber, or may be quite free from it, as in lichen scrofulosorum.

One of a class of cellular, flowerless plants, (technically called Lichenes ), having no distinction of leaf and stem, usually of scaly, expanded, frond-like forms, but sometimes erect or pendulous and variously branched. They derive their nourishment from the air, and generate by means of spores. The species are very widely distributed, and form irregular spots or patches, usually of a greenish or yellowish color, upon rocks, trees, and various bodies, to which they adhere with great tenacity. They are often improperly called rock moss or tree moss .

A name given to several varieties of skin disease, esp. to one characterized by the eruption of small, conical or flat, reddish pimples, which, if unchecked, tend to spread and produce great and even fatal exhaustion.
Any of many symbiotic organisms , being associations of fungi and algae ; often found as white or yellow patches on old walls , etc.
any of several eruptive skin diseases characterized by hard thick lesions grouped together and resembling lichens growing on rocks
any thallophytic plant of the division Lichenes; occur as crusty patches or bushy growths on tree trunks or rocks or bare ground etc.

lictor.explanation: A Roman functionary who carried fasces when attending a magistrate in public appearances.

Among the ancient Romans, one of a number of officers, required to be free-born (though freed-men were admitted to the office under the empire), whose functions were to attend a magistrate, bearing the fasces, in some cases with the ax and in others without it, in order to clear the way and enforce due respect, and also to arrest offenders and to scourge or behead condemned persons.

An officer who bore an ax and fasces or rods, as ensigns of his office. His duty was to attend the chief magistrates when they appeared in public, to clear the way, and cause due respect to be paid to them, also to apprehend and punish criminals.
An officer in ancient Rome, attendant on a consul or magistrate , who bore the fasces and was responsible for punishing criminals.

a complex polymer; the chief constituent of wood other than carbohydrates; binds to cellulose fibers to harden and strengthen cell walls of plants

ligniperdous.explanation: Wood - destroying ; said of certain insects and fungi.

Brown-coal; imperfectly formed coal, or that in which the original form of the wood is so distinctly preserved that it can be easily recognized by the unaided eye.

Mineral coal retaining the texture of the wood from which it was formed, and burning with an empyreumatic odor. It is of more recent origin than the anthracite and bituminous coal of the proper coal series. Called also brown coal , wood coal .
intermediate between peat and bituminous coal

lignitic.explanation: Containing lignite; resembling, or of the nature of, lignite.

The combination of lignin and cellulose in the structural cells of woody plants .

Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the formic acid series, found in the tar, wax, or paraffine obtained by distilling certain kinds of wood, as the beech.
Of or pertaining to lignoceric acid or its derivatives

lignose.explanation: A colorless compound, C 18 H 26 O 11 , prepared by the action of dilute acids on glueolignose.

ligroin.explanation: That part of petroleum which has a boiling-point between 90° and 120° C.

It is a complex and variable mixture of several hydrocarbons, generally boils below 170° Fahr., and is more inflammable than safe kerosene. It is used as a solvent, as a carburetant for air gas, and for illumination in special lamps.
a petroleum fraction boiling 75°-125°C used as a solvent and fuel

A process on the elytra of certain beetles. See elytral .—

In anatomy , a band of white nervous substance bordering the membranous covering of the posterior part of the fourth ventricle of the brain on each side, and extending from the clava to the striæ acusticæ, where it winds around the restiform bodies. Also called tænia ventriculi quarti, ala pontis , and ponticulus.

[ capitalized ] A genus of simple cestoid worms, type of the family Ligulidæ , having an unsegmented elongated body with two lateral depressions at the head end, and numerous sets of sexual organs in longitudinal series opening on the median line of the body. These endoparasites inhabit fishes and amphibians, and acquire their matured character in water-birds.
The central process, or front edge, of the labium of insects. It sometimes serves as a tongue or proboscis, as in bees.

a furnace used to produce lime from limestone
a kiln used to reduce naturally occurring forms of calcium carbonate to lime

limelight.explanation: An early type of stage light in which lime was heated to incandescence producing brilliant illumination.
The brilliant white light so produced.
Same as calcium light (which see, under calcium ).

That part of the stage upon which the limelight is cast, usually where the most important action is progressing or where the leading player or players are placed and upon which the attention of the spectators is therefore concentrated.
A type of stage lighting once used in theatres and music halls , producing a bright light by the use of incandescent quicklime .
Attention , notice , a starring or central role , present fame .
a lamp consisting of a flame directed at a cylinder of lime with a lens to concentrate the light; formerly used for stage lighting

limen.explanation: The point at which a stimulus is strong enough to produce a physiological or psychological response.
In experimental psychology and psychophysics , the threshold; the dividing line between noticeableness and unnoticeableness of stimulus.
In anatomy , the portion of brain-substance situated between the base and the island of Reil.
a threshhold, especially the point where a psychological or physiological effect begins to occur.

limequat.explanation: A citrus tree, a cross between a lime and a kumquat

limer.explanation: Someone who limes ; someone who uses bird-lime or who limewashes .
A kind of dog kept on a lead ; a bloodhound ; a mongrel .
Someone who hangs around the streets; someone hanging out .

limerick.explanation: A light humorous, nonsensical, or bawdy verse of five usually anapestic lines with the rhyme scheme aabba, in which the first, second, and fifth lines are in trimeter, and the third and fourth lines are in dimeter.
A nonsense song or verse, one of a series of impromptu productions of a free character, sung at convivial parties in Ireland.
A nonsense verse of a fixed type, more or less amusing, of the pattern of those written by Edward Lear in his “Book of Nonsense.” See Learic . The following is an example:
A humorous, often nonsensical, and sometimes risqé poem of five anapestic lines, of which lines 1, 2, and 5 are of three feet, and rhyme, and lines 3 and 4 are of two feet, and rhyme.
A humorous , often bawdy verse of five anapestic lines, with the rhyme scheme aabba, and typically has a 9-9-6-6-9 cadence .
a humorous verse form of 5 anapestic lines with a rhyme scheme aabba

limes.explanation: A fortified boundary or border, especially of the Roman Empire.
In anatomy , one of two distinct tracts of the lateral root of the olfactory lobe of the brain, distinguished as limes alba and limes cinerca.
In zoology , a boundary; a line of division or separation between two parts or organs.

limestone.explanation: A common sedimentary rock consisting mostly of calcium carbonate, CaCO 3 , used as a building stone and in the manufacture of lime, carbon dioxide, and cement.

A limestone in the New York series of formations, originally called the Scutella and Upper Pentamerus limestones of the Lower Helderberg group of strata. It belongs to the lowest or Helderbergian division of the Lower Devonian, lying near the top, beneath the Port Ewen beds and above the New Scotland limestone. It abounds in fossil remains, and from its purity is highly esteemed both as a construction stone and as a flux in smelting.

A division of the Lower Silurian of New York State and the adjoining regions, originally termed by Eaton the “ Calciferous sandrock. ” It is regarded as the lowest member of the Lower Silurian, resting on and graduating by easy changes from the Potsdam sandstone beneath. The rock in northern New York and the Lake Champlain basin is largely a limestone, at times magnesian, and carries a profuse and highly interesting marine fauna. In the Mohawk valley the beds are almost devoid of organic remains, are highly dolomitic, and have been locally designated as the Little Falls dolomite.
Rock consisting wholly or in large part of calcareous material or carbonate of lime.

A rock consisting chiefly of calcium carbonate or carbonate of lime. It sometimes contains also magnesium carbonate, and is then called magnesian or dolomitic limestone . Crystalline limestone is called marble .
An abundant rock of marine and fresh-water sediments ; primarily composed of calcite (CaCO₃); it occurs in a variety of forms, both crystalline and amorphous .
a sedimentary rock consisting mainly of calcium that was deposited by the remains of marine animals

limettin.explanation: A colorless compound, contained in the ethereal oil of Citrus limetta. It crystallizes in small prisms or needles melting at 147.5° C.

limewash.explanation: A mixture of slaked lime in water .
To paint with limewash ( slaked lime in water ).

limewater.explanation: A clear colorless alkaline aqueous solution of calcium hydroxide, used in calamine lotion and other skin preparations and sometimes as an antacid.
A saturated aqueous solution of lime.
Water impregnated with lime; esp., an artificial solution of lime for medicinal purposes.
a solution of calcium hydroxide in water , used as a simple test for carbon dioxide , and in skin preparations
solution of calcium hydroxide in water used as an antacid

limewood.explanation: The wood of the lime tree.

limewort.explanation: An old name of the catch-fly, Silene Armeria , and of one or two other plants.

limey.explanation: Of, or pertaining to, limes (the fruit).
An Englishman or other Briton , or a person of British descent.

limicolae.explanation: term used in some classifications for migratory shorebirds; coextensive with the Charadrii

limicoline.explanation: Of or relating to shorebirds, especially the plovers, sandpipers, and phalaropes.
Limicolæ , in either sense of that word. It is a common epithet of the large group of birds known as shore-birds, bay-snipe , etc.
In ornithology , a member of the Limicolæ.
Shore-inhabiting; of or pertaining to the Limicolæ.
Shore-dwelling, usually said of certain wading birds, such as snipes and plovers .

limiest.explanation: superlative form of limey : most limey .

liminal.explanation: Intermediate between two states, conditions, or regions; transitional or indeterminate.
Existing at the limen. Used of stimuli.
psychophysics , pertaiuing to the stimulus limen or differential limen. See limen .
of or pertaining to a limen, especially a sensory threshhold.
Pertaining to a threshold or entrance .
Relating to a beginning or first stage of a process; inceptive ; inchoative ; marginal ; insignificant .

liminess.explanation: The state or quality of being limy.
The state or quality of being limy .

liming.explanation: The operation of treating with lime, or of sprinkling with slaked lime; in leather manufacturing , the steeping of hides in a solution of lime to remove their hair.
In bleaching , a solution of lime in water.
The smearing of twigs with lime to catch birds; bird-liming.
hanging around, usually in a public place with friends, enjoying the scene.

limit.explanation: The point, edge, or line beyond which something ends, may not go, or is not allowed.
The boundary surrounding a specific area; bounds.
Something that restricts or restrains; a restraint.
The greatest or least amount, number, or extent allowed or possible.
The largest amount which may be bet at one time in games of chance.
A number or point L that is approached by a function f(x) as x approaches a if, for every positive number ε, there exists a number δ such that | f(x)−L | < ε if | x−a | < δ.
A number or point L that is approached by a sequence b n if, for every positive number ε, there exists a number N such that | b n −L | < ε if n > N .
One that is intolerable, remarkable, or extreme in some other way.
To confine or restrict with a limit.
limiting friar.
Inpoker , an amount, agreed upon before play begins, by which any one player may increase his bet over that of another. Sometimes called the raise.
A definite terminal or border line; a boundary; that which bounds or circumscribes in a material manner; as, the northern limit of a field or town; the limits of a country.

A terminal line or point in general; the extent or reach beyond which continuity ceases; a fixed term or bound as to amount, supply, continuance, inclusion, or the like: used of both material and immaterial things: as, to reach the limit of one's resources; the limit of vision or of resistance; to set limits to one's ambition.
That which is within or defined by limits; confine; district; region.
A logical term. See the quotation.
In mathematics , the precise boundary between two continuous regions of magnitude or quantity; especially, the point at which a variable upon which some function depends passes through infinity.
A limb, as a limit or extremity of the body.
Synonyms Confine, termination, bourn, precinct, boundary, frontier (see boundary ); restriction, restraint, check.
To apply a limit to, or set a limit for; to terminate, circumscribe, or restrict, by a limit or limits
those parallels of latitude between which only an occultation of a star or planet by the moon, in a given case, can occur.
That which terminates, circumscribes, restrains, or confines; the bound, border, or edge; the utmost extent
The space or thing defined by limits.
That which terminates a period of time; hence, the period itself; the full time or extent.
A restriction; a check; a curb; a hindrance.
A determining feature; a distinguishing characteristic; a differentia.

A determinate quantity, to which a variable one continually approaches, and may differ from it by less than any given difference, but to which, under the law of variation, the variable can never become exactly equivalent.
See under Elastic .
a definite, extent of space in or around a prison, within which a prisoner has liberty to go and come.
To beg, or to exercise functions, within a certain limited region.
To restrict; not to allow to go beyond a certain bound.
To have a limit in a particular set.
To beg , or to exercise functions , within a certain limited region.
A restriction; a bound beyond which one may not go.

A value to which a sequence converges . Equivalently, the common value of the upper limit and the lower limit of a sequence: if the upper and lower limits are different, then the sequence has no limit (i.e., does not converge).
Any of several abstractions of this concept of limit.

Given diagram F : J → C, a cone (L, φ) from L ∈ Ob(C) to F is the limit of F if it has the universal property that for any other cone (N, ψ) from N ∈ Ob(C) to F there is a unique morphism u : N → L such that for all X ∈ Ob(J), .
Short for fixed limit .
The final , utmost , or furthest point .
Being a fixed limit game.
the greatest possible degree of something
final or latest limiting point
the greatest amount of something that is possible or allowed
as far as something can go
restrict or confine,
place limits on (extent or access)
decide upon or fix definitely

limitarian.explanation: One who limits; in theology , one who holds that a part of the human race only are to be saved: opposed to universalist.

limitary.explanation: Of or relating to a limit or boundary.
That which constitutes a limit or boundary, as a stretch of land; a border-land.
Placed at the limit, as a guard.
Confined within limits; limited in extent, authority, power, etc.
Limiting, or tending to limit; restrictive.
That which serves to limit; a boundary; border land.
Of or pertaining to a limit or boundary

limitate.explanation: botany , bounded by a distinct line, as the hypothallus in some lichens.

limitation.explanation: The act of limiting or the state of being limited.
A limiting rule or condition; a restriction.
A shortcoming or defect.
A period established by statute during which a lawsuit or criminal prosecution must be initiated.
The act of bounding or circumscribing; the fixing of a limit or restriction.
The condition of being limited, bounded, or circumscribed; restriction.
An opposing limit or bound; a fixed or prescribed restriction; a restraining condition, defining circumstance, or qualifying conception: as, limitations of thought.
That to which one is limited; that which is required as a condition.

In law: The period of time prescribed by law after which an action cannot be brought. Since the investigation of controversies becomes more difficult with the lapse of time, and long delay to sue may imply either that satisfaction has been received or that all claim is abandoned, and as it is vexatious to revive stale claims, the law allows fixed periods, varying with the nature of the grievance, within which, if at all, a claimant must apply to the courts.

In the law of conveyancing, the carving out of an estate less than a fee simple absolute (see fee ); the prescribing of an ulterior direction for the devolution of an estate in case the estate of the primary grantee shall fail.
The particular district in which a limiter or begging friar was allowed to beg for alms.
The act of limiting; the state or condition of being limited.
That which limits; a restriction; a qualification; a restraining condition, defining circumstance, or qualifying conception.
A certain precinct within which friars were allowed to beg, or exercise their functions; also, the time during which they were permitted to exercise their functions in such a district.
A limited time within or during which something is to be done.
A certain period limited by statute after which the claimant shall not enforce his claims by suit.
A settling of an estate or property by specific rules.
A restriction of power.
to know the reach and limits of one's abilities.
The act of limiting or the state of being limited .
A restriction ; a boundary , real or metaphorical, caused by some thing or some circumstance.
An imperfection or shortcoming which limits somethings use or value.
A time period after which some legal action may no longer be brought .
the quality of being limited or restricted
(law) a time period after which suits cannot be brought
the greatest amount of something that is possible or allowed
a principle that limits the extent of something
an act of limiting or restricting (as by regulation)

limited.explanation: Confined or restricted within certain limits.
Not attaining the highest goals or achievement.
Having only mediocre talent or range of ability.
Having governmental or ruling powers restricted by enforceable limitations, as a constitution or a legislative body.
Of or relating to a limited company.
Of, relating to, or being transportation facilities, such as trains or buses, that make few stops and carry relatively few passengers.
A limited train or bus.
railroading , restricted as to number of cars (weight), or to the carrying of first-class passengers: said of a train.
A limited express-train: as, the Chicago limited.
Confined within limits; narrow; circumscribed; restricted.
a company in which the liability of each shareholder is limited by the number of shares he has taken, so that he can not be called on to contribute beyond the amount of his shares.
Simple past tense and past participle of limit .
With certain (often specified) limits placed upon it.
having a specific function or scope
mediocre
not unlimited
including only a part
small in range or scope
public transport consisting of a fast train or bus that makes only a few scheduled stops
subject to limits or subjected to limits
not excessive

limiter.explanation: A circuit that prevents the amplitude of a waveform from exceeding a specified value.
One who or that which limits or confines.
A friar licensed to beg, collect convent-dues, preach, or perform other duties within certain limits, or in a certain district.
One who, or that which, limits.
A friar licensed to beg within certain bounds, or whose duty was limited to a certain district.
(electronics) a nonlinear electronic circuit whose output is limited in amplitude; used to limit the instantaneous amplitude of a waveform (to clip off the peaks of a waveform)

limiting.explanation: Restricting the range of application of the noun modified.
strictly limiting the reference of a modified word or phrase
restricting the scope or freedom of action
the grammatical relation that exists when a word qualifies the meaning of the phrase

limitless.explanation: Having no limit or limits; unrestricted.
Without limits in extent , size , quantity , and/or comprehensive perception ; boundless
having no limits in range or scope
seemingly boundless in amount, number, degree, or especially extent
without limits in extent or size or quantity

limitlessness.explanation: Property of being limitless , infiniteness , boundlessness .
the quality of being infinite; without bound or limit

limitrophe.explanation: A bordering country; a frontier land.

limits.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of limit .

limivorous.explanation: Eating mud or soil for organic matter in it.

limma.explanation: In the Pythagorean system of music, the smaller half-step or semitone, being the remnant of a perfect fourth after subtracting from it two whole steps or “tones”: . A limma and an apotome together made a “tone”: . Also called Pythagorean semitone or hemitone.
In prosody , a monosemic empty time or pause; a time equal to one mora or semeion, existing in the rhythm, but not expressed by a syllable in the words.
Any of several small musical intervals , such as the semitone

limmer.explanation: A limehound; in general, a hound; in a later use, a mongrel hound.
Hence A low, base, or worthless person; a scoundrel; as applied to a woman, in a milder sense, a jade.
Nautical , a man-rope at the side of a ladder.
A mongrel, as a cross between the mastiff and hound.
A low, base fellow; also, a prostitute.
A man rope at the side of a ladder.
A rogue ; a low, base fellow.
A mongrel , such as a cross between the mastiff and hound .
A manrope at the side of a ladder .

limn.explanation: To describe or depict by painting or drawing.
To suffuse or highlight with light or color; illuminate.
To describe or portray in words.
To draw or paint; especially, to represent in an artistic way with pencil or brush.
To picture in words; to describe in graphic terms.
To illumine, as books or parchments, with ornamental figures, letters, or borders.

limnanthemum.explanation: A genus of plants of the order Gentianeæ and tribe Menyantheæ , distinguished by the indehiscent fruit and cordate leaves.

limnanthes.explanation: A genus of plants of the order Geraniaceæ , type of the tribe Limnantheæ , and distinguished from Flœrkea , the other genus of the tribe, by having five petals instead of three.

limned.explanation: described or represented in a lifelike manner
Simple past tense and past participle of limn .

limner.explanation: One who limns; an artist or delineator; more especially, one who paints portraits or miniatures.
a painter or drawer of portraits

limnetic.explanation: Of or occurring in the deeper, open waters of lakes or ponds.
Of or pertaining to the deeper , open waters of a lake etc.

limnetis.explanation: One of the three leading genera of Limnadiidæ (or Estheriidæ ), having a bivalve carapace, numerous body-segments, and the foliaceous appendages of typical phyllopods.

limnic.explanation: Of or pertaining to fresh water ; freshwater

limning.explanation: The act of delineating, as by means of pencil or brush.
That which is limned; a delineation, literally or figuratively.
The act, process, or art of one who limns; the picture or decoration so produced.
a drawing of the outlines of forms or objects

limnobiology.explanation: That branch of science which deals with the animals and plants which live in fresh water as contrasted with those of the ocean.

limnobios.explanation: The animals and plants of fresh water considered collectively and in contrast with the animals and plants of the ocean and those of the land.

limnocnida.explanation: A genus of fresh-water hydromedusans known only from Lake Tanganyika.

limnograph.explanation: An apparatus for keeping a continuous record of the height of water, especially in a lake. See limnometer .

limnological.explanation: Of or pertaining to limnology , the study of freshwater bodies of water

limnologically.explanation: with regard to or concerning limnology

limnologist.explanation: a specialist in the study of freshwater ponds and lakes

limnology.explanation: The scientific study of the life and phenomena of fresh water, especially lakes and ponds.
The scientific study of lakes and ponds, with especial reference to the organisms which live in them.
the scientific study of bodies of fresh water for their biological and physical and geological properties.
The science concerning the biological , physical and geological properties of fresh water bodies , especially lakes and ponds .
the scientific study of bodies of fresh water for their biological and physical and geological properties

limnometer.explanation: A form of tide-gage, first devised by Forel and Sarasin for recording small oscillations in Swiss lakes and applied by Nakamura and Yoshida to tidal oscillations in Japanese harbors; specifically, Sarasin's limnometer of 1901, which is properly a limnograph (which see).

limnophilid.explanation: A member of the trichopterous family Limnophilidæ.

limnophilous.explanation: Loving or having an affinity towards lakes .

limnoplankton.explanation: The floating and swimming organisms of fresh water, considered collectively and as contrasted with the floating and swimming fauna and flora of the ocean, or haliplankton. See haliplankton .

limnoria.explanation: The typical genus of Limnoriidæ. L. lignorum or terebrans is the common gribble, a minute isopod highly injurious to submerged woodwork.

limns.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of limn .

limo.explanation: large luxurious car; usually driven by a chauffeur

limodorum.explanation: A genus of orchidaceous plants of the tribe Neottieæ , type of the subtribe Limodoreæ.

limoncillo.explanation: In Porto Eico, any one of several trees of the myrtle family, especially Pimenta racemosa , from the leaves of which is distilled the oil used for making bay-rum.

In the southwestern United States and Mexico, any one of several species of Pectis , especially P. papposa, P. diffusa , and P. uniaristata , small, yellow-flowered composites, with linear glandular-dotted leaves, and a strong odor of lemon. In many localities these plants are used for making beverages and are administered in the form of decoctions as a remedy for fever and ague and for other maladies. Also called lemonweed and romerillo.

limoncito.explanation: In the Philippine Islands, Guam, and on the west coast of Mexico, the orangeberry, Triphasia trifoliata , a shrub with glossy, dark-green, trifoliate leaves, white flowers with the fragrance of hyacinth, and globular berries of an orange-scarlet color filled with a somewhat gummy, bitter-sweet pulp, which has the flavor of curaçao liqueur. The plants send up many shoots from the root and form dense thickets if undisturbed. They are much used for hedges, and from the fruit marmalade and jelly are made, of an orange-like flavor, but having a constipating effect if eaten in any quantity. Also called limoncito de China and lemoncito.

limonene.explanation: A liquid terpenoid, C 10 H 16 , with a characteristic lemonlike fragrance, used as a solvent, wetting agent, and dispersing agent and in the manufacture of resins.
A general term applied to certain terpenes, C 10 H 16 .
a liquid terpene with a lemon odor; found in lemons and oranges and other essential oils.
A monoterpene hydrocarbon 1-methyl-4-prop-1-en-2-yl-cyclohexene found in the essential oils of oranges , lemons and similar fruit, and mainly responsible for their fragrance
a liquid terpene with a lemon odor; found in lemons and oranges and other essential oils

limoniad.explanation: A nymph of the meadows; -- called also Limniad .

limonin.explanation: A bitter crystallizable matter (C 22 H 50 O 13 ) found in the seeds of oranges, lemons, etc.
A bitter, white, crystalline substance found in orange and lemon seeds.
A limonoid found in orange and lemon seeds .

limonite.explanation: Any of a group of widely occurring yellowish-brown to black iron oxide minerals, essentially FeO(OH) · n H 2 O, used as a minor ore of iron.
An important iron ore which is found earthy, concretionary, or mammillary and fibrous.

Hydrous sesquioxide of iron, an important ore of iron, occurring in stalactitic, mammillary, or earthy forms, of a dark brown color, and yellowish brown powder. It includes bog iron. Also called brown hematite .
any of several natural hydrous iron oxides ; often a mixture of goethite and hemite with clays and manganese oxide
a widely occurring iron oxide ore; a mixture of goethite and hematite and lepidocrocite

limonitization.explanation: In petrography , the change of a mineral or rock into limonite.

limonium.explanation: A genus of dicotyledonous plants of the family Plumbaginaceæ.

limosa.explanation: A genus of wading birds of the family Scolopacidæ , having the bill a little recurved; the godwits.

limosella.explanation: A genus of small creeping or floating herbs of the order Scrophularineæ and tribe Gratioleæ , characterized by having the leaves in clusters, the calyx 5-toothed, and the 4 stamens with the anthers confluently 1-celled.

limousine.explanation: Any of various large passenger vehicles, especially a luxurious automobile usually driven by a chauffeur and sometimes having a partition separating the passenger compartment from the driver's seat.
A van or small bus used to carry passengers on a regular route, as between an airport and a downtown area.
A cloak of goats' hair or coarse wool worn by peasants and wagon-drivers.
A type of automobile body, in which the rear seats are inclosed by fixed sides, back, and top.
an elongated, luxurious automobile, designed to be driven by a chauffeur and often having a glass partition between the driver's seat and the passengers' compartment behind.
An automobile body with seats and permanent top like a coupe , and with the top projecting over the driver and a projecting front
An automobile with such a body.
A luxury sedan / saloon car, especially one with a lengthened wheelbase or driven by a chauffeur .
large luxurious car; usually driven by a chauffeur

limp.explanation: To walk lamely, especially with irregularity, as if favoring one leg.
To move or proceed haltingly or unsteadily.
An irregular, jerky, or awkward gait.
Lacking or having lost rigidity, as of structure or substance.
Lacking strength, vigor, or effectiveness; weak.
limping argument; limping verses.
A halting step; the act of limping.
A scraper of board or sheet-iron shaped like half the head of a small cask, used for scraping the ore off the sieve in the operation of hand-jigging.
A halt; the act of limping.
To halt; to walk lamely. Also used figuratively.
A scraper for removing poor ore or refuse from the sieve.
Flaccid; flabby, as flesh.
Lacking stiffness; flimsy.
To happen ; befall ; chance .
To come upon; meet .
flaccid ; flabby , as flesh .
lacking stiffness ; flimsy ; as, a limp cravat.
not erect
not having an erect penis
physically weak
To be inadequate or unsatisfactory .
A scraper of board or sheet-iron shaped like half the head of a small cask, used for scraping the ore off the sieve in the operation of hand-jigging.
To walk lamely , as if favouring one leg .
To travel with a malfunctioning system of propulsion
To call .
An irregular , jerky or awkward gait
A scraper for removing poor ore or refuse from the sieve
not firm
proceed slowly or with difficulty
the uneven manner of walking that results from an injured leg
lacking in strength or firmness or resilience
walk impeded by some physical limitation or injury

limped.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of limp .

limper.explanation: One who limps; a lame person.
comparative form of limp : more limp
someone who has a limp and walks with a hobbling gait

limpest.explanation: superlative form of limp : most limp .

limpet.explanation: Any of numerous marine gastropod mollusks that have a conical shell and often adhere to rocks in intertidal areas, especially those of the order Patellogastropoda.
A type of explosive designed to cling to the hull of a ship and detonate on contact or signal.
A marine docoglossate gastropod with an open conical shell imperforate at the apex.
Some mollusk resembling the foregoing, at least in shape of the shell.
In a general sense, any hatshaped, or conical, gastropod shell.
Any one of many species of marine shellfish of the order Docoglossa, mostly found adhering to rocks, between tides.
Somthing or someone that clings tenaciously to another object or person
Any species of Siphonaria, a genus of limpet-shaped Pulmonifera, living between tides, on rocks.
A small mollusc , of the family Patellidae with a conical shell found clinging to rocks in the intertidal zones of rocky shores.
Someone dependant ; someone disregarding or ignorant of another's personal space .
mollusk with a low conical shell
any of various usually marine gastropods with low conical shells; found clinging to rocks in littoral areas

limpid.explanation: Characterized by transparent clearness; pellucid. synonym : clear .
Characterized by clearness or transparency; clear.
Clear and unambiguous; lucid; easy to understand; -- of speech and writing.
Calm, untroubled, and without worry; serene.
transmitting light; able to be seen through with clarity

limpidity.explanation: The quality or state of being limpid.
free from obscurity and easy to understand; the comprehensibility of clear expression
passing light without diffusion or distortion

limpidly.explanation: in a clear and lucid manner

limpidness.explanation: The state of being limpid; clearness; transparency; lucidity.
The property of being limpid , clarity .

limping.explanation: disability of walking due to crippling of the legs or feet

limpingly.explanation: In a limping manner; with a limp.

limpkin.explanation: A large brownish wading bird (Aramus guarauna) of warm, swampy regions of Florida, the Caribbean islands, and Central and South America, having long legs, a curved bill, and a distinctive wailing call.
A local (Florida) name of the crying-bird or courlan, Aramus giganteus. See courlan, Aramus.

Either one of two species of wading birds of the genus Aramus, intermediate between the cranes and rails. The limpkins are remarkable for the great length of the toes. One species ( Aramus giganteus ) inhabits Florida and the West Indies; the other ( Aramus scolopaceus ) is found in South America. Called also courlan , and crying bird .
A large bird, Aramus guarauna, found in marshes in the Caribbean , Central America and southern Florida .
wading bird of Florida, Cuba and Jamaica having a drooping bill and a distinctive wailing call

limply.explanation: In a limp manner, without support or resistance.

limpness.explanation: The quality of being limp or flaccid; weak pliancy.
The quality or state of being limp.

limps.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of limp .

limu.explanation: Throughout Polynesia, a generic name for mosses and seaweeds.
The Hawaiian name for seaweeds. Over sixty kinds are used as food, and have species names, as Limu Lipoa , Limu palawai , etc.
Hawaiian algae , an important part of the ancient Hawaiian diet

limuloid.explanation: Limulus ; related to or resembling a limulus; pœcilopodous; merostomatous; xiphurous.
A limuloid crustacean; a pœcilopod, merostome, or xiphure.

limuloidea.explanation: An order of Merostomata, including among living animals the genus Limulus, with various allied fossil genera, mostly of the Carboniferous period. Called also Xiphosura .

limulus.explanation: [ lowercase ] Any crustacean of the genus Limulus.

a characteristic language of a particular group (as among thieves)

tart red berries similar to American cranberries but smaller

An articulation pronounced by the aid or use of the tongue and teeth .

lingual.explanation: Of, relating to, or situated near the tongue or a tonguelike organ.

t , d , etc. (also called dental ), or especially to the peculiar Sanskrit t, d , etc. (also called cacuminal, cerebral ), forming a distinct class from the Sanskrit dentals, and pronounced with the tip of the tongue drawn back.
lingual corruptions of words or language.
A letter pronounced in the manner described in I., 2.

Of or pertaining to the tongue; uttered by the aid of the tongue; glossal

lying near the tongue; especially, in dentistry, on the surface of the tooth next to the tongue. Contrasted with buccal , the side of a tooth touching the cheek, i. e. the side opposite to the lingual side.

Related to the tongue .
Related to language or linguistics .
articulated with the tongue
Of a lower tooth , on the side facing the tongue. See mesial .
a sound articulated with the tongue

a consonant that is produced with the tongue and other speech organs
consisting of or related to language

linguale.explanation: The bone of the tongue, more fully called os linguæ or os linguale ; the hyoid bone, or os hyoides. See hyoid , n.

lingualis.explanation: The proper muscle of the tongue; the muscular substance of the tongue which is not definitively attached to surrounding bony parts.

lingually.explanation: In a lingual manner, relating to language or linguistics .

linguatula.explanation: A genus of worm-like entoparasitic Arachnida , remarkable among air-breathing arthropods in having the appendages reduced to two pairs of minute hooks.

linguatulina.explanation: Linguatulidæ , related to the mites or acarids, bear-animalcules or Arctisca , and Pycnogonida ; the tonguelets, tongueworms, or fivemouths.
An order of wormlike, degraded, parasitic arachnids. They have two pairs of retractile hooks, near the mouth. Called also Pentastomida .

linguiform.explanation: Having the form of the tongue; tongue-shaped.

linguine.explanation: Pasta in long, flat, thin strands.

linguist.explanation: A person who speaks several languages fluently.

A master of the use of language; a talker.
A human translator ; an interpreter , especially in the armed forces .
a person who speaks more than one language

linguister.explanation: A dabbler in linguistics; a student of philology; a linguist.

linguistic.explanation: Of or relating to language or linguistics.

consisting of or related to language
of or relating to the scientific study of language

linguistics.explanation: The study of the nature, structure, and variation of language, including phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, sociolinguistics, and pragmatics.

The science of languages, or of the origin, signification, and application of words; glossology.
the humanistic study of language and literature

lingula.explanation: A little tongue or tongue-like part or process; a ligula.
In zoology : [ capitalized ] The typical genus of Lingulidæ.
Pl. lingulas (-läz). Any species of the genus Lingula or family Lingulidæ ; a lingulid or tongue-shell.
Any one of numerous species of brachiopod shells belonging to the genus Lingula, and related genera. See Brachiopoda , and Illustration in Appendix.
a group of strata in the lower Silurian or Cambrian system of Wales, in which some of the layers contain vast numbers of a species of Lingula.
Any of several tongue - shaped bony structures, especially that which forms the anterior border of the mandibular foramen .

lingulate.explanation: Shaped like the tongue or a strap; ligulate.
In the shape of a tongue

lingulella.explanation: A genus of atrematous brachiopods having a linguloid form and characterized by a more or less elevated ventral cardinal area which is bisected medially by a narrow pedicel-furrow. It occurs in the Cambrian of North America and Europe.

linguopalatal.explanation: A sound or letter produced by the tongue and palate.

linhay.explanation: An open shed attached to a farm-yard.

linie.explanation: The twelfth part of the zoll or inch; a line.

a medicinal liquid that is rubbed into the skin to relieve muscular stiffness and pain

linin.explanation: The crystallizable bitter principle of Linum catharticum , or purging-flax.

lining.explanation: A covering or coating for an inside surface.

The covering of the inner surface of anything, as of a garment, a box, a wall, or the like.
Specifically— In milit. engin. , a wooden sheeting to support the top and sides of the galleries and the sides of the shafts of a mine.
In carpentry , the inside boarding, or the felt fabric, paper, or other material, put on the inside of walls, floors, partitions, etc.

In a figurative use, contents.
The jacket of a steam-boiler or -cylinder: an inverted use.
In marble-working , the process of cementing back to back with plaster of Paris two pieces of marble, so that they can be ground on two or on all four faces, as if they were one piece.
The act of one who lines; the act or process of making lines, or of inserting a lining.
That which covers the inner surface of anything, as of a garment or a box; also, the contents of anything.

Present participle of line .
the act of attaching an inside lining (to a garment or curtain etc.)
providing something with a surface of a different material
a protective covering that protects an inside surface
a piece of cloth that is used as the inside surface of a garment

link.explanation: One of the rings or loops forming a chain.
A unit in a connected series of units.
A unit in a transportation or communications system.
A connecting element; a tie or bond.
An association; a relationship.
A causal, parallel, or reciprocal relationship; a correlation.
A cufflink.
A unit of length used in surveying, equal to 0.01 chain, 7.92 inches, or about 20.12 centimeters.
A rod or lever transmitting motion in a machine.
A graphical item or segment of text in a webpage or other electronic document that, when clicked, causes another webpage or section of the same webpage to be displayed.
To put together physically, as with links.
To connect, relate, or associate: synonym : join .
To make or have a link to (another webpage or electronic document).
To make a link in (a webpage or electronic document).
To be or become joined together physically.
To be or become connected, related, or associated.
To make or have a link to a webpage or electronic document.
To follow a link in a webpage or electronic document.
A torch formerly used for lighting one's way in the streets.

plural A stretch of flat or slightly undulating ground on the sea-shore, often in part sandy and covered with bent-grass, furze, etc., and sometimes with a good sward, on part of it at least.
plural The ground on which golf is played.
A torch made of tow or hards, etc., and pitch, carried for lighting the streets, formerly common in Great Britain, and still used in London in fogs.
plural The ground on which golf is played.
One of the rings or separate pieces of which a chain is composed. In ornamental chain-making, any member of the chain, of whatever form, as a plaque, a bead, etc., is called a link.
Anything doubled and closed together like a ring or division of a chain.
Anything which serves to connect one thing or one part of a thing with another; any constituent part of a connected series.
A division, forming the hundredth part, of the chain used in surveying and for other measurement.
One of the divisions of a sausage made in a continuous chain.
Any rigid movable piece connected with other pieces, generally themselves movable, by means of interlinked open ends or pivots about which it can turn.
In a steam-engine, the link-motion.

In zoology , specifically, an unknown hypothetical form of animal life in any evolutionary chain or series, assumed to have existed at some time and thus to have been the connecting-link between some known forms; especially, an anthropomorphic animal supposed to have been derived from some simian and to have been the immediate ancestral stock of the human race; hence, humorously, an ape or monkey taken as itself the connectinglink for which Darwinians seek. See Alalus .
In mathematics :
A piece of a straight line joining two given points.
A double tangent.
In music , a connecting passage of one or more measures, intervening between two well-defined sections or phrases.
A torch made of tow and pitch, or the like.
A hill or ridge, as a sand hill, or a wooded or turfy bank between cultivated fields, etc.
A winding of a river; also, the ground along such a winding; a meander; -- usually in pl.

A system of interconnected machine elements, such as rods, springs, and pivots, used to transmit power or motion.
A measure of the induced voltage in a circuit caused by a magnetic flux and equal to the flux times the number of turns in the coil that surrounds it.
An association between two or more genes such that the traits they control tend to be inherited together.
In chem. , the hypothetical connection between two atoms. Same as bond , 11.
In electricity , the product obtained by-multiplying the magnetic flux through a coil by the number of turns which the coil contains.
A system of connected links; a combination of pieces pivoted together so as to turn about one another in parallel planes of rotation.
The state of being linked together.
a linkage which has one, two, etc., degrees of freedom more than a complete linkage.
The act of linking; the state of being linked; also, a system of links.
Manner of linking or of being linked; -- said of the union of atoms or radicals in the molecule.
A system of straight lines or bars, fastened together by joints, and having certain of their points fixed in a plane. It is used to describe straight lines and curves in the plane.
Any object, factor, or relationship that creates a bond or association between two other objects.

The proximity of two or more genes on the genome of an organism that causes those genes to be inherited, transferred, or moved together with a frequency greater than for genes not associated. The linkage is a continuous variable, and is inversely related to the distance between genes on the genome.
A mechanical device that connects things.
A connection or relation between things or ideas.
The property of genes of being inherited together.
A set of definitely related words for which no proto-language can be derived.
an associative relation
a mechanical system of rods or springs or pivots that transmits power or motion
the act of linking things together
(genetics) traits that tend to be inherited together as a consequence of an association between their genes; all of the genes of a given chromosome are linked (where one goes they all go)

male servant or other attendant (regardless of age), employed to bear a torch or other light abroad at night

Any one of several species of fringilline birds of the genera Linota, Acanthis, and allied genera, esp. the common European species ( Linota cannabina ), which, in full summer plumage, is chestnut brown above, with the breast more or less crimson. The feathers of its head are grayish brown, tipped with crimson. Called also gray linnet , red linnet , rose linnet , brown linnet , lintie , lintwhite , gorse thatcher , linnet finch , and greater redpoll . The American redpoll linnet ( Acanthis linaria ) often has the crown and throat rosy. See redpoll , and twite .

A small passerine bird, Carduelis cannabina in the finch family Fringillidae that derives its scientific name from its fondness for hemp, and its English name from its liking for seeds of flax, from which linen is made.

Of, or derived from linoleum , or linseed oil

designating an organic fatty acid , a thin yellow oil, found combined as an ester of glycerol in oils of linseed, poppy , hemp , and certain nuts ; it is a polyunsaturated fatty acid with 18 carbon atoms and two double bonds .

[ capitalized ] [NL.] A genus of Viverridæ , now commonly called Prionodon .

Any viverrine mammal of the genus Prionodon, inhabiting the East Indies and Southern Asia. The common East Indian linsang ( Prionodon gracilis ) is white, crossed by broad, black bands. The Guinea linsang ( Porana Richardsonii ) is brown with black spots.
Any of the members of two superficially catlike animal species classified in the mammalian subfamily Prionodontinae.

the seed of flax used as a source of oil

a stick about a meter long with a point on one end (to stick in the ground) and a forked head on the other end (to hold a lighted match); formerly used to fire cannons

The mass of soft fibers surrounding the seeds of unginned cotton.

Raw cotton that has been ginned and is ready for baling.

A horizontal member spanning an opening, and carrying the superincumbent weight by means of its strength in resisting crosswise fracture.

horizontal beam used as a finishing piece over a door or window

A corrupt dialectal form of lean-to .

The short fibres that cling to cottonseeds after the first ginning.

linum.explanation: A genus of dicotyledonous polypetalous plants, of the natural order Lineæ , tribe Eulineæ.

a herbaceous plant genus of the family Linaceae with small sessile leaves

lion.explanation: A large carnivorous feline mammal (Panthera leo) of Africa and northwest India, having a short tawny coat, a tufted tail, and, in the male, a heavy mane around the neck and shoulders.
A mountain lion.
A very brave person.
A person regarded as fierce or savage.
A noted person; a celebrity.
( lion's share ) The greatest or best part.
A silver and a gold coin of the Belgian provinces, struck in 1790. The value of the gold lion was about $6.50.

A quadruped of the genus Felis, F. leo , the largest of all carnivorous animals, distinguished by its tawny or yellow color, a full flowing mane in the male, a tufted tail, and the disappearance of the feline markings in both sexes before they arrive at maturity.
Figuratively, a lion-like person; a man possessing the courage, fierceness, etc., of a lion.
[ capitalized ] In astronomy , a constellation and sign of the zodiac. See Leo , 1.
In heraldry , a representation of a lion used as a bearing.
A gold coin current in Scotland from the time of Robert III. to the reign of James VI.: so called from the lion on the obverse of the coin.
A copper coin: same as hardhead , 2.

An object of interest and curiosity; especially, a celebrated or conspicuous person who is much sought by society or by the public in general: as, to visit the lions of the place; such a one is the lion of the day.
An imaginary danger, trumped up by cowardice or sloth.
Any humble friend or follower who acts as a sycophant or foil to another.

A large carnivorous feline mammal ( Panthera leo , formerly Felis leo ), found in Southern Asia and in most parts of Africa, distinct varieties occurring in the different countries. The adult male, in most varieties, has a thick mane of long shaggy hair that adds to his apparent size, which is less than that of the largest tigers. The length, however, is sometimes eleven feet to the base of the tail. The color is a tawny yellow or yellowish brown; the mane is darker, and the terminal tuft of the tail is black. In one variety, called the maneless lion , the male has only a slight mane.
A sign and a constellation; Leo.
An object of interest and curiosity, especially a person who is so regarded.
the puma or cougar.
the ant-lion.
a fancy dog with a flowing mane, usually clipped to resemble a lion's mane.
the basilisk.
all, or nearly all; the best or largest part; -- from Æsop's fable of the lion hunting in company with certain smaller beasts, and appropriating to himself all the prey.

a famous sculptured lion at Lucerne, Switzerland, designed by Thorwaldsen and dedicated in 1821 as a memorial to the Swiss Guards who fell defending Louis XVI. in the attack of the mob on the Tuileries, Aug. 10, 1792. The animal, which is hewn out of the face of a rock, is represented as transfixed with a broken spear and dying, but still trying to protect with its paw a shield bearing the fleur-de-lis of France.

a winged lion, the emblem of the evangelist Mark, especially that of bronze surmounting a granite column in the Piazzetta at Venice, and holding in its fore paws an open book representing St. Mark's Gospel.
Gustavus Adolphus (1594-1632), King of Sweden, the hero of the Protestant faith in the Thirty Years' War.

A big cat , Panthera leo , native to Africa , India and formerly to much of Europe . The term may apply to the species as a whole, to individuals , or to male individuals. It also applies to related species like mountain lions .
A stylized representation of a large cat, used on a coat of arms .
A Chinese foo dog .
An individual who shows strength and courage , attributes associated with the lion.
A famous person.
large gregarious predatory feline of Africa and India having a tawny coat with a shaggy mane in the male
(astrology) a person who is born while the sun is in Leo
a celebrity who is lionized (much sought after)
the fifth sign of the zodiac; the sun is in this sign from about July 23 to August 22

lionfish.explanation: Any of various colorful scorpionfishes chiefly of the genera Pterois and Dendrochirus, native to the Pacific and Indian Oceans but introduced elsewhere, having a striped body with long pectoral fins and venomous spines in the dorsal fin.
Any of the venomous fish of the Pterois or Scorpaenidae family , notable for their long and separated spines
brightly striped fish of the tropical Pacific having elongated spiny fins

lionhood.explanation: The state of being a lion .

lionised.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lionise .

lionises.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of lionise .

lionism.explanation: The practice of lionizing; the treating of persons or things as lions in the figurative sense; the pursuit or adulation of celebrities. See lion , 6.
An attracting of attention, as a lion; also, the treating or regarding as a lion.
An attracting of attention , as a lion (celebrity); the treating or regarding as a lion.

lionization.explanation: The act of lionizing or making a ‘lion’ of some one.
The act of lionizing , the behavior that treats someone as a celebrity , either respectfully honoring or fawning adoration.

lionize.explanation: To look on or treat (a person) as a celebrity.
To treat or regard as a lion or object of great interest.
To show the lions or objects of interest to; to conduct about among objects of interest.
To treat (a person) as if he were important , or a celebrity .
To visit famous places in order to revere them.

lionized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lionize .

lionizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of lionize .

lionlike.explanation: Like a lion; brave as a lion.
Resembling a lion or some aspect of one.

lionship.explanation: The state of being a lion.
The state of being a lion , or famous person in society.

liothrix.explanation: A genus of turdiform passerine birds.

lip.explanation: Either of two fleshy folds that surround the opening of the mouth.
A structure or part that encircles or bounds an orifice, as.
A labium.
The margin of flesh around a wound.
Either of the margins of the aperture of a gastropod shell.
A rim, as of a vessel, bell, or crater.
One of the two divisions of a bilabiate corolla or calyx, as in the snapdragon, or the modified median petal of an orchid flower.
The tip of a pouring spout, as on a pitcher.
Insolent talk.
To touch the lips to.
To kiss.
To utter.
To lap or splash against.
To hit a golf ball so that it touches the edge of (the hole) without dropping in.
music , to apply one's lips to the mouthpiece of a metal wind-instrument so as to produce tones; also, to use one's lips in some particular manner: as, to lip well or badly.
machinery , to flange; turn over a lip on (a piece of sheet-metal).
In zoology : In the Blastoidea , one of the distal ends of the radial sinuses.
In the Gastropoda , the outer or thickened inner margin of the aperture of the shell.
In metallurgy , the part of a ladle or forehearth over which the metal flows.
One of the two edges or borders of the mouth; one of the two fleshy or muscular parts composing the opening of the mouth in man and many other animals, and covering the teeth.
plural Figuratively, the organs of speech as represented by the lips; speech or utterance as passing between the lips and aided by them.
Impudent or abusive talk.
Anything resembling a lip in position or relation; the edge or border of anything; a margin: as, the lip of a vessel; the lips of a wound.
In botany : Either of the divisions of a bilabiate corolla.
In orchids, one of the petals differing from the other two in shape. It is really the upper, but by a half-twist of the ovary has become as if anterior or lower.
In zoology , any lip-like part or organ. See labium and labrum for technical usages.
In a lip-auger, the blade at the end which cuts the chip after it has been circumscribed by the spur.
In a turbine water-wheel, a rim which closes the joint between the barrel and the curb.
In a vehicle, a projecting part of the bolster; a cuttoo-plate.
In organ-building , one of the flat vertical surfaces above or below the mouth of a flue-pipe, called respectively the upper lip and the lower lip.
In music , the power or facility of adjusting one's lips to the mouthpiece of a metal wind-instrument so as to produce tones; embouchure.
To touch with the lips; to put the lips to; hence, to kiss.
To utter; to speak.
To clip; to trim.

One of the two fleshy folds which surround the orifice of the mouth in man and many other animals. In man the lips are organs of speech essential to certain articulations. Hence, by a figure they denote the mouth, or all the organs of speech, and sometimes speech itself.
An edge of an opening; a thin projecting part of anything; a kind of short open spout.
The sharp cutting edge on the end of an auger.
One of the two opposite divisions of a labiate corolla.
One of the edges of the aperture of a univalve shell.
Impudent or abusive talk.
a pod auger. See Auger .
comfort that is given with words only.

lipa.explanation: A Croatian unit of currency equal to 1 / 100 of the kuna.
A subdivision of currency, equal to a 1/100th of a Croatian kuna

lipaciduria.explanation: The elimination of fatty acids in the urine.

lipaemia.explanation: In pathology , the presence of an excessive quantity of fat in the blood.
A condition in which fat occurs in the blood.
presence of excess lipids in the blood

liparian.explanation: Any species of a family ( Liparidæ ) of destructive bombycid moths, as the tussock moths.

liparid.explanation: A member of the lepidopterous family Liparidæ.

liparidae.explanation: A natural family including the snailfishes.

liparite.explanation: A name applied by Roth to the rock called rhyolite by Von Richthofen. See rhyolite .

lipase.explanation: Any of a group of enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of fats into glycerol and fatty acids.

A widely distributed ferment occurring in both the animal and the vegetable world, which splits fats into fatty acids and glycerin, is also capable of bringing about the synthesis of fats, and is thus reversible in its action. The synthetic activity of this ferment was first demonstrated by Kastle and Loeven-hart, and Hanriot.
Any of a group of enzymes which catalyses the hydrolysis of lipids .
an enzyme secreted in the digestive tract that catalyzes the breakdown of fats into individual fatty acids that can be absorbed into the bloodstream

lipectomy.explanation: Surgical excision of subcutaneous fatty tissue.
The surgical removal of fat from the body
plastic surgery involving the breakdown and removal of fatty tissue

lipemia.explanation: The presence of an abnormally high concentration of lipid in the blood. Called also hyperlipemia , hyperlipidemia , hyperlipoidemia , lipidemia , lipoidemia .
An excess of lipids in the blood
presence of excess lipids in the blood

lipemic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or suffering from lipemia

lipic.explanation: Pertaining to, or derived from, fat. The word was formerly used specifically to designate a supposed acid obtained by the oxidation of oleic acid, tallow, wax, etc.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fat .

lipid.explanation: Any of a group of organic compounds, including the fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and triglycerides, that are insoluble in water but soluble in nonpolar organic solvents, are oily to the touch, and together with carbohydrates and proteins constitute the principal structural material of living cells.

Any of a variety of oily or greasy organic compounds found as major structural components of living cells; they are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents such as alcohol and ether, and include the common fats , cholesterol and other steroids, phospholipids , sphingolipids , waxes , and fatty acids ; some of the lipids, together with proteins and carbohydrates, form an essential structural component of living cells, as in the cell walls and membranes. The term lipid refers to its solubility in nonpolar solvents, and has no significance with regard to chemical structure.

Any of a group of organic compounds including the fats , oils , waxes , sterols , and triglycerides . Lipids are characterized by being insoluble in water, and account for most of the fat present in the human body. They are, however, soluble in nonpolar organic solvents .
an oily organic compound insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents; essential structural component of living cells (along with proteins and carbohydrates)

lipide.explanation: an oily organic compound insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents; essential structural component of living cells (along with proteins and carbohydrates)

lipidic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the lipids

liplike.explanation: Resembling a lip or some aspect of one.
having lips or parts that resemble lips

lipobranchia.explanation: Arachnida , contrasted with Embolobranchia and Delobranchia , and composed of the weasel-spiders, harvestmen, false scorpions, and mites, or the four orders Galeodina, Opilionina, Pseudoscorpionina , and Acarina.

lipochrome.explanation: A pigment found in fatty tissue, commonly of a yellow or red color. Such products occur widely distributed both in the animal and the vegetable world. The yellow color of the blood-serum, of the corpora lutea, and of the yoke of birds' eggs, and the reddish pigment of carrots and tomatoes belong to this order. Their composition is for the most part unknown.
Any naturally-occurring, fat-soluble pigment such as carotenes or chlorophyll

lipochromogen.explanation: A substance which gives rise to the formation of a lipochrome.

lipocyte.explanation: An adipocyte in connective tissue that stores and metabolizes fat

lipodystrophy.explanation: In pathology , a disturbance of the metabolism of fat.
A disorder characterized by abnormal or degenerative conditions of the body's adipose tissue .

lipofibroma.explanation: In pathology , a lipoma in which there is a considerable amount of connective tissue. Also called adipofibroma .

lipogenesis.explanation: The biochemical production of fat , especially the conversion of carbohydrate into fat so that it may be stored as a long-term source of energy when food is scarce

lipogram.explanation: A story, poem, or other text in which one or more letters of the alphabet have been deliberately avoided.

A writing from which all words containing a particular letter are omitted, as the several books of the Odyssey of Tryphiodorus, in the first of which, it is said, there was no A, in the second no B, etc.
A writing composed of words not having a certain letter or letters; -- as in the Odyssey of Tryphiodorus there was no A in the first book, no B in the second, and so on.
A word, or writing which omits a symbol or symbols.
a text that excludes a particular letter or particular letters of the alphabet

lipogrammatic.explanation: Omitting a letter; composed of words not having a certain letter or letters.
Omitting a letter ; composed of words not having a certain letter or letters.

lipogrammatism.explanation: The art or practice of writing lipograms.

lipoid.explanation: Any of various substances, such as lecithin, that resemble fat.
The fat of the nerve-cells. It consists chiefly of cholesterol and lecithin.
A lipid or other substance resembling fat
an oily organic compound insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents; essential structural component of living cells (along with proteins and carbohydrates)

lipoidaemia.explanation: presence of excess lipids in the blood

lipoidemia.explanation: presence of excess lipids in the blood

lipolysis.explanation: The cleavage of fats into fatty acids and glycerin.
The reverse of lipogenesis in which stored fat is broken down

lipoma.explanation: A benign tumor composed chiefly of fat cells.
In pathology , a tumor formed of fatty tissue. Also called adipoma and liparocele.
A tumor consisting of fat or adipose tissue.
A nonmalignant tumor comprising fat cells .
a tumor consisting of fatty tissue

lipomatosis.explanation: The excessive growth of fatty tissue in the body or any of its parts.
pathology in which fat accumulates in lipomas in the body

lipomorph.explanation: An organism which characterizes a district by its absence from it. See the extract.

lipomyxoma.explanation: In pathology , a tumor composed partly of fatty and partly of mucous tissue.

lipophilic.explanation: Having an affinity for, tending to combine with, or capable of dissolving in lipids.
having an affinity for lipids; -- of chemical substances or parts of molecules. Contrasted to lipophobic or polar .
Having the quality of dissolving in lipids
Typically have the quality of being composed of mostly nonpolar bonds

lipophore.explanation: A lipochrome -containing chromatophore , usually a xanthophore .

lipopoda.explanation: Rotifera , called a class and contrasted with Parapodiata , and divided into the orders Ploima, Bdelligrada , and Rhizota.

lipopolysaccharide.explanation: Any of a group of polysaccharides in which a lipid constitutes a portion of the molecule.
Any of a large class of lipids conjugated with polysaccharides

lipoprotein.explanation: Any of a group of conjugated proteins in which at least one of the components is a lipid. Lipoproteins, classified according to their densities and chemical qualities, are the principal means by which lipids are transported in the blood.
Any of a large group of complexes of protein and lipid with many biochemical functions .
a conjugated protein having a lipid component; the principal means for transporting lipids in the blood

liposarcoma.explanation: Any malignant tumour that originates in adipose tissue

liposome.explanation: A microscopic artificial vesicle consisting of an aqueous core enclosed in phospholipid molecules, used to convey vaccines, drugs, or other substances to target tissues.
an aqueous compartment enclosed by a bimolecular phospholipid membrane ; a lipid vesicle
an artificially made microscopic vesicle into which nucleic acids can be packaged; used in molecular biology as a transducing vector

lipostomy.explanation: Atrophy of the mouth; an astomatous condition.
In sponges, the temporary obliteration of the osculum by the contraction of the walls. Compare lipogastry .

lipotropic.explanation: Preventing abnormal or excessive accumulation of fat in the liver.
having an affinity for lipids ; lipophilic

lipotropin.explanation: A hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland that promotes the utilization of fat by the body and is a precursor to the endorphins.
A pituitary hormone that promotes the metabolism of fat , and is a precursor to the endorphins

lipotype.explanation: In zoögeog. , a type or form of animal life which distinguishes a given faunal area by its absence therefrom.

lipotyphla.explanation: Insectivora , including those forms which have no cæcum, as distinguished from the Menotyphla , which have a cæcum.
A suborder of mammals including the moles; hedgehogs; and true shrews.

lipoxeny.explanation: In botany , the desertion of its host by a parasitic fungus. See lipoxenous .

lipped.explanation: ichthyology , specifically, thick-lipped; labroid: applied to the wrasse or rockfish family.
Having a lip or lips; having a raised or rounded edge resembling the lip; -- often used in composition
having some specific type of lip

lippen.explanation: to or on : as, do not lippen to him; I was lippening on you.
To trust ; to expect ; to depend or rely (on).

lipper.explanation: off : as, to lipper off the deck.
A thin piece of blubber cut in oblong shape, with slits in it, used to wipe up gurry or slumgullion from the deck of a whaler.
A large metal ladle used for scooping up the oil from the deck of a whaler.
The spray from small waves, in either fresh or salt water.

lippia.explanation: A genus of plants of the tribe Verbeneæ , characterized by a small membranaceous two- to four-toothed calyx, a fourlobed corolla, and a dry indehiscent fruit.

lippier.explanation: comparative form of lippy : more lippy

lippiest.explanation: superlative form of lippy : most lippy .

lipping.explanation: The formation of a lip-like projection.

lippitude.explanation: Soreness of the eyes; blearedness; lippitudo.
Soreness of eyes; the state of being blear-eyed; blearedness.

lippitudo.explanation: In pathology , the presence of a gummy or crusting accumulation along the edges of the eyelids.

lippy.explanation: An old Scotch dry measure, the fourth part of a peck: same as forpet .
lip , n., 3); impertinent and voluble in speech; saucy.
Talking back , in a cheeky manner .

lipread.explanation: To know what a person is saying by watching how their lips move.

lipreading.explanation: perceiving what a person is saying by observing the movements of the lips

lipsanotheca.explanation: A shrine for relics; a reliquary.

lipstick.explanation: A small stick of waxy lip coloring enclosed in a cylindrical case.
makeup that is used to color the lips

lipuria.explanation: The elimination of fat in the urine: a pathological event.
The abnormal presence of lipids in urine .

liquate.explanation: To separate (the metals in an alloy) by melting the more fusible constituents while leaving the less fusible ones solid.
metallurgy , to separate, as one metal from another less fusible, by applying just sufficient heat to melt the more easily liquefiable, so that it can be run off from the other. Also eliquate .
To separate by fusion, as a more fusible from a less fusible material.
To separate by fusion , as a more fusible from a less fusible material.

liquated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of liquate .

liquates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of liquate .

liquation.explanation: In mixtures of fluids, a separation by differences of specific gravity. The lightest rises to the top and the heaviest goes to the bottom.
The act or operation of liquating or melting.
The condition or capacity of being melted: as, a substance congealed beyond liquation.

The separation of metals differing considerably in fusibility by subjecting them, when contained in an alloy or mixture, to a degree of heat sufficient to melt the most fusible only, which then flows away, or liquates, from the unmelted mass.
The act or operation of making or becoming liquid; also, the capacity of becoming liquid.
The process of separating, by heat, an easily fusible metal from one less fusible; eliquation.
The partial melting of a mixture of metals or ores in order to separate components

liquefacient.explanation: That which liquefies or serves to liquefy; in medicine , an agent, as mercury or iodine, used to produce liquefaction of solid depositions.
An agent, as mercury, iodine, etc., which promotes the liquefying processes of the system, and increases the secretions.
Any agent , such as mercury , iodine , etc., that promotes the liquefying processes of the system, and increases the secretions .

liquefaction.explanation: The act or process of liquefying, or of rendering or becoming liquid; reduction to a liquid state.
The state of being liquefied or melted.

The act, process, or method, of reducing a gas or vapor to a liquid by means of cold or pressure.

the conversion of a solid or a gas into a liquid

liquefactive.explanation: That causes, or is associated with liquefaction

liquefiable.explanation: Capable of being changed from a solid to a liquid state.

liquefied.explanation: rendered liquid by heating; changed from a solid to a liquid state; melted.
rendered liquid by dissolution in a solvent; -- of solids.

reduced to liquid form by heating

liquefier.explanation: One who or that which liquefies.

liquefies.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of liquefy .

liquefy.explanation: To cause to become liquid, especially.
To convert from a solid form to that of a liquid; to melt; to dissolve; and technically, to melt by the sole agency of heat.
To convert from a gaseous form into a liquid.
To make into a liquid , either by condensing a gas or by melting a solid .
To make into a liquid by mashing , such as by using a blender .
