[ capitalized ] The typical genus of Lorisinæ , based by Geoffroy on the slender lori or loris of Ceylon, and the same as Arachmocebus of Lesson; extended to include the slow lemur, which is more frequently referred to a genus Nycticebus, Stenops , or Bradylemur.

Any one of several species of small lemurs of the genus Stenops. They have long, slender limbs and large eyes, and are arboreal in their habits. The slender loris ( Stenops gracilis ), of Ceylon, in one of the best known species.
Any of several small, slow-moving primates , of the family Lorisidae , found in India and southeast Asia .

Synonyms Loss, Detriment, Damage, Waste, Forfeiture , etc. Loss is the class word under which detriment, damage, waste, forfeiture , etc., are species. Loss, detriment , and damage apply to persons or things; waste and forfeiture only to things. As to detriment and damage , see injury. Waste is generally voluntary, although not always realized; sometimes it is only by neglect. Forfeiture is a loss through the law, as a penalty or as the result of neglect.

lota.explanation: A globular or melon-shaped pot, usually of polished brass, used in the East Indies for drawing water, drinking, and ablutions.

A pot ; specifically a container filled with water used in India, for washing and ablution .

A person that switches loyalties, especially from one political party to another. This comes from the fact that the "lota" has a tendency to fall over and roll around, as it is not stable sitting on its base.
Slurry, also used as an insult.
A person who is employed by a for-profit institution despite having a high net worth derived from managing a family-owned business .
a globular water bottle used in Asia

unwillingness to do something contrary to your custom

A people visited by Ulysses in his wanderings. They subsisted on the lotus. See lotus (b), and lotus-eater .

to a very great degree or extent

An activity or event regarded as having an outcome depending on fate.
Distribution of anything by lot; allotment; also, the drawing of lots; determination by chance or fate; random choice; matter of chance: as, the lottery of life.

A scheme for raising money by selling chances to share in a distribution of prizes; more specifically, a scheme for the distribution of prizes by chance among persons purchasing tickets, the correspondingly numbered slips, or lots, representing prizes or blanks, being drawn from a wheel on a day previously announced in connection with the scheme of intended prizes.
The lot or portion falling to one's share; a chance allotment or prize.
A scheme for the distribution of prizes by lot or chance; esp., a gaming scheme in which one or more tickets bearing particular numbers draw prizes, and the rest of the tickets are blanks.
A scheme for the distribution of prizes by lot or chance , especially a gaming scheme in which one or more tickets bearing particular numbers draw prizes, the other tickets are blanks.
players buy (or are given) chances and prizes are distributed by casting lots
something that is regarded as a chance event

lotto.explanation: A game of chance similar to bingo.
A lottery, typically with an accumulating jackpot, in which participants play numbers of their choice in a random drawing.
A game played with disks and cards.

A game of chance, played with cards or tickets, on which are inscribed numbers, and any contrivance (as a wheel containing numbered balls) for determining a set of numbers by chance. The player holding a card having on it the set of numbers drawn from the wheel takes the stakes after a certain percentage of them has been deducted for the dealer. In some systems, lesser prizes are awarded for having some but not all of the numbers selected, such as four or five numbers in a six-number drawing. A variety of lotto is called keno . In another variety, the player chooses the numbers for the card or ticket s/he holds. There may be from three to seven different numbers on a card or ticket. In a modern computerized lotto system conducted by state authorities, the player chooses numbers, or allows the computer to choose numbers at random, which are then printed on a ticket that the player holds until the winning number is selected.
a game of chance similar to bingo
a game in which numbered balls are drawn at random and players cover the corresponding numbers on their cards

lotus.explanation: Either of two aquatic plants, Nelumbo nucifera of Asia and Australia with pink flowers, or N. lutea of eastern North America with yellow flowers, or their cultivated varieties, having large round leaves, fragrant many-petaled flowers, a round perforated seedpod, and fleshy rhizomes.
The edible seed, leaf, or rhizome of either of these plants.
Any of several water lilies, especially Nymphaea caerula or N. lotus.
An artistic representation of the flower or bud of any of various lotuses or similar plants.
Any of several leguminous plants of the genus Lotus.
A small Mediterranean tree or shrub whose fruit was eaten by the lotus-eaters.
The fruit of this plant.

Nelumbo Nelumbo , a native of the warmer parts of Asia and of Australia, apparently not of Egypt, though long cultivated there and often called Egyptian lotus . It is a superb plant with large, showy pink or sometimes white flowers. It is very common in cultivation, and figures extensively in Indian mythology.
One of a number of different plants famous in mythology and tradition, or in modern times associated with traditions.
[ capitalized ] [NL. (Tournefort, 1700).] A genus of leguminous plants, type of the tribe Loteæ , distinguished by a two-valved pod and the pointed keel of the corolla.

In architecture , an ornament in the form of the Egyptian water-lily, Castalia mystica , frequently figured in the art of ancient nations, notably on certain types of the capitals of Egyptian columns.

A name of several kinds of water lilies; as Nelumbium speciosum , used in religious ceremonies, anciently in Egypt, and to this day in Asia; Nelumbium luteum , the American lotus; and Nymphæa Lotus and Nymphæa cærulea , the respectively white-flowered and blue-flowered lotus of modern Egypt, which, with Nelumbium speciosum , are figured on its ancient monuments.

The lotus of the lotuseaters , probably a tree found in Northern Africa, Sicily, Portugal, and Spain ( Zizyphus Lotus ), the fruit of which is mildly sweet. It was fabled by the ancients to make strangers who ate of it forget their native country, or lose all desire to return to it.
The lote, or nettle tree. See lote .
A genus (Lotus) of leguminous plants much resembling clover.
a small tree ( Diospyros Lotus ) of Southern Europe and Asia; also, its rather large bluish black berry, which is called also the date plum .
An ornament much used in Egyptian architecture, generally asserted to have been suggested by the Egyptian water lily.
A kind of aquatic plant, genus Nelumbo in the family Nelumbonaceae.
A water lily , genus Nymphaea, especially those of Egypt or India.
A legendary plant eaten by the Lotophagi of the Odyssey that caused drowsiness and euphoria.
A number of other plants bearing "lotus" in their scientific or common names.
An architectural motif of ancient Egyptian temples .

native to eastern Asia; widely cultivated for its large pink or white flowers

louse.explanation: Any of numerous small, flat-bodied, wingless biting or sucking insects of the order Phthiraptera, which live as external parasites on birds and mammals, including humans. The lice are sometimes classified together with the psocids in the order Psocodea.
A mean or despicable person.

An insect or other small arthropod (as a crustacean) that infests other animals or plants, or an animal resembling such parasites: a name for a great variety of small creatures.

Bird-lice are parasitic insects, of several hundred species, various genera, and several families, which some authors range with the foregoing in the order Hemiptera , but most place in the Pseudoneuroptera. They are known as the order or superfamily Mallophaga. They have mandibulate or biting mouth-parts, are wingless, and of very variable forms. They are by no means confined to birds, but infest mammals as well; almost every kind of bird and beast is infested by these creatures, sometimes several species to one host, and in such multitudes as to canse disease and death. Of these, such as infest domestic quadrupeds and birds belong to the genera Trichodectes, Docophorus, Nirmus, Goniocotes, Goniodes, Lipeurus, Trinotum, Colpopocephalum, Menopon , and Gyropus.
The beaver harbors a remarkable louse, Platypsyllus castoris , a degraded clavicorn beetle, so peculiar as to have been made type of an order, Achreioptera.

Insects have their own lice. Such are the bee-lice , or pupiparous dipterous insects of the family Braulidæ , order Diptera ; and some of the lice of bats are similar dipterous insects, though wingless, of the family Nycteribiidæ. Bees, wasps, etc., are also infested by certain small parasitic heteromerous beetles in the form of lice, such as the wingless larvæ of Meloidæ , a species of which has been named Pediculus melittæ , and the whole family Stylopidæ. Insects affected by the latter are said to be stylopized. None of the foregoing lice are aquatic.

Fishes, marine mammals. crustaceans, etc., are infested by a great variety of small degraded crustaceans, collectively known as fish-lice or Ichthyophthira. Most of these belong to a class or order Epizoa or Siphonostoma , or Lernæoidea ; a few are cirripeds, as Rhizocephala. Whale-lice are Cyamidæ. Carpice are Argulidæ.
Wood-lice are the terrestrial isopods of the family Oniscidæ , also called slaters, sow-bugs , etc. These are not parasites, but some of the aquatic isopods are fish-lice, as Cymothoidæ.

Plants are infested by multitudes of small plant-sucking hemipters, known as plant-lice , and formerly collectively termed Phytophthiria : as the aphids, Aphididæ , some of which are also called gall-lice ; the psyllids, Psyllidæ , called flea-lice and jumping plant-lice ; and the scale-insects or Coccidæ , some of which are also known as bark-lice.
Book-lice are pseudoneuropterous insects of the family Psocidæ , various species of which, as those of the genera Atropos and Clothilla , injure books.

Certain mites or acarids are sometimes called lice , as the harvest-ticks, known as red-lice , the itch-mite or itch-louse, etc. For further information, see the compounded words, and also the technical names.
To clean from lice.

Any one of numerous species of small, wingless, suctorial, parasitic insects belonging to a tribe ( Pediculina ), now usually regarded as degraded Hemiptera. To this group belong of the lice of man and other mammals. See Crab louse, Dog louse, Cattle louse, etc., under crab , dog , etc.

Any one of numerous small mandibulate insects, mostly parasitic on birds, and feeding on the feathers. They are known as Mallophaga, or bird lice, though some occur on the hair of mammals. They are usually regarded as degraded Pseudoneuroptera. See Mallophaga .

See Euelephas, elephant. Falconer , 1857. Also Loxodonta .

loxodromic.explanation: Pertaining to sailing on rhumb lines.

a line on the surface of a sphere, which always makes an equal angle with every meridian; the rhumb line. It is the line on which a ship sails when her course is always in the direction of one and the same point of the compass.
Pertaining to motion at a constant angle to the meridians; on a set compass bearing.

luciferin.explanation: A chemical substance present in the cells of bioluminescent organisms, such as fireflies, that produces an almost heatless, bluish-green light when oxidized under the catalytic effects of luciferase and ATP.

any of several substances found in luminescent organisms (such as the firefly, Photinus pyralis ) which, when oxidized, produces an almost heatless light. It was first isolated from fireflies, and is the source of the firefly luminescence. See also firefly luciferin
Any of a class of polycyclic heterocycles that are responsible for the bioluminescence of fireflies , being converted to oxyluciferin by luciferase in the process.

luck.explanation: The chance happening of fortunate or adverse events; fortune.

( as luck would have it ) As it turned out; as it happened.
( in luck ) Enjoying success; fortunate.

( press /push ) To risk one's good fortune, often by acting overconfidently.
( try (one's) luck ) To attempt something without knowing if one will be successful.
A lock of wool twisted on the finger of a spinner.

Fortune; hap; that which happens to a person by chance, conceived as having a real tendency to be favorable or unfavorable, or as if there were an inward connection between a succes sion of fortuitous occurrences having the same character as favorable or unfavorable.

Good fortune; favorable hap; a supposed something, pertaining to a person, at least for a time, giving to fortuitous events a favorable character; also, in a weakened sense, a fortuitous combination of favorable occurrences.
An object with which good fortune is thought to be connected; especially, a vessel for holding liquid, as a drinking-cup.

That which happens to a person; an event, good or ill, affecting one's interests or happiness, and which is deemed casual; a course or series of such events regarded as occurring by chance; chance; hap; fate; fortune; often, one's habitual or characteristic fortune. Luck is often used by itself to mean good luck .
a small sum given back for luck to one who pays money.
to receive some good, or to meet with some success, in an unexpected manner, or as the result of circumstances beyond one's control; to be fortunate.
Something that happens to someone by chance , a chance occurrence.
A superstitious feeling that brings fortune or success .
success
To succeed by chance .
To rely on luck.
To carry out relying on luck.
your overall circumstances or condition in life (including everything that happens to you)
an unknown and unpredictable phenomenon that causes an event to result one way rather than another
an unknown and unpredictable phenomenon that leads to a favorable outcome

ludicrous.explanation: So absurd or incongruous as to be laughable. synonym : foolish .
Funny, Comical, Droll, Ludicrous, Ridiculous, Laughable. Either the direct action of laughter or a corresponding sentiment is included in the signification of all these terms.

laughable is the generic word, but it is also one of the strongest. Funny is the weakest of the list, ranging from the meaning of ‘amusing’ or ‘odd’ down to its colloquial use in the sense of ‘strange.’ Comical still retains a faint suggestion of its origin in connection with the drama, being primarily used in connection with something done or seen, and hence something viewed by the mind: a comical predicament is just such as would be fit for exhibition in a comedy. Droll especially implies the odd or unfamiliar: as, a droll story, idea, fellow. Ludicrous is an advance in strength upon comical , as comical is an advance upon funny. Ridiculous is the only word in the list that throws contempt or even discredit upon the person concerned: it is allowable to tell a ludicrous story about one's friend, but not a story that makes him appear ridiculous. A thing may be ludicrous , etc., on account of its unreasonableness or violation of common sense; if it is ridiculous , it is certainly on that account. That is laughable which simply provokes a hearty laugh.
Adapted to excite laughter, without scorn or contempt; sportive.

Any body that gives light, especially one of the heavenly bodies.
One who illustrates any subject, or enlightens mankind.
One that is an inspiration to others; one who has achieved success in his chosen field; a leading light .
A body that gives light; especially, one of the heavenly bodies .
a celebrity who is an inspiration to others

lumination.explanation: A lighting up; a flashing out, as of light or energy; an illuminating outburst.

luminator.explanation: In St. Andrews University, a student (one in each class) who was privileged to attend the professor′ s lectures without payment, and to receive certain dues from the other students, in return for services rendered by him.

lumine.explanation: The principle or the medium of light; the luminiferous ether.

luminesce.explanation: To give off light, including in the invisible electromagnetic radiation frequencies, or become luminescent .
be or become luminescent; exhibit luminescence

luminesced.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of luminesce .

luminescence.explanation: The emission of light that does not derive energy from the temperature of the emitting body, as in phosphorescence, fluorescence, and bioluminescence. Luminescence is caused by chemical, biochemical, or crystallographic changes, the motions of subatomic particles, or radiation-induced excitation of an atomic system.
The emission of light from causes other than that which produces incandescence.

Any emission of light not ascribable directly to incandescence, and therefore occurring at low temperatures, as in phosphorescence and fluorescence or other luminous radiation resulting from vital processes, chemical action, friction, solution, or the influence of light or of ultraviolet or cathode rays, etc.
The faculty or power of producing light by biological processes, as in the firefly and glowworm. Also called bioluminescence .
The light produced by biological or biochemical processes. Also called bioluminescence .
Any emission of light that cannot be attributed merely to the temperature of the emitting body.
light not due to incandescence; occurs at low temperatures

luminescent.explanation: Capable of, suitable for, or exhibiting luminescence.
Shining with a light due to any of the various causes which produce luminescence.
emitting light not caused by heat

luminesces.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of luminesce .

luminiferous.explanation: physics , producing or bearing light; yielding light: as, the luminiferous ether. See ether , 2.
Producing light; yielding light; transmitting light.

luminism.explanation: A style of 19th-century American landscape painting concerned especially with the meticulous rendering of atmospheric light and the perceived effects of that light on depicted objects.

an artistic movement in the United States that was derived from the Hudson River school; active from 1850 to 1870; painted realistic landscapes in a style that pictured atmospheric light and the use of aerial perspective

luminist.explanation: A painter who affects brilliancy of light in plein-air effects.

luminologist.explanation: One who is versed in the study of illuminations (of manuscripts).

luminometer.explanation: An instrument for the measurement of the intensity of illumination at any point in a field of light flux.

luminophore.explanation: That part of a molecule that is responsible for a given emission band when it undergoes luminescence .

luminous.explanation: Emitting light, especially in the dark; shining.
Having a high degree of saturation.
Presented or perceived clearly or vividly.
Shining; emitting or reflecting light; brilliant; bright
a paint made up with some phosphorescent substance, as sulphide of calcium, which after exposure to a strong light is luminous in the dark for a time.

luminously.explanation: In a luminous manner, brightly , glowingly .

luminousness.explanation: The quality of being luminous, in any sense; brightness; clearness.
the quality of being luminous; emitting or reflecting light.
the quality of being luminous; emitting or reflecting light

lummox.explanation: A fat, ungainly, stupid person; an awkward bungler.
A clumsy , stupid person; an awkward bungler .

lump.explanation: An irregularly shaped mass or piece.
A small cube of sugar.
A swelling or small palpable mass.
A collection or totality; an aggregate.
A person regarded as ungainly or dull-witted.
Severe punishment or treatment, as a beating or an unsparing criticism.
One's just deserts; comeuppance.
Formed into lumps.
Not broken or divided into parts.
To put together in a single group without discrimination.
To move with heavy clumsiness.
To make into lumps.
To become lumpy.
To move heavily.
( lump in (one's) throat ) A feeling of constriction in the throat caused by emotion.
To tolerate (what must be endured).
The lump-fish.
A small mass; a relatively small aggregation or conglomeration of solid matter without regular form: as, a lump of ore, clay, or dough; to melt a number of coins into one lump.
A protuberant part; a knob, bunch, or swelling: as, a lump raised on the head by a blow.
A blow.
A dull, stolid person.
In firearms
The nipple-seat on the barrel.
In a break-joint breech-loader, an iron block on the barrel which descends into a recess in the action.
A bloom or loupe of malleable iron.
lump it.”
In mining , a coarse fragment of ore, coal, phosphate rock, or any useful mineral, as contrasted with the fines, spalls , or otherwise designated smaller pieces.
lumped large in public imagination.
To throw into a mass; to unite in a body or sum without distinction of particulars.
To take in the gross; to speak of collectively.
To get along with as one can, although displeased.
A small mass of matter of irregular shape; an irregular or shapeless mass
A mass or aggregation of things.
A projection beneath the breech end of a gun barrel.
the whole together; in gross.
coal in large lumps; -- the largest size brought from the mine.

a single sum paid once in satisfaction of a claim, as contrasted with the alternate choice of several payments over a period of time; -- sometimes allowed, e.g., as an alternative to periodical pension payments for a lifetime.
Something that protrudes , sticks out, or sticks together; a cluster or blob ; a mound , hill , or group .
A group, set , or unit .
A small, shaped mass of sugar, typically about a teaspoonful.
A dull or lazy person.
A beating or verbal abuse.

lumpectomy.explanation: Surgical excision of a tumor from the breast with the removal of a minimal amount of surrounding tissue.

the removal of a cyst or tumor from the breast by surgery. This is one method of treating breast tumors when in an early stage, and is preferred for cosmetic reasons, when medically feasible, to radical mastectomy , the removal of the entire breast along with nearby muscles.
The surgical removal of a tumour or cyst from a breast .
surgical removal of a tumor without removing much of the surrounding tissue or lymph nodes; performed in some cases of breast cancer

lumped.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lump .

lumpen.explanation: The European eelpout; -- called also lumper .
Of or referring to social outcasts .
Of or relating to the lumpenproletariat .

lumpenproletariat.explanation: The lowest stratum of the proletariat. Used originally in Marxist theory to describe those members of the proletariat, especially criminals, vagrants, and the unemployed, who lacked awareness of their collective interest as an oppressed class.

the lowest level of the proletariat, comprising unskilled workers, the unemployed, and the dispossessed, alienated from the class with with they would normally identify and having little or no class solidarity; -- an important element in Marxist theory.
the lowest stratum of the proletariat
(Marxism) the unorganized lower levels of the proletariat who are not interested in revolutionary advancement

lumper.explanation: In some places, a laborer employed to load and unload vessels in port; a dock-hand; a longshoreman; a stevedore.
In zoology , one who lumps several described species, genera, etc., in one: opposed to splitter.
The European eelpout; -- called also lumpen .
A laborer who is employed to load or unload vessels when in harbor.
The European eelpout ; -- called also lumpen .
Extra labor hired by a trucking company to assist a driver and/or customer unloading or loading a truck.
A scientist in one of various fields who prefers to keep categories such as species or dialects together in larger groups.
a laborer who loads and unloads vessels in a port
a taxonomist who classifies organisms into large groups on the basis of major characteristics

lumpfish.explanation: Any of various fishes of the family Cyclopteridae, especially Cyclopterus lumpus of North Atlantic waters, having a stout knobby body with pelvic fins united to form a suction disk, and producing roe that is used for caviar.
An acanthopterygian fish, Cyclopterus lumpus , of the family Cyclopteridæ.

A large, thick, clumsy, marine fish ( Cyclopterus lumpus ) of Europe and America. The color is usually translucent sea green, sometimes purplish. It has a dorsal row of spiny tubercles, and three rows on each side, but has no scales. The ventral fins unite and form a ventral sucker for adhesion to stones and seaweeds. Called also lumpsucker , cock-paddle , sea owl .
clumsy soft thick-bodied northern Atlantic fish with pelvic fins fused into a sucker; edible roe used for caviar

lumpier.explanation: comparative form of lumpy : more lumpy

lumpiest.explanation: superlative form of lumpy : most lumpy .

lumpiness.explanation: The quality or condition of being lumpy or full of lumps.

lumpish.explanation: Like a lump; inert; gross; heavy; dull; spiritless.
Like a lump , cloddish , dull, slow-witted.
Like lumps , composed of unshaped or mismatched pieces.
Shaped like a lump , ill defined in shape.

lumpishness.explanation: The quality of being lumpish; heaviness; dullness; stolidity.

lumpsucker.explanation: Any of the scorpaeniform fish in the Cyclopteridae family , with adhesive pelvic discs.
any of several very small lumpfishes

lumpy.explanation: Full of lumps, or small compact masses.
having lumps; not smooth and even in texture
like or containing small sticky lumps

luna.explanation: A luna moth : a member of species Actias luna.

lunacy.explanation: Intermittent mental derangement attributed to the changing phases of the moon.
A wildly foolish or irrational act.
The kind of intermittent insanity formerly supposed to be subject to the change's of the moon; hence, madness in general; any unsoundness of mind. See insanity .
In law , unsoundness of mind sufficient to incapacitate for civil transactions. The usual test is incapacity to manage one's own property and affairs.
Synonyms Derangement, Craziness , etc. See insanity .

Insanity or madness; properly, the kind of insanity which is broken by intervals of reason, -- formerly supposed to be influenced by the changes of the moon; any form of unsoundness of mind, except idiocy; mental derangement or alienation.
A morbid suspension of good sense or judgment, as through fanaticism.

lunacy.category: of a person or group of people
lunacy.explanation: The state of being mad , insanity

lunambulism.explanation: Somnambulism or sleep-walking supposed to be induced by the influence of the moon.

lunar.explanation: Of, involving, caused by, or affecting the moon.
Measured by the revolution of the moon.
Of or relating to silver.

Arabic gram. , a fanciful term applied to the class of consonants before which the l of the article al is not assimilated in pronunciation: so called because including q , the initial of qamar , moon. Opposed to solar.
lunar changes; lunar observations.
lunar months or years.
lunar shield, specifically, in anatomy and zoology :
lunar madness.
anatomy , of or pertaining to the lunare, or semilunar bone of the carpus.
lunar caustic (nitrate of silver).

navigation , tables for correcting the apparent distance of the moon from the sun, or from a fixed star, on account of refraction and parallax, and for deducing the longitude of the observer from the lunar data given in the almanac.
In navigation , lunar distance, or an observation for lunar distance: as, to take a lunar.
Of or pertaining to the moon.
Resembling the moon; orbed.
Measured by the revolutions of the moon.
Influenced by the moon, as in growth, character, or properties.
silver nitrate prepared to be used as a cautery; -- so named because silver was called luna by the ancient alchemists.
Same as Metonic cycle. See under Cycle .
the angular distance of the moon from the sun, a star, or a planet, employed for determining longitude by the lunar method.

the method of finding a ship's longitude by comparing the local time of taking (by means of a sextant or circle) a given lunar distance, with the Greenwich time corresponding to the same distance as ascertained from a nautical almanac, the difference of these times being the longitude.
See Month .
an observation of a lunar distance by means of a sextant or circle, with the altitudes of the bodies, and the time, for the purpose of computing the longitude.
Tables for correcting an observed lunar distance on account of refraction and parallax.
the period of twelve lunar months, or 354 days, 8 hours, 48 minutes, and 34.38 seconds.
A lunar distance.
The middle bone of the proximal series of the carpus; -- called also semilunar , and intermedium .
Of, or pertaining to, the Moon ; moonly .
Crescent shaped, lunate .
Of, or pertaining to, silver .
A lunar distance .
The middle bone of the proximal series of the carpus .
of or relating to or associated with the moon

lunare.explanation: A bone of the carpus, more fully named os lunare , and also called semilunare , or the semilunar bone: supposed to represent the bone of the typical carpus called intermedium by Gegenbaur.

lunarium.explanation: A mechanical representation of the moon and its phases.
In paleontology , a more or less thickened portion of the posterior wall in many Paleozoic bryozoans which is curved to a shorter radius and usually projects above the plane of the zoœcial aperture.

lunary.explanation: The garden-flower Lunaria annua. See honesty , 5, and Lunaria.
A low fleshy fern ( Botrychium Lunaria ) with lunate segments of the leaf or frond.

lunate.explanation: A small stone artifact, probably an arrowhead, with a blunt straight edge and a sharpened, crescent-shaped back, especially characteristic of the Mesolithic Period.
A small stone artifact , probably an arrowhead, with a blunt straight edge and a sharpened, crescent-shaped back, especially characteristic of the Mesolithic Period.
resembling the new moon in shape

lunated.explanation: zoology , having crescentiform markings: as, the lunated broadbill, Serilophus lunatus.

lunatellus.explanation: An orrery showing the astronomical relations of the earth and the moon.

lunatic.explanation: A person who is affected by lunacy; a mentally deranged person.
Of or for people who are mentally deranged.
A person affected with lunacy; specifically, an insane person who has lucid intervals, or one whose unsoundness of mind is acquired, not congenital, as distinguished from an idiot.
More generally (and in law), any person of unsound mind. See further under lunacy and insanity.
Affected by lunacy; insane; mad; crazy; demented.
Of or pertaining to, or suitable for, an insane person; evincing lunacy
A person affected by lunacy; an insane person, esp. one who has lucid intervals; a madman; a person of unsound mind.
insane and believed to be affected by the phases of the moon

lunation.explanation: The time that elapses between successive new moons, averaging 29 days, 12 hours, 44 minutes; a lunar month.
The period of a synodic revolution of the moon, or the time from one new moon to the next.

The period of a synodic revolution of the moon, or the time from one new moon to the next; varying in length, at different times, from about 291/4 to 295/6 days, the average length being 29 d., 12h., 44m., 2.9s.

a month of approximately 29.53 days , measured from a lunar phase until the return of that same phase. On average, the number of days between Full Moons is about 29.5306 days. The actual number of days may differ from the average number by more than a half day. From one Full Moon to the next, the number of days in one lunation can vary between 29.272 and 29.833 days.
The irregular period from one new moon until the next.
the period between successive new moons (29.531 days)

lunatum.explanation: A bone of the proximal row of the carpus of some animals, as batrachians, on the radial side of the wrist, probably homologous with the radiale.

lunch.explanation: The food provided for a midday meal.
( out to lunch ) Not in touch with the real world; crazy.
A large lump or piece, as of bread.
A slight repast or meal between breakfast and dinner, or, as formerly, between dinner and supper, or between dinner or supper and bedtime; luncheon.
A luncheon; specifically, a light repast between breakfast and dinner, most commonly about noontime.
A light meal usually eaten around midday , notably when not as main meal of the day.
A break in play between the first and second sessions .
Any small meal, especially one eaten at a social gathering.

lunched.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lunch .

luncheon.explanation: A lunch, especially a formal one.
An afternoon party at which a light meal is served.
A large lump or piece, as of bread: same as lunch , Cotgrave.
A slight repast: same as lunch , 2. The form luncheon is now regarded as more “elegant” than lunch.
A portion of food taken at any time except at a regular meal.
A lunch, especially one organized by a group as a formal social gathering.
A formal meal served in the middle of the day.

luncheonette.explanation: A small restaurant that serves simple, easily prepared meals.
A small diner or restaurant that serves lunch .

luncher.explanation: Someone who lunches , someone who eats lunch .

lunches.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of lunch .

lunchroom.explanation: A room in a facility, such as a school, in which lunches may be purchased or those brought from home may be eaten.
a dining room (in a school, business, or other non-domestic facility) where lunch can be purchased.
A room reserved for eating food, especially at a business (lunch may or may not be served there).
A diner or restaurant that specializes in serving lunch.
a restaurant (in a facility) where lunch can be purchased

lunchtime.explanation: The time during which lunch is usually eaten.
The time or hour at which lunch is normally eaten.
the period of 30 minutes to an hour at midday between lessons when schoolchildren are allowed to go outside and play or eat.
the customary or habitual hour for eating lunch

lunda.explanation: The common puffin, Fratercula arctica. Montagu.
[ capitalized ] [NL.] A genus of Alcidæ , having the bill much as in Fratercula , but the head adorned with a long curly crest on each side; the tufted puffins.
A genus of birds including some of the puffins.

lundress.explanation: A sterling silver penny formerly coined in London.

lune.explanation: A crescent-shaped portion of a plane or sphere bounded by two arcs of circles.
A leash: as, the lune of a hawk.
Anything in the shape of a crescent or half-moon.
In geometry , a figure formed on a sphere or on a plane by two arcs of circles which inclose a space.
A fit of lunacy or madness; a mad freak or tantrum.
Anything in the shape of a half moon.
A figure in the form of a crescent, bounded by two intersecting arcs of circles.
A fit of lunacy or madness; a period of frenzy; a crazy or unreasonable freak.
A fit of lunacy or madness; a period of frenzy; a crazy or unreasonable freak
A concave figure formed by the intersection of the arcs of two circles on a plane, or on a sphere the intersection between two great semicircles

lunel.explanation: In heraldry , a figure formed by four crescents placed point to point, resembling a rose with four leaves.
A sweet and rich white muscat wine, similar to Frontignan, produced in the south of France, in the department of Hérault.
A type of sweet muscat wine.

lunette.explanation: A small, circular or crescent-shaped opening in a vaulted roof.
A crescent-shaped or semicircular space, usually over a door or window, that may contain another window, a sculpture, or a mural.
A fortification that has two projecting faces and two parallel flanks.
A broad, low-lying, typically crescent-shaped mound of sandy or loamy matter that is formed by the wind, especially along the windward side of a lake basin.
The circular hole in a guillotine in which the neck of the condemned rests.
In fortification , a detached work with flanks, presenting a salient angle to the enemy, intended for the protection of avenues, bridges, and the curtains of fieldworks.
In farriery , a halfhorseshoe, having only the front.
A blinder for the eye of a horse.
In architecture

The aperture formed by the intersection of any vault by a vault of smaller dimensions; particularly, such an aperture in a vaulted ceiling for the admission of light. Of this class are the upper lights of the naves of St. Peter's at Rome and St. Paul's in London.
A small aperture or window, especially if curved or circular, in a roof.
In a glass-furnace, the flue connecting the fire-chamber and the pot-chamber.
A watch-crystal flattened in the center; also, a kind of concavo-convex lens for spectacles.
In archaeology , a crescent ornament made of thin gold and intended as a diadem or gorget, found in ancient tombs of various epochs.
A work of art of such a shape as to fill a lunette, especially a painting or panel of such shape: as, the lunettes of Correggio.
One of the two open loops of steel which constitute the guard of the ordinary fleuret or foil used in fencing.
In artillery , an iron ring at the end of the trail-plate of a gun-carriage, to be placed over the pintle-hook of the limber in limbering up.
In the Roman Catholic Church , a crescent-shaped or circular case of crystal fitted into the monstrance for the purpose of receiving the consecrated host for solemn exposition.
A fieldwork consisting of two faces, forming a salient angle, and two parallel flanks. See bastion .
A half horseshoe, which lacks the sponge.
A kind of watch crystal which is more than ordinarily flattened in the center; also, a species of convexoconcave lens for spectacles.
A piece of felt to cover the eye of a vicious horse.
Any surface of semicircular or segmental form; especially, the piece of wall between the curves of a vault and its springing line.
An iron shoe at the end of the stock of a gun carriage.
a window which fills or partly fills a lunette.
See lunettes .
oval or circular opening; to allow light into a dome or vault
temporary fortification like a detached bastion

lunettes.explanation: A particular kind of spectacles / glasses , consisting of two circles lenses connected by a half-circle bridge over the nose.

lung.explanation: Either of two spongy, saclike respiratory organs in air-breathing vertebrates, occupying the chest cavity together with the heart and functioning to provide oxygen to the blood while removing carbon dioxide.
A similar organ in some invertebrates, including spiders and terrestrial snails.
( at the top of (one's) lungs ) As loudly as one's voice will allow.

One of the two spongy or saccular organs, occupying the thorax or upper part of the body-cavity, which communicate with the pharynx through the trachea, and are the organs of respiration in air-breathing vertebrates.

In entomology , one of the respiratory organs peculiar to those Arachnida whose tracheal system is modified into a number of lamellæ superimposed upon one another like the leaves of a book. They are also called pulmonary lamellæ and respiratory leaflets.
In pulmonate mollusks, a modification of the integument subserving aërial respiration: more fully called external lung. Huxley .
plural A bellows-blower; a chemist's servant.
An organ for aërial respiration; -- commonly in the plural.
a species of gentian ( Gentian Pneumonanthe ).
one of the breathing organs of spiders and snails.
A biological organ that extracts oxygen from the air .
either of two saclike respiratory organs in the chest of vertebrates; serves to remove carbon dioxide and provide oxygen to the blood

lunge.explanation: A sudden thrust or pass, as with a sword.
A sudden forward movement or plunge.
To make a sudden thrust or pass.
To move with a sudden thrust.
To cause (someone) to lunge.
In fencing , a thrust.
Any sudden forward movement of a person or thing resembling the lunge of a fencer; a plunge; a lurch: as, the lunge of a coach.
A long rope used to train a horse; also, the circular track or ring where horses are trained by cantering them around the edge of the ring in one direction with the aid of a lunge.
Same as longe .
A sudden thrust or pass, as with a sword.
To make a lunge.
To cause to go round in a ring, as a horse, while holding his halter.
Same as namaycush .
A sudden forward movement , especially with a sword .

A long rope or flat web line, more commonly referred to as a lunge line , approximately 20-30 feet long, attached to the bridle , lungeing cavesson , or halter of a horse and is used to control the animal while lungeing .
An exercise performed by stepping forward one leg while kneeling with the other leg, then returning back to a standing position.
A fish, the namaycush .
To make a sudden forward movement (present participle: lunging ).
To longe or work a horse in a circle around a handler (present participle: lunging or lungeing ).
make a thrusting forward movement
(fencing) an attacking thrust made with one foot forward and the back leg straight and with the sword arm outstretched forward
the act of moving forward suddenly

lunged.explanation: zoology , pulmonate: common in compounds, as strong- or weak- lunged.
Having lungs, or breathing organs similar to lungs.
Simple past tense and past participle of lunge .

lunges.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of lunge .

lungfish.explanation: Any of several freshwater lobe-finned fishes of the group Dipnoi of Africa, South America, and Australia, having a lunglike organ that enables them to breathe air, especially during drought conditions.
A dipnoan; any fish of the order Dipnoi.
Any fish belonging to the Dipnoi; -- so called because they have both lungs and gills.
air - breathing fish , of the class Dipnoi , that have four limblike appendages instead of fins
air-breathing fish having an elongated body and fleshy paired fins; certain species construct mucus-lined mud coverings in which to survive drought

lungful.explanation: As much as the lungs will hold.

lungi.explanation: A cloth, often of brightly colored silk or cotton, that is used as a piece of clothing, especially the traditional skirtlike garment of South Asia and Myanmar (Burma).
A garment worn around the waist by many people, especially men, in Southern India , Bangladesh , Burma , and Pakistan .
a long piece of brightly colored cloth (cotton or silk) used as clothing (a skirt or loincloth or sash etc.) in India and Pakistan and Burma

lungis.explanation: A long, awkward fellow; a dull, drowsy man.
A lingerer; a dull, drowsy fellow.
A lingerer ; a dull , drowsy fellow.

lungoor.explanation: A monkey of northern India, Semnopithecus sehistaceus , resembling and related to the entellus monkey or hanuman; the white-bearded ape. Also langoor, langhur.
A long-tailed monkey ( Semnopithecus schislaceus ), from the mountainous districts of India.

lungworm.explanation: Any of various nematode worms of the order Strongylida that are parasitic in the lungs of mammals.
A worm parasitic in the lungs.

Any one of several species of parasitic nematoid worms which infest the lungs and air passages of cattle, sheep, and other animals, often proving fatal. The lungworm of cattle ( Strongylus micrurus ) and that of sheep ( Strongylus filaria ) are the best known.
Any of several nematode worms, of the family Metastrongylidae, that are parasitic to mammalian lungs

lungwort.explanation: Any of several Eurasian plants of the genus Pulmonaria, having coiled clusters of blue or purple flowers and formerly used in treating respiratory disorders.
Any of various plants of the genus Mertensia, having drooping clusters of tubular, usually blue flowers.
A European boraginaceous plant, Pulmonaria officinalis.
An American plant, Mertensia Virginica , of the same family, at first referred to Pulmonaria. M. maritima is the sea-lungwort.
A lichen, Sticta pulmonaria , somewhat resembling in shape a human lung, and formerly regarded as a lung-remedy: same as hazel-crottles .
The toothwort, Lathræa squamaria , a reputed remedy for diseases of the lungs.
An herb of the genus Pulmonaria ( Pulmonaria officinalis ), of Europe; -- so called because the spotted appearance of the leaves resembles that of a diseased lung.
Any plant of the genus Mertensia (esp. Mertensia Virginica and Mertensia Sibirica ), plants nearly related to Pulmonaria. The American lungwort is Mertensia Virginica , Virginia cowslip.
Mertensia maritima , found on the seacoast of Northern Europe and America.
a lichen ( Sticta pulmonacea ) growing on trees and rocks. The thallus is lacunose, and in appearance somewhat resembles the lungs, for diseases of which it was once thought a remedy.
Any of various European plants , of the genus Pulmonaria, that were once used to treat respiratory disorders

lungyi.explanation: a long piece of brightly colored cloth (cotton or silk) used as clothing (a skirt or loincloth or sash etc.) in India and Pakistan and Burma

lunicurrent.explanation: Having relation to changes in currents that depend on the moon's phases.
Related to changes in currents that depend on the moon 's phases .

lunisolar.explanation: Of or caused by both the sun and the moon.
Resulting from the united action, or pertaining to the mutual relations, of the sun and moon.
that portion of the annual precession of the equinoxes which depends on the joint action of the sun and moon.

a period of time, at the end of which, in the Julian calendar, the new and full moons and the eclipses recur on the same days of the week and month and year as in the previous period. It consists of 532 common years, being the least common multiple of the numbers of years in the cycle of the sun and the cycle of the moon.
Based on both the lunar month and the solar year.
Pertaining to or caused by both the moon and the sun.
relating to or attributed to the moon and the sun or their mutual relations

lunistice.explanation: In astronomy , the moment of the moon's greatest northing and southing in her monthly revolution.
The farthest point of the moon's northing and southing, in its monthly revolution.
The farthest point of the moon 's northing and southing , in its monthly revolution .

lunitidal.explanation: Of or relating to tidal phenomena caused by the moon.
Pertaining to tidal movements dependent on the moon.
Of or pertaining to tides caused by the moon
Describing the difference in time between the crossing of a meridian by the moon and the subsequent high tide at that point

lunk.explanation: A tall, brawny man, especially a sexually attractive one.
A stupid man; a lunkheaded man.
A fool ; an idiot ; a lunkhead .

lunker.explanation: Something, especially a game fish, that is large for its kind.

yellow carotenoid pigments in plants and animal fats and egg yolks

luteinization.explanation: The formation of the corpus luteum from a mature ovarian follicle

luteinize.explanation: To cause the production of a corpus luteum in.
To develop into or become part of the corpus luteum.
To promote the development of the corpus luteum

luteinized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of luteinize .

luteinizing.explanation: Causing development of the corpus luteum

lutenist.explanation: One who plays the lute , a lutist .
a musician who plays the lute

luteocobaltic.explanation: chem. , containing a cobalt-hexammine constituent: as, a luteocobaltic salt.
Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of cobalt having a yellow color. Cf. cobaltic .
a brilliant reddish yellow crystalline compound, Co2Cl6(NH3)12, obtained by the action of ammonium chloride on an ammoniacal solution of cobaltic chloride.
Applied to certain cobalt compounds with a yellow colour.

luteolin.explanation: A yellow dyestuff obtained from the foliage of the dyer's broom ( Reseda luteola ).
A particular flavone , found in many vegetables , that functions as an antioxidant

luteoma.explanation: A rare tumour derived from a previous folliculoma or thecoma after luteinization , acquiring the ability to produce and to accumulate the hormone .

luteotropin.explanation: gonadotropic hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary; in females it stimulates growth of the mammary glands and lactation after parturition

luteous.explanation: Of a light or moderate greenish yellow.
Yellowish; more or less like buff.

luter.explanation: One who plays on a lute.

lutestring.explanation: A string such as was used on a lute.
One of certain noctuid moths: so called from the lines on the fore wings, likened to lutestrings: as, the poplar- lutestring, Cymatophora or ; the lesser lutestring, C. diluta.
A plain glossy kind of silk formerly used for women's dresses.
A plain, stout, lustrous silk, used for ladies' dresses and for ribbon.
A plain, stout, lustrous silk , used for ladies' dresses and for ribbon .

lutetian.explanation: In geology , the Middle Eocene Tertiary of the Paris basin, which takes its name from Lutetia, the Roman name of Paris. This stage is regarded as the probable equivalent of the Lower Bagshot and Brackle-sham beds of England.

lutetium.explanation: A silvery-white rare-earth element that is exceptionally difficult to separate from the other rare-earth elements, used in nuclear technology. Atomic number 71; atomic weight 174.97; melting point 1,663°C; boiling point 3,402°C; specific gravity 9.841 (at 25°C); valence 3. cross-reference : Periodic Table .

A metallic element separated from ytterbium in 1907, by Urbain in Paris and by von Welsbach in Vienna. It is a member of the Lanthanide rare earth group. Symbol, Lu; atomic number 71; atomic weight 174.967 [C=12.011]. Previously spelled Lutecium .
A metallic chemical element (symbol Lu) with an atomic number of 71.
a trivalent metallic element of the rare earth group; usually occurs in association with yttrium

lutfisk.explanation: dried cod soaked in a lye solution before boiling to give it a gelatinous consistency

lutheranism.explanation: The principles of the Reformation as represented by Luther; the doctrines and ecclesiastical system of the Lutheran Church.
The doctrines taught by Luther or held by the Lutheran Church.
teachings of Martin Luther emphasizing the cardinal doctrine of justification by faith alone

lutherism.explanation: That which is characteristic of or peculiar to Luther; also, an imitation of Luther.

lutherist.explanation: A student of Luther; one versed in or devoted to the study of Luther's life and works.

luthier.explanation: One that makes or repairs stringed instruments, such as violins.
One who makes wooden stringed instruments, such as violins, guitars, etc.
A person who, or a business which, makes or repairs stringed wooden musical instruments , such as lutes , violins , and guitars .
a craftsman who makes stringed instruments (as lutes or guitars or violins)

lutianus.explanation: A genus of fishes of the family Lutianidæ.

lutidine.explanation: The collective name of the various isomeric dimethylpyridines, (CH 3 ) 2 C 5 H 3 N. They are present in coal-tar oil and in animal-and bone-oil, and resemble pyridine in general properties.

Any one of several metameric alkaloids, C5H3N.(CH3)2, of the pyridine series, obtained from bone oil as liquids, and having peculiar pungent odors. These alkaloids are also called respectively dimethyl pyridine , ethyl pyridine , etc.
Any of several dimethyl derivatives of pyridine , but especially 2,6-dimethyl pyridine that occurs in coal tar

luting.explanation: lute (a kind of sticky clay or cement)
a substance for packing a joint or coating a porous surface to make it impervious to gas or liquid

lutist.explanation: One who plays on a lute.
a musician who plays the lute

lutjanus.explanation: type genus of the Lutjanidae: snappers

lutose.explanation: entomology , covered with a powdery substance resembling mud, which easily rubs off.

lutra.explanation: The leading genus of Lutrinæ , formerly including the sea-otters as well as the land-otters, now confined to land-otters in which the claws are well formed and the tail is terete. Compare Pteronura .
A genus which in some classifications considered a genus of the subfamily Lutrinae.
in some classifications considered a genus of the subfamily Lutrinae

lutraria.explanation: A genus of siphonate bivalve mollusks of the family Mactridæ ; the otter's - shells.

lutrinae.explanation: A subdivision of mammals including the otters; it is not used in some classifications.
subdivision not used in some classifications: otters

lutrine.explanation: Of or pertaining to an otter.
Belonging to the otter sub-family of animals.

lutulence.explanation: The state or quality of being lutulent.
The state or quality of being lutulent .

luvaridae.explanation: A natural family including the louvars.

lux.explanation: The International System unit of illumination, equal to one lumen per square meter.
Light: a Latin word occurring in some phrases used more or less in English.
Richness; superfine quality; elegance: said of material objects. Also luxe , as mere French.
The unit of illumination; the illumination received by a surface at a distance of one meter from a light-source the intensity of which is one hefner. See illumination , 1.
To put out of joint; to luxate.
In the International System of Units , the derived unit of illuminance or illumination ; one lumen per square metre . Symbol: lx
To put out of joint ; to luxate .
a unit of illumination equal to 1 lumen per square meter; 0.0929 foot candle

luxate.explanation: To put out of joint; dislocate.
To displace, or remove from its proper place, as a joint; to put out of joint; to dislocate.

luxated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of luxate .

luxates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of luxate .

luxation.explanation: The act of luxating (a bone), or forcing it from its proper place or articulation.
The state of being luxated; a dislocation, as of a joint.
The act of luxating, or the state of being luxated; a dislocation.
The act of luxating , or the state of being luxated; a dislocation .
displacement or misalignment of a joint or organ

luxe.explanation: The condition of being elegantly sumptuous.
A sumptuous edition as regards paper, illustrations, binding, etc.

luxemburger.explanation: a native or inhabitant of Luxembourg.
of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Luxemburg.
of or relating to or characteristic of the grand duchy of Luxemburg or its people
of or relating to the capital city of Luxemburg
a native or inhabitant of Luxembourg

luxullianite.explanation: A rock consisting of a finegrained mixture of schorl, feldspar, and quartz, through which are distributed large crystals of red orthoclase, found at Luxullian or Luxulian in Cornwall, England. From this rock was made the sarcophagus of the Duke of Wellington, in St. Paul's Cathedral, London.
A kind of granite from Luxullian, Cornwall, characterized by the presence of radiating groups of minute tourmaline crystals.
A kind of granite characterized by the presence of radiating groups of minute tourmaline crystals .

luxuria.explanation: self-indulgent sexual desire (personified as one of the deadly sins).
self-indulgent sexual desire (personified as one of the deadly sins)

luxuriance.explanation: The state of being luxuriant; abundant or excessive growth or quantity; strong, vigorous growth; exuberance.
The state or quality of being luxuriant; rank, vigorous growth; excessive abundance produced by rank growth.
the property of being lush and abundant and a pleasure to the senses

luxuriancy.explanation: The state or quality of being luxuriant; luxuriance.

luxuriant.explanation: Characterized by rich or profuse growth: synonym : profuse .
Rich and elaborate, as in decoration.
Marked by or displaying luxury; luxurious.
botany , having the floral envelop so multiplied as to destroy the essential parts: said of a flower: opposed to mutilated.
Exuberant in growth; rank; excessive; profuse; very abundant
Producing luxuriant growth; very fertile; -- of soil.
Having or producing an abundance of elaborate details; unrestrained; -- of imagery or ornamentation.
one in which the floral envelopes are overdeveloped at the expense of the essential organs.
marked by complexity and richness of detail
displaying luxury and furnishing gratification to the senses
produced or growing in extreme abundance

luxuriantly.explanation: in an abundant and luxuriant manner

luxuriate.explanation: To take luxurious pleasure; indulge oneself.
To grow exuberantly; to grow to superfluous abundance.
To indulge with unrestrained delight and freedom.

luxuriated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of luxuriate .

luxuriates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of luxuriate .

luxuriation.explanation: The act of luxuriating; the process of growing exuberantly.
The act or process of luxuriating.
The act of enjoying or experiencing luxury .
an activity that affords excessive pleasure and enjoyment

luxurious.explanation: Marked by luxury or a fondness for luxury.
Providing great pleasure or comfort, especially at great cost: synonym : sensuous .

Luxurious, Luxuriant. These words are now never synonymous. Luxurious means given to luxury or characterized by luxury : as, luxurious people; a luxurious life; a luxurious table. Luxuriant means exuberant in growth: as, the luxuriant vegetation of the tropics; by figure, a luxuriant style in composition. Luxurious implies blame, except where it is used by hyperbole for that which is exceedingly comfortable, etc.: as, a luxurious bed. Luxuriant does not come enough into the field of the moral for either praise or blame.
Of or pertaining to luxury; ministering to luxury; supplied with the conditions of luxury
displaying luxury and furnishing gratification to the senses

luxuriously.explanation: In a manner that involves luxury , in an expensive or indulgent manner.

luxuriousness.explanation: The state or quality of being luxurious.
The state or property of being luxurious , of being expensive or indulgently pleasant.
wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living

luxurist.explanation: One who is given to luxury.

luxury.explanation: Sumptuous or extremely comfortable living or surroundings.
Something that is not essential but provides pleasure and comfort.
Something that is desirable but expensive or hard to obtain or do.
Providing luxury.
Luxuriance; exuberance of growth.

A free or extravagant indulgence in pleasure, as of the table; voluptuousness in the gratification of any appetite; also, the free expenditure of wealth for the gratification of one's own desires, as in costly dress and equipage.

That which is delightful to the senses, the feelings, etc.; especially, that which gratifies a nice and fastidious appetite or taste; a dainty: as, a house filled with luxuries ; the luxuries of the table.
Exuberant enjoyment; complete gratification or satisfaction, either physical or intellectual.
Lust; lewd desire; lasciviousness; indulgence in lust.
Synonyms and Epicurism, effeminacy, sensuality, delicacy, gratification, pleasure, enjoyment, delight. See luxurious .
A free indulgence in costly food, dress, furniture, or anything expensive which gratifies the appetites or tastes.
Anything which pleases the senses, is not necessary for life, and is also costly, or difficult to obtain; an expensive rarity; Contrasted to necessity .
Lechery; lust.
Luxuriance; exuberance.
very wealthy and comfortable surroundings.
something desirable but expensive .
something very pleasant but not really needed in life.
very expensive
the quality possessed by something that is excessively expensive
wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living
something that is an indulgence rather than a necessity

luxus.explanation: In physiology , the consumption of more nitrogenous food-material than is necessary to maintain nitrogenous equilibrium, that is, to cover the actual wear and tear of the nitrogenous constituents of the body tissues: in such an event the term ‘luxus consumption’ is used.

luzula.explanation: A genus of monocotyledonous plants of the natural order Juncaceæ , the rush family, and the tribe Eujunceæ.

lv.explanation: Roman numeral for 55 (more common in upper case)

lvalue.explanation: A value that can be treated as an address or storage location.

lx.explanation: the Roman numeral representation of sixty ; six times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
Symbol for the lux , an SI unit of illumination .
the cardinal number that is the product of ten and six
a unit of illumination equal to 1 lumen per square meter; 0.0929 foot candle

lxx.explanation: The Roman numeral for ‘seventy’; hence, the ‘Seventy’ (Latin Septuaginta ) who, according to tradition, translated the Hebrew Scriptures into Greek; also the translation—the Septuagint itself. See Septuagint .
the Roman numeral representation of seventy ; seven times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
the cardinal number that is the product of ten and seven

lyart.explanation: designating a horse with dappled white and grey spots

lyase.explanation: Any of a group of enzymes that catalyze the formation of double bonds by removing chemical groups from a substrate without hydrolysis or catalyze the addition of chemical groups to double bonds.
Any of many classes of enzyme that catalyze the breaking of a specific form of bond

lycaena.explanation: The type genus of the Lycaenidae ; small slender butterflies with upper surface of wings usually metallic blue or green or copper.
type genus of the Lycaenidae; small slender butterflies with upper surface of wings usually metallic blue or green or copper

lycaenid.explanation: A member of the dipterous family Lycænidæ.
any of various butterflies of the family Lycaenidae .
A member of the taxonomic family Lycaenidae .
any of various butterflies of the family Lycaenidae

lycaenidae.explanation: A natural family of small usually brilliantly colored butterflies; males have short forelegs.
family of small usually brilliantly colored butterflies; males have short forelegs

lycanthrope.explanation: A man superstitiously supposed to be possessed of the power of transforming himself at pleasure into a wolf, and to be endowed while in that shape with its savage propensities; a were-wolf.
A person affected with lycanthropy; one who imagines himself to be a wolf, and acts in conformity with his delusion.
A human being fabled to have been changed into a wolf; a werewolf.
A human with a curse that causes involuntary shapeshifting.
a monster able to change appearance from human to wolf and back again

lycanthropist.explanation: One affected by the disease lycanthropy.
One affected by the disease lycanthropy .

lycanthropy.explanation: In folklore, the magical ability to assume the form and characteristics of a wolf.
A delusion that one has become or assumed the characteristics of a wolf or other animal.
The supposed power of certain human beings to change themselves or others temporarily or permanently into wolves or other savage animals. See werewolf .
The belief that certain persons change themselves into wolves or other wild beasts.
A kind of erratic melancholy or madness, in which the patient supposes himself to be a wolf. See lycanthrope .
The supposed act of turning one's self or another person into a wolf.
A kind of erratic melancholy, in which the patient imagines himself a wolf, and imitates the actions of that animal.
The act of shapeshifting between the form of a human being and an animal (usually a wolf), often done during a full moon , according to legend.
A delusion in which one believes oneself to be a wolf or other wild animal
(folklore) the magical ability of a person to assume the characteristics of a wolf

lycee.explanation: A French lyceum, or secondary school for students intermediate between elementary school and college, supported by the French government, for preparing students for the university.
a school for students intermediate between elementary school and college; usually grades 9 to 12

lyceum.explanation: A hall in which public lectures, concerts, and similar programs are presented.
An organization sponsoring public programs and entertainment.

[ capitalized ] An ancient public gymnasium with covered walks outside of Athens, near the river Ilissus, where Aristotle taught philosophy; hence, the Peripatetic school of philosophy. See Aristotelian .
A school for higher education preparatory to a university course. Compare college , 2 .
A house or an apartment appropriated to instruction by lectures or disquisitions.
A place of exercise with covered walks, in the suburbs of Athens, where Aristotle taught philosophy.
A house or apartment appropriated to instruction by lectures or disquisitions.
A higher school, in Europe, which prepares youths for the university.
An association for debate and literary improvement.
A public hall designed for lectures or concerts .
A school at a stage between elementary school and college .
a public hall for lectures and concerts
a school for students intermediate between elementary school and college; usually grades 9 to 12

lychee.explanation: An evergreen tree (Litchi chinensis) native to China, cultivated for its bright red fruits with sweet white pulp surrounding a large seed.
The dried fruit of this tree.
The Chinese tropical fruit tree Litchi chinensis , of the soapberry family.
That tree's bright red oval fruit with a single stone surrounded by a fleshy white aril .
Chinese fruit having a thin brittle shell enclosing a sweet jellylike pulp and a single seed; often dried

lychnic.explanation: In the Gr. Ch. , an office, consisting of psalms and prayers, accompanying the lighting of the lamps or candles, originally introductory to, but now incorporated in, vespers on occasion of a vigil.

lychnis.explanation: Any of various plants of the genus Lychnis of the pink family, including cultivated species such as the rose campion.

lychnoscope.explanation: In architecture , a small opening like a window, usually placed in the south chancel-wall of a church, and lower than the other windows, for what purpose is not strictly known. Also called low side window. Gwilt .
Same as Low side window, under Low, a.
A low side window in a church.

lycine.explanation: A colorless compound, HON(CH 3 ) 3 CH 2 COOH, or, in the anhydrous form, , contained in sugar-beet juice, cotton-seeds, and other vegetable products, and in urine. It forms large crystals which become anhydrous at 100° C. and attract moisture from the air, and is of considerable importance in plant physiology. Also called betain, hydroxyneurine , or trimethylglyein.
A weak base identical with betaine; -- so called because found in the boxthorn ( Lycium barbarum ). See betaine .
A weak base identical with betaine .

lycodes.explanation: The typical genus of Lycodidæ , with numerous species, of northern seas, as L. vahli of the North Atlantic. They are among various fishes known as eel-pouts.

lycodoid.explanation: Lycodidæ or Lycodoidea , or having their characters.
A fish of the family Lycodidæ ; or super-family Lycodoidea.

lycopene.explanation: A red carotenoid pigment, C 40 H 56 , found chiefly in blood, the reproductive organs, tomatoes, and palm oils.
A red carotenoid pigment found in tomatoes , other red vegetables , and in animal tissue ; there is some evidence that it may lower the risk of prostate cancer.
carotenoid that makes tomatoes red; may lower the risk of prostate cancer

lycoperdon.explanation: A genus of gasteromycetous fungi, founded by Tournefort in 1700, and typical of the order Lycoperdaceæ.
A genus of fungi, remarkable for the great quantity of spores, forming a fine dust, which is thrown out like smoke when the plant is compressed or burst; puffball.
genus of fungi whose fruiting body tapers toward a base consisting of spongy mycelium

lycopin.explanation: A colorless amorphous compound obtained from bugleweed, Lycopus. It has astringent, styptic, and sedative properties.

lycopod.explanation: A plant of the natural order Lycopodiaceæ.
A plant of the genus Lycopodium.
primitive evergreen moss-like plant with spores in club-shaped strobiles

lycopode.explanation: A highly inflammable yellow powder made up of the spores of species of Lycopodium , especially L. clavatum and L. Selago ; vegetable brimstone.
