A powder found in lycopodium , or club moss .

lycopodiaceae.explanation: a family of ferns belonging to the order Lycopodiales

lycopodiaceous.explanation: Belonging, or relating, to the Lycopodiaceæ, an order of cryptogamous plants (called also club mosses ) with branching stems, and small, crowded, one-nerved, and usually pointed leaves.
Of or pertaining to the family Lycopodiaceae of club mosses .

lycopodiales.explanation: Pteridophyta , coördinate with the Filicales and Equisetales.
lower vascular plants coextensive with the family Lycopodiaceae; in some classifications includes the Selaginellaceae and Isoetaceae

lycopodium.explanation: A plant of the genus Lycopodium, which includes many of the club mosses.
The yellowish powdery spores of certain club mosses, especially Lycopodium clavatum, formerly used in fireworks and explosives and as a covering for pills.

lycopsis.explanation: A genus of boraginaceous plants, of the tribe Borageæ , distinguished by having the corolla - tube curved instead of straight.

lycopus.explanation: A genus of labiate plants of the tribe Satureineæ and the subtribe Menthoideæ.
A small genus of nonaromatic herbs of the mint family.
small genus of herbs of the mint family

lycorine.explanation: A colorless crystalline alkaloid, C 32 H 32 O 8 N 2 , contained in Lycoris radiata ( Nerine japanica ), melting at 250° C. It affects the central nervous system.
A toxic crystalline alkaloid that inhibits protein synthesis , found in several plant species

lycosa.explanation: The typical genus of Lycosidæ. L. piratica is an example. L. tarantula , or Tarantula apuliæ , is the well-known tarantula of southern Europe.
The type genus of the family Lycosidae .
type genus of the family Lycosidae

lycosid.explanation: A member of the araneid family Lycosidæ.

lycosidae.explanation: The natural family of arachnids including the wolf spiders.

lycus.explanation: A genus of beetles of the family Malacodermidæ , having the head prolonged like a rostrum with the antennæ at its base, and the final joints of the antennæ as long as the preceding ones.

lyddite.explanation: An explosive consisting chiefly of picric acid.
An explosive, consisting of picric acid melted and cast into a shell. It is difficult to detonate.
A high explosive consisting principally of picric acid, used as a shell explosive in the British service; -- so named from the proving grounds at Lydd, England.
An explosive consisting mostly of picric acid

lydite.explanation: In petrography , Lydian stone, a black or dark-colored compact, hard rock composed of minute grains of quartz with carbonaceous matter. It was used by the ancients as a touchstone for testing gold.

lye.explanation: The liquid obtained by leaching wood ashes.
In a general sense, water charged with soluble solid matter by contact with a mixture of solid substances, partly soluble, partly insoluble.

Water impregnated with alkaline salt imbibed from the ashes of wood by the process of leaching; also, some solution of an alkali, as potash, which is itself the product of leached lye concreted by evaporation.
A strong caustic alkaline solution of potassium salts, obtained by leaching wood ashes. It is much used in making soap, etc.
Sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide, or a concentrated aqueous solution of either compound.
A short side line, connected with the main line; a turn-out; a siding.
A strong caustic alkaline solution of potassium or sodium salts, obtained by leaching wood ashes. It is much used in making soap as well as its use in biodiesel .
a strong solution of sodium or potassium hydroxide

lyencephala.explanation: Mammalia , including the marsupials and monotremes, or Didelphia and Ornithodelphia ; the implacental mammals.
A group of Mammalia, including the marsupials and monotremes; -- so called because the corpus callosum is rudimentary.

lyencephalous.explanation: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the Lyencephala.
Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the Lyencephala.

lygaeid.explanation: a true bug: usually bright-colored; pest of cultivated crops and some fruit trees

lygaeidae.explanation: A natural family comprising the lygaeid bugs.

lygeum.explanation: A genus of grasses, containing but one species, L. Spartum , found on stony soils in the Mediterranean region, particularly in Spain and Algeria. It is often called esparto because of confusion with the true esparto, Stipa tenacissima , but its proper name is albardin. Its tough, slender leaves are used in making baskets and for other coarse textile purposes. See albardin .

lygodium.explanation: A widely diffused genus of ferns with climbing stipes.
A genus of ferns with twining or climbing fronds, bearing stalked and variously-lobed divisions in pairs.

lying.explanation: the deliberate act of deviating from the truth

lyingly.explanation: In a lying manner; deceptively , mendaciously .

lym.explanation: A dog held in a leam; a bloodhound; a limehound.

lymantria.explanation: type genus of the Lymantriidae; a pest (Lymantria means `destroyer')

lymantriid.explanation: An insect of the lepidopterous family Lymantriidæ.
A dull-colored moth whose larvae have tufts of hair on the body and feed on the leaves of many deciduous trees.
Any of the moth family Lymantriidae.
dull-colored moth whose larvae have tufts of hair on the body and feed on the leaves of many deciduous trees

lymantriidae.explanation: The natural family comprising the tussock moths.

lymph.explanation: A clear, watery, sometimes faintly yellowish fluid derived from body tissues that contains white blood cells and circulates throughout the lymphatic system, returning to the venous bloodstream through the thoracic duct. Lymph acts to remove bacteria and certain proteins from the tissues, transport fat from the small intestine, and supply mature lymphocytes to the blood.
A spring or stream of pure, clear water.
Any antitoxic serum, as vaccine virus.
Pure, clear water, or any fluid similarly transparent.
In physiology , a fluid in animal bodies, contained in certain vessels called lymphatics .
A spring of water; hence, water, or a pure, transparent liquid like water.

An alkaline colorless fluid, contained in the lymphatic vessels, coagulable like blood, but free from red blood corpuscles. It is absorbed from the various tissues and organs of the body, and is finally discharged by the thoracic and right lymphatic ducts into the great veins near the heart.
A fibrinous material exuded from the blood vessels in inflammation. In the process of healing it is either absorbed, or is converted into connective tissue binding the inflamed surfaces together.
A fluid containing certain products resulting from the growth of specific microorganisms upon some culture medium, and supposed to be possessed of curative properties.
finely granular nucleated cells, identical with the colorless blood corpuscles, present in the lymph and chyle.
A colourless, watery, bodily fluid carried by the lymphatic system , that consists mainly of white blood cells .
a thin coagulable fluid (similar to plasma but) containing white blood cells (lymphocytes) and chyle; is conveyed to the blood stream by lymphatic vessels

lymphad.explanation: A galley with one mast and usually a yard upon it. Representations of such a galley, with three or more oars fixed in place for rowing, are common in Scotch heraldry.

lymphadenia.explanation: Enlargement of the lymphatic glands in general: a symptom of Hodgkin's disease.

lymphadenitis.explanation: Inflammation of one or more lymph nodes.
Inflammation of the lymphatic glands; -- called also lymphitis .

lymphadenopathy.explanation: An enlargement of the lymph nodes, usually associated with disease.
An abnormal enlargement of the lymph nodes
chronic abnormal enlargement of the lymph nodes (usually associated with disease)

lymphagogue.explanation: A therapeutic agent which promotes the formation of lymph.

lymphangial.explanation: Of or pertaining to the lymphatics, or lymphoid tissue; lymphatic.

lymphangiectasis.explanation: Dilatation of the lymphatic vessels. Also lymphangiectasia .

lymphangiectodes.explanation: Hypertrophy of the skin associated with dilatation of the lymph-spaces.

lymphangioma.explanation: A tumor composed of lymphatic vessels.
A benign tumour of the lymph vessel .
benign angioma consisting of a mass of lymphatic vessels

lymphangitis.explanation: Inflammation of the lymphatic channels , the result of infection at a site distal to the channel.

lymphatic.explanation: Of or relating to lymph or to the nodes or vessels of the lymphatic system.
One of the lymphatic or absorbent vessels, which carry lymph and discharge it into the veins; lymph duct; lymphatic duct.
pertaining to, containing, or conveying lymph.
one of the solid glandlike bodies connected with the lymphatics or the lacteals; -- called also lymphatic ganglion , and conglobate gland .

a temperament in which the lymphatic system seems to predominate, that is, a system in which the complexion lacks color and the tissues seem to be of loose texture; hence, a temperament lacking energy, inactive, indisposed to exertion or excitement. See Temperament .
Pertaining to lymph or the lymphatic system .
of or relating to or produced by lymph

lymphatism.explanation: A depressed physical condition, marked by low vitality, associated with the lymphatic temperament.
Enlargement or swelling of the lymphatic tissue , associated in the past with sudden death of children but no longer considered to be an authentic ailment .

lymphatolysin.explanation: A cytotoxin directed against lymphatic tissue.

lymphedema.explanation: Swelling, especially in subcutaneous tissues, as a result of obstruction of lymphatic vessels or lymph nodes, with accumulation of lymph in the affected region.
A dropsical condition of the tissues due to obstruction to the flow of lymph.
The swelling of tissue due to retention of fluid in the lymph vessels
swelling (usually in the legs) caused by lymph accumulating in the tissues in the affected areas

lymphoblast.explanation: A dividing cell that gives rise to a mature lymphocyte.
A leucocyte of lymph-gland origin, which possesses feeble phagocytic properties: distinguished from the myeloblast .
An immature lymphocyte ; they proliferate uncontrollably in lymphoblastic leukemia

lymphoblastic.explanation: Of or pertaining to a lymphoblast

lymphocyte.explanation: Any of the nearly colorless cells found in the blood, lymph, and lymphoid tissues, constituting approximately 25 percent of white blood cells in humans and including B cells, which function in humoral immunity, and T cells, which function in cellular immunity.

A typo of leucocyte found in the blood of all vertebrate animals. It is colored blue or purple with Ehrlich's triple stain, and occurs, in man, normally in the proportion of about 30 per cent. of the entire number of white blood-cells. There are two varieties, the large (11 to 14 microns in diameter), and the small (7.5 microns in diameter), the latter being the more numerous.

A type of white blood cell or leukocyte that is divided into two principal groups and a null group; B-lymphocytes, which produce antibodies in the humoral immune response, T-lymphocytes, which participate in the cell-mediated immune response and the null group, which contains natural killer cells, cytotoxic cells that participate in the innate immune response.
an agranulocytic leukocyte that normally makes up a quarter of the white blood cell count but increases in the presence of infection

lymphocytosis.explanation: A condition marked by an abnormal increase in the number of lymphocytes in the bloodstream, usually resulting from infection or inflammation.
The formation of lymph-cells; specifically, increase, actual or relative, in the number of lymphocytes in the blood.
An increase in the number or proportion of lymphocytes in the blood
an abnormal increase in the number of lymphocytes in the circulating blood

lymphogenic.explanation: Connected with, or formed in, the lymphatic glands.
Connected with, or formed in, the lymphatic glands .

lymphoglandula.explanation: An alternative name for a lymph node .

lymphography.explanation: A description of the lymphatic vessels, their origin and uses.
A description of the lymphatic vessels, their origin and uses.
A description of the lymphatic vessels , their origin and uses.
roentgenographic examination of lymph nodes and lymph vessels after injection of a radiopaque contrast medium; produces a lymphangiogram

lymphoid.explanation: Of or relating to lymph or the lymphatic tissue where lymphocytes are formed.
Resembling lymph; also, resembling a lymphatic gland; adenoid.
Like or relating to the lymphatic system of the body.

lymphoma.explanation: Any of various usually malignant tumors that arise in the lymph nodes or in other lymphoid tissue.
A hyperplastic mass of lymphoid tissue.
A tumor having a structure resembling that of a lymphatic gland; -- called also lymphadenoma .
a fatal disease characterized by the formation in various parts of the body of new growths resembling lymphatic glands in structure.
a malignant tumor that arises in the lymph nodes or in other lymphoid tissue
a neoplasm of lymph tissue that is usually malignant; one of the four major types of cancer

lymphopenia.explanation: A diminution in the number of the lymphocytes of the blood.
The condition of having an abnormally reduced number of lymphocytes in the blood
an abnormally small number of lymphocytes in the circulating blood

lymphopoiesis.explanation: The development of lymphocytes and associated tissue
the formation of lymphocytes in the bone marrow and lymph nodes and thymus and spleen

lymphorrhagia.explanation: Discharge of lymph from a wounded lymphatic vessel.

lymphosarcoma.explanation: A sarcoma which in the combination of retiform cells with lymphoid cells presents the structure of a lymphatic gland.

lymphostasis.explanation: Arrest of the flow of lymph.

lymphuria.explanation: The presence of lymph in the urine when voided.
the presence of lymph in the urine

lyn.explanation: An obsolete spelling of line , lin .

lyncean.explanation: Of or pertaining to the lynx.

lynceus.explanation: A name sometimes given to the constellation Lynx.
The typical genus of the family Lynceidæ.

lynch.explanation: To punish (a person) without legal process or authority, especially by hanging, for a perceived offense or as an act of bigotry.
To inflict punishment upon, especially death, without the forms of law, as when a mob captures and hangs a suspected person. See lynch law .
To execute (somebody) without a proper legal trial or procedure , especially by hanging .
To commit an act of violence by a mob upon the body of another person.

lynched.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lynch .

lyncher.explanation: One who lynches or takes part in a lynching.

lynchet.explanation: a bank of earth that slowly builds up on the lower slope of a ploughed field ; a feature of ancient field systems

lynching.explanation: The act of executing lynch-law upon a person; the killing of a person by a mob under pretense of summary justice.
Execution of a person by mob action without due process of law, especially hanging
Any act of violence inflicted by a mob upon the body of another person.
putting a person to death by mob action without due process of law

lynx.explanation: Any of several wildcats of the genus Lynx, especially L. canadensis of northern North America or L. lynx of Eurasia, having soft thick fur, a black-tipped short tail, and tufted ears.
A constellation in the Northern Hemisphere, near Auriga and Gemini.
A wild cat with a short tail, penciled ears, and 28 teeth, belonging to the family Felidæ and genus Lynx , such as the caracal, the loup-cervier, and others.
[ capitalized ] A genus of Felidæ lacking the front upper premolar of the true cats; the lynxes.
[ capitalized ] A small northern constellation introduced by Hevelius in 1690, the name being chosen because the sharp-sightedness of a lynx is required to distinguish any of its stars.
Any one of several species of feline animals of the genus Felis, and subgenus Lynx. They have a short tail, and usually a pencil of hair on the tip of the ears.
Any of several medium-sized wild cats , mostly of the genus Lynx .
short-tailed wildcats with usually tufted ears; valued for their fur

lyonetia.explanation: The typical genus of Lyonetidæ. L. clerckella is an example.

lyonetiid.explanation: A member of the lepidopterous family Lyonetiidæ.

lyonnaise.explanation: Applied to boiled potatoes cut into small pieces and heated in oil or butter. They are usually flavored with onion and parsley.
Cooked with onions , especially caramelized onions.
Prepared in a style typical to Lyons .

lyophilic.explanation: Characterized by strong attraction between the colloid medium and the dispersion medium of a colloidal system.
Having an affinity for the dispersion medium and thus not easily precipitated .

lyophilization.explanation: freeze-drying ; the removal of moisture from a frozen material using vacuum
a method of drying food or blood plasma or pharmaceuticals or tissue without destroying their physical structure; material is frozen and then warmed in a vacuum so that the ice sublimes

lyophilize.explanation: To freeze-dry (blood plasma or other biological substances).
to freeze-dry; -- a technique used to dry serum, tissue, unstable chemicals and other sensitive materials.
to dry (blood, serum, or tissue) by freezing in a high vacuum

lyophilized.explanation: dried by freezing and subsequent evaporation of the water in a high vacuum; -- used of tissue or blood or serum or other biological or sensitive substances.
Simple past tense and past participle of lyophilize .
used of tissue or blood or serum or other biological substances; dried by freezing in a high vacuum

lyophobic.explanation: Characterized by a lack of attraction between the colloid medium and the dispersion medium of a colloidal system.
Having no affinity for the dispersion medium and thus easily precipitated .

lyopomata.explanation: Brachiopoda , one of two into which the class is usually divided, the other being Arthropomata. Formerly called Inarticulata .
An order of brachiopods, in which the valves of shell are not articulated by a hinge. It includes the Lingula, Discina, and allied forms.

lyotropic.explanation: describing a liquid crystal that exhibits phase transitions as a function of concentration

lypemania.explanation: Insanity marked by an extreme degree of melancholy.

lyra.explanation: The middle portion of the ventral surface of the fornix of the brain ; so called from the arrangement of the lines with which it is marked in the human brain.

lyraid.explanation: One of the meteors sometimes observed about April 20th: so named because they appear to radiate from the constellation Lyra.

lyrate.explanation: Having a form or curvature suggestive of a lyre.
Having a pinnately divided leaf with an enlarged terminal lobe and smaller lateral lobes.

ornithology , applied to the tail of the lyre-bird, Menura superba , and of the blackcock, Tetrao or Lyrurus tetrix ; in entomology , to insects or parts which approach the form of a lyre or lyrate leaf.
Lyre-shaped, or spatulate and oblong, with small lobes toward the base.
Shaped like a lyre, as the tail of the blackcock, or that of the lyre bird.
Having a large terminal lobe and smaller rounded lobes toward its base .
(of a leaf shape) having curvature suggestive of a lyre

lyre.explanation: A stringed instrument of the harp family having two curved arms connected at the upper end by a crossbar, used to accompany a singer or reciter of poetry, especially in ancient Greece.
pianoforte-making , the lyre-shaped frame to which the pedals are attached and through which the pedal-rods work.
lyre of David or lyra Davidis.
See lire .
An obsolete form of leer .
In music
A stringed instrument of Egyptian origin, which became the national instrument of ancient Greece.
An element in the name of some instruments of the viol class, as the arm-lyre or lira da braccio, and the knee- lyre or lira da gamba. See lira .
A kind of metallic harmonica, mounted on a lyre-shaped frame, occasionally used in military music.
A kind of rebec used by the modern Greeks. See rebec .
[ capitalized ] A constellation. See Lyra , 1.
A verse of the kind commonly used in lyric poetry.
The Manx shearwater, Puffinus anglorum.
A grade of isinglass: a trade-name.
A stringed instrument of music; a kind of harp much used by the ancients, as an accompaniment to poetry.
One of the constellations; Lyra. See Lyra .
a small bat ( Megaderma lyra ), inhabiting India and Ceylon. It is remarkable for the enormous size and curious shape of the nose membrane and ears.
the leatherback.
A stringed musical instrument .
a harp used by ancient Greeks for accompaniment

lyrebird.explanation: Either of two Australian birds of the genus Menura, the male of which has long tail feathers that are spread in a lyre-shaped display during courtship.

Either of two large ground-dwelling Australian songbirds , of the genus Menura , named because of the beautiful tail feathers of one species, the Superb Lyrebird ( Menura novaehollandiae ) which can be erected to look like a lyre , most notable for their extraordinary ability to mimic natural and artificial sounds from their environment.
Australian bird that resembles a pheasant; the courting male displays long tail feathers in a lyre shape

lyreflower.explanation: A handsome, hardy perennial plant, Bikukulla spectabilis , with rosy-crimson flowers arranged in graceful racemes. see Dicentra and bleeding-heart , 2.
A garden plant ( Dicentra spectabilis ) having deep-pink drooping heart-shaped flowers.
garden plant having deep-pink drooping heart-shaped flowers
garden plant having deep-pink drooping heart-shaped flowers

lyreman.explanation: A cicada or harvest-fly; a homopterous insect of the family Cicadidæ , such as Cicada tibicen.

lyric.explanation: Of or relating to a category of poetry that expresses subjective thoughts and feelings, often in a songlike style or form.
Relating to or constituting a poem in this category, such as a sonnet or ode.
Of or relating to a writer of poems in this category.
Lyrical.
Having a singing voice of light volume and modest range.
Of, relating to, or being musical drama, especially opera.
Having a pleasing succession of sounds; melodious.
Of or relating to the lyre or harp.
Appropriate for accompaniment by the lyre.
A lyric poem.
The words of a song.
lyric poet.
A composer of lyric poems.
A lyric composition or poem.
A verse of the kind commonly used in lyric poetry.
Of or pertaining to a lyre or harp.
Fitted to be sung to the lyre
expressing deep personal emotion; -- said especially of poetry which expresses the individual emotions of the poet.
A lyric poem; a lyrical composition.
A composer of lyric poems.
A verse of the kind usually employed in lyric poetry; -- used chiefly in the plural .
The words of a song.
Of, or relating to a type of poetry (such as a sonnet or ode ) that expresses subjective thoughts and feelings , often in a songlike style
Of, or relating to a writer of such poetry
lyrical
Having a light singing voice of modest range
Of, or relating to musical drama and opera
melodious
Of, or relating to the lyre (or sometimes the harp )
A lyric poem .
The words of a song or other vocal music. The singular form often refers to a part of the words, whereas the plural form can refer to all of the words.
a short poem of songlike quality
expressing deep emotion
the text of a popular song or musical-comedy number
of or relating to a category of poetry that expresses emotion (often in a songlike way)
used of a singer or singing voice that is light in volume and modest in range
relating to or being musical drama
write lyrics for (a song)

lyrical.explanation: Expressing deep personal emotion or observations.
Appropriate for or suggestive of singing .
suitable for or suggestive of singing

lyrically.explanation: In a manner that is pleasing to hear, as singing.

lyricism.explanation: The character or quality of subjectivity and sensuality of expression, especially in the arts.
The quality or state of being melodious; melodiousness.
An intense outpouring of exuberant emotion.
A lyrical utterance or mode of expression.
Suitability to be sung or used as lyrics .
the property of being suitable for singing

lyricist.explanation: A lyric poet; one versed in lyrical composition.
A person who writes the lyrics of a song .
a person who writes the words for songs

lyricize.explanation: To write lyrically or in a lyric style.
To treat (something) lyrically; put into lyric style.

lyrics.explanation: The words to a song (or other vocal music).

lyrid.explanation: Same as lyraid , and now the more usual form of the name.

One of the group of shooting stars which come into the air in certain years on or about the 19th of April; -- so called because the apparent path among the stars if traced backwards crosses the constellation Lyra.

lyriform.explanation: Having the shape of a lyre .

lyrism.explanation: The art or act of playing the lyre; hence, musical performance generally.
The act of playing on a lyre or harp.
The act of playing on a lyre or harp .

lyrist.explanation: A performer on the lyre; a composer, singer, or reciter of lyrics.
A musician who plays on the harp or lyre; a composer of lyrical poetry.
A person who plays the lyre .
a person who writes the words for songs

lyrurus.explanation: A genus of Tetraonidæ , including the blackcock or black grouse, Lyrurus tetrix , in the male of which the tail is lyrate; the lyre-tailed grouse.

lysate.explanation: All the material formed by the lysis of cells

lyse.explanation: To undergo or cause to undergo lysis.
To burst or cut a cell or cell structure; to induce lysis .

lysed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of lyse .

lysergic.explanation: Used in designation of lysergic acid , lysergic acid diethylamide .

lyses.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of lyse .

lysidine.explanation: A bright red basic compound, , prepared by the action of ethylenediamine hvdrochlorid on sodium acetate. It melts at 105° C., boils at 195–198° C., and is used medicinally in cases of gout to remove uric acid, its salt with which is extremely readily soluble. Also called ethylene ethenyldiamine and μ - methylglyoxalidine.

lysigenous.explanation: botany , produced by the absorption or destruction of contiguous cells: applied to certain cavities or intercellular spaces in plants.
Related to or formed by lysigeny .

lysiloma.explanation: A genus of leguminous plants of the suborder Mimoseæ and the tribe Ingeæ , characterized by bipinnate leaves, usually a small number of stamens, and the valves of the flat, straight pod breaking away from the persistent sutures.
A small genus of tropical American trees and shrubs with pinnate leaves and flat straight pods.
small genus of tropical American trees and shrubs with pinnate leaves and flat straight pods

lysimachus.explanation: Macedonian general under Alexander the Great; with Seleucus he defeated Antigonus and Demetrius at the battle of Ipsus (circa 355-281 BC)

lysimeter.explanation: An instrument for determining the quantity of matter held in solution in a liquid.
An instrument for measuring the natural percolation of rain through a given depth of soil.
An instrument for measuring the water that percolates through a certain depth of soil.
an instrument that measures the percolation of water through soil

lysin.explanation: An antibody that is capable of causing the destruction or dissolution of red blood cells, bacteria, or other cellular elements.

In physiol. chem. , one of the hexon bases; a diamino acid of the composition C 6 H 14 N 2 O 2 , resulting on decomposition of most albumins, including the protamines. It is the mother-substance of the ptomaïne cadaverin.

A substance, found in blood serum, which, when injected into the body of an animal, will cause the dissolution or destruction of cellular elements. Such lysins may be produced artificially by immunization with various cells in animals of different species, and are then lytic for the corresponding cells. Such bodies are the hemolysins, the leucolysins, endotheliolysins, etc.
any substance or antibody that can cause the destruction (by lysis ) of blood cells , bacteria etc
any substance (such as an antibody) or agent that can cause lysis

lysine.explanation: An essential amino acid, C 6 H 14 N 2 O 2 , obtained by the hydrolysis of proteins and required by the body for optimum growth.

A colorless compound, CH 2 (NH 2 ) CH 2 CH 2 CH 2 CH (NH 2 )COOH, formed by the action of dilute acids or of trypsin on albuminous substances of both vegetable and animal origin. It crystallizes in slender needles and forms salts with both acids and bases. Also called α-ϵ-diaminocapric acid .
an essential amino acid found in proteins; occurs especially in gelatin and casein

lysis.explanation: The dissolution or destruction of cells, such as blood cells or bacteria, as by the action of a specific lysin that disrupts the cell membrane.
The gradual subsiding of the symptoms of an acute disease.
The dissolution of various cells by means of lysins.
In medicine , the gradual recession of a disease, as distinguished from crisis , in which the change for the better is more abrupt.
In architecture , a plinth or step above the cornice of the podium of some Roman temples. When present in a columnar edifice, it constitutes the stylobate proper.
The resolution or favorable termination of a disease, coming on gradually and not marked by abrupt change.
A gradual recovery from disease (opposed to crisis ).
The disintegration or destruction of cells
recuperation in which the symptoms of an acute disease gradually subside
(biochemistry) dissolution or destruction of cells such as blood cells or bacteria

lysogen.explanation: An agent capable of inducing lysis.
A bacterium in a state of lysogeny.
A phage that can exist as a prophage within its host organism .

lysogenesis.explanation: The production of a lysin, or the initiation of the process of lysis.

lysogenic.explanation: Capable of causing or undergoing lysis.
of, relating to, or causing lysis
capable of producing or undergoing lysis

lysogenicity.explanation: the condition of a host bacterium that has incorporated a phage into its own genetic material

lysogenization.explanation: the process by which a bacterium acquires a phage that becomes integrated into its genome

lysogenize.explanation: become integrated into the genome of (a bacterium)

lysogeny.explanation: The fusion of the nucleic acid of a bacteriophage with that of a host bacterium so that the potential exists for the newly integrated genetic material to be transmitted to daughter cells at each subsequent cell division.
The incorporation of the nucleic acid of a bacteriophage into that of a host bacterium ; sometimes transmitted to daughter cells following lysis
the condition of a host bacterium that has incorporated a phage into its own genetic material

lysosomal.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or originating in lysosomes .

lysosome.explanation: A membrane-bound organelle in the cytoplasm of most cells containing various hydrolytic enzymes that function in intracellular digestion.
An organelle found in all types of animal cells which contains a large range of digestive enzymes capable of splitting most biological macromolecules .
an organelle found in the cytoplasm of most cells (especially in leukocytes and liver and kidney cells)

lysozyme.explanation: An enzyme occurring naturally in egg white, human tears, saliva, and other body fluids, capable of destroying the cell walls of certain bacteria and thereby acting as a mild antiseptic.
A bacteriolytic (or antibiotic ) enzyme found in many animal secretions , and in egg white .
an enzyme found in saliva and sweat and tears that destroys the cell walls of certain bacteria

lyssa.explanation: an acute viral disease of the nervous system of warm-blooded animals (usually transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal); rabies is fatal if the virus reaches the brain

lyssophobia.explanation: A nervous state produced by morbid dread of having contracted rabies.

lyterian.explanation: medicine , terminating a disease; indicating the solution of a disease.
Terminating a disease; indicating the end of a disease.
Indicating lysis , or the end of a disease .

lythe.explanation: The European pollack; -- called also laith , and leet .

lythraceae.explanation: herbs and shrubs and small trees with pink or purple flowers

lythraceous.explanation: Lythrarieæ ( Lythraceæ ), or having their characters.

lythrum.explanation: A genus of dicotyledonous polypetalous plants of the natural order Lythrarieæ and the tribe Lythreæ.

lytic.explanation: Of, relating to, or causing lysis.
Of or relating to a lysin.
of, relating to, or causing lysis

lytta.explanation: A thin cartilaginous strip on the underside of the tongue of certain carnivorous mammals, such as dogs.
A long vermiform rod of cartilage or fibrous tissue in the middle line and under surface of the tongue of a carnivore; the glossohyal of a carnivore; the so-called “worm” of a dog's tongue.
[ capitalized ] A Fabrician genus of Coleoptera : same as Cantharis .
A fibrous and muscular band lying within the longitudinal axis of the tongue in many mammals, as the dog.
A fibrous muscular band lying within the longitudinal axis of the tongue in many mammals , such as the dog .

lyxose.explanation: An aldopentose found in some bacteria
